body_text.text: A. Radiological hemostatic intervention in trauma (at admission) R.F. Dondelinger; Liège/BE Blunt trauma victims and selected patients with penetrating trauma are systematically investigated after resuscitation and haemodynamic stabilization with crosssectional imaging. Marginally stable patients with flank and pelvic trauma are also included. Computed tomography is a good predictor of the need for haemostatic arteriographic embolization, based on contrast medium extravasation observed on CT. Ongoing hemorrhage must be differentiated from small intraparenchymal or intramuscular "blushes" of contrast or venous bleeding. In centers admitting polytrauma patients, the CT and angiography units should be installed together within the emergency environment to minimize time delay between diagnosis and intervention and obviate transport of polytrauma victims. Traumadedicated interventional radiologists should be on call for optimal patient management. Ongoing posttraumatic retroperitoneal and pelvic bleeding is a primary indication for angiographic haemostasis, together with orthopedic fixation of pelvic bone fractures, avoiding diagnostic peritoneal lavage and laparotomy, when no associated visceral injuries, requiring repair, are detected on CT. Angiography should be carried out rapidly, before the patient decompensates from considerable internal blood loss. In patients with intraperitoneal visceral bleeding, arterial embolization can obviate primary surgery or potentialize surgical intervention or contribute to changing hierarchy of injuries to be treated surgically. Overall, haemostasis is achieved in 83 to 100% of cases. Failure to achieve primary haemostasis may occur, according to type of specific organ injury and coagulation and metabolic parameters of the patient, due to delayed intervention and underestimation of severity of injury on CT. Postembolization complications are few and are usually non-life threatening, and rarely carry definitive sequelae. Learning Objectives: 1. To differentiate CT findings of "ongoing hemorrhage" and "probably arrested bleeding". 2. To understand the importance of timely appropriate angiographic intervention for effective management of some specific sites of hemorrhage.

J.E. Jackson; London/UK Patients who are cardiovascularly unstable following trauma frequently require urgent operative therapy. There is an increasing trend, however, to treat those who remain stable after initial resuscitation conservatively. A few of these individuals, and some of those who required early surgery, will develop delayed complications that are often best managed non-operatively in the radiology department.

body_text.text: Most of these will occur shortly after the original injury but some may occasionally not present until months or even years later. This presentation will concentrate upon the imaging and endovascular treatment of vascular injuries that may occur. The diagnosis of a vascular injury is increasingly being made non-invasively with the use of duplex Doppler ultrasound, CT and MR. Contrast angiography, however, remains the gold standard in the diagnosis of arterial injury and in view of its potential for therapeutic intervention remains the diagnostic method of choice. An understanding of the relatively limited ways in which a vessel can respond to trauma is essential as it is usually the type of vascular injury that determines the method of endovascular therapy rather than the organ within which it occurs. It is equally important to understand how vessels respond to endovascular treatment in order to ensure therapeutic success and this presentation will discuss these points in detail. Learning Objectives: 1. To recognize the imaging findings in patients with vascular trauma. 2. To understand the different ways in which a vessel may respond to trauma. 3 . To recognize the importance of a meticulous angiographic technique in the diagnostic workup of a patient with a vascular injury.

body_text.text: A-003 C. Imaging and intervention of large vessel injuries J. Lammer; Vienna/AT Traumatic vessel injury can cause bleeding, thrombosis, embolization, or malperfusion due to external compression and spasm. Non-traumatic causes of acute large arterial emergencies include rupture of an aneurysm and pseudoaneurysm, dissection, embolization, and thrombosis in hypercoagulability syndromes. Ultrasonography is, of course, the imaging modality of choice in emergency cases. However, in central vascular injuries, spiral computed tomography with contrast enhancement is the imaging modality that provides the most information. 3D CT angiography may replace catheter angiography in some emergency cases. However, catheter angiography may be necessary for detailed information and before intervention. Stents covered by a plastic membrane (stentgrafts) are used to close large vascular lacerations, ruptured aortic aneurysms, and the entry tear of dissections. Embolization with coils is indicated if large side branches of the aorta are the cause of bleeding. Interventional radiology methods play a major role in managing vascular emergencies. Learning Objectives: 1. Imaging of large vessel injuries by angiography and noninvasive modalities such as CT-angiography. 2. Interventional treatment of traumatic arterial lacerations such as rupture and dissection by stents, stentgrafts and coils. The hip contains extensive marrow space in which various processes may occur. Disease processes involving the hip joint -such as trauma, osteonecrosis, arthritis and infection -can induce marrow changes. However, the conditions mentioned above are frequently not detected by conventional radiographic techniques until they have reached an advanced clinical stage. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has been successfully used to evaluate pathologic processes in the hip. The excellent spatial and contrast resolution provided by MRI facilitates early detection and evaluation of various disorders. With direct, noninvasive MR imaging of bone marrow, fractures and infiltrative diseases can be identified earlier than with radiographic studies. For imaging the marrow of the hip we use a combination of pulse sequences, including T1-w spin echo, T2-w turbo spin echo with fat suppression and turbo-short T1 inversion recovery. In selected cases contrast enhanced T1-w spin echo with fat suppression is applied. Radiological interpretation of the marrow space requires an understanding of normal maturation and recognition that the proximal femur contains variable amounts of red and yellow marrow. With MRI this variability yields normal patterns ranging from very uniform and homogeneous signal intensity to patchy and heterogeneous signal intensity. Signal changes depend on the pulse sequence applied. The marrow reflects patient health and may herald developing anemia with marrow re-conversion from inactive to active. Disorders to be considered include: marrow ischemia and infarction, transient osteoporosis, marrow oedema secondary to trauma, osteoarthritis, tendon pathology and infection, and marrow infiltration resulting from disorders such as Gaucher's disease or myelofibrosis. Learning Objectives:
body_text.section: To learn the angiographic techniques used in the endovascular treatment of vascular injuries.

The pelvic floor is complex, involving various support structures and sphincteric mechanisms for the viscera of the excretory and reproductive organs. Functional control requires interaction between nerves, muscles and specialised connective tissue supports within the pelvic cavity, and the integrity of these structures. Dynamic imaging reveals how the pelvis moves as an entity, how prolapse and intussusception develop, and the mechanisms of sphincter dysfunction. The traumatic effects of childbirth injury on the muscular structure of the pelvic floor and its sphincters may be visualised, and striated muscle atrophy secondary to nerve damage shown by MRI. The limited space in the pelvic cavity may prevent abnormal movement of one organ when another is distended; the concept of the "crowded pelvis". Imaging has made a significant impact on diagnosis in pelvic floor dysfunction, and by revealing the morphological changes from surgery, has directly affected operative technique. It is now an essential component of management of these disorders. Owing to time constraints, only faecal incontinence will be considered. Learning Objectives: 1. Understanding pelvic floor anatomy based on MRI.

body_text.text: Pelvic floor anatomy J. Stoker; Amsterdam/NL

The pelvic floor is a complex integrated multi-layer system providing active and passive support, maintains continence and coordinates relaxation during urination and defecation. Fascia and ligaments provide passive support, with the muscles of the pelvic floor, mainly the levator ani, giving active support. The pelvic floor has three layers, from superior to inferior: The pelvic fascia, pelvic diaphragm and perineal membrane, intimately related to the urogenital region, urethra, anal sphincter and vagina in women. The pelvic fascia comprises the endopelvic fascia and ligaments, mostly delicate structures not visualized at imaging. The levator ani muscle and coccygeus muscle are the muscles of the pelvic diaphragm. The constant muscle tone of these muscles combined with fascial stability, results in a dome-shaped form and also closes the urogenital hiatus. The perineal membrane is a fibromuscular layer directly below the pelvic diaphragm. Urethral closure pressure depends on the resting tone of the smooth and striated urethral muscles, and on a process of coaptation of the vascular plexus to form a complete mucosal seal. The supportive ligamentous structures of the urethra are complex and not fully elucidated.

The anal sphincter has a multi-layer anatomy with closure pressure by primarily the internal sphincter and coaptation by the anal cushions. Pubovisceral and external sphincter contract rapidly in response to any sudden increase in intraabdominal pressure to prevent incontinence. The nerve supply to the pelvic floor and related organs is by branches of the sacral plexus, including pudendal nerve, and by sympathetic supply of the hypogastric nerve. Learning Objectives: 1. To describe the principle anatomical structures of the pelvic floor. 2. To understand the inter-relationship of the pelvic floor muscles. 3 . To learn the morphology of the pelvic floor anatomy at magnetic resonance imaging. 4. To understand the relevance of integrity of the pelvic floor muscles for maintaining continence.

Pelvic floor dysfunction and associated pelvic organ prolapse represent a major problem in our present-day society, mostly afflicting parous women. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is assuming an increasingly important role in the more accurate delineation of the extent of the problem. This lecture will briefly review one of the main radiological methods for the dynamic evaluation of the pelvic floor: Functional cine MRI. After a more general definition of the method, details of the technique are given. Out of the literature the smallest common denominator for functional cine MRI can be defined as follows: High field system; patient either in supine or sitting position; fast gradient echo sequence; midsagittal slice orientation; either a stack of slices or repeated measurements at the same slice position with the patient at rest or straining. As image analysis plays an important role a critical survey of the parameters and reference lines in use is provided. Finally, while giving a summary of important findings within the different compartments, clinical applications, strengths and limitations of this imaging technique are described. All except two publications stress the usefulness of functional cine MRI in the evaluation of patients with organ descent and prolapse. This well accepted method allows for the visualization of all relevant structures. It is especially useful in the detection of enteroceles, and provides a reliable postoperative follow-up tool.

Faecal incontinence: Atrophy and tears E. Rociu; Amsterdam/NL When conservative treatment fails, faecal incontinence is most often due to local sphincter dysfunction: Tears or atrophy. Tears comprise asymmetric disruption of the sphincteric ring associated with scar tissue. Atrophy comprises generalised volume reduction of the striated muscle with fatty replacement regardless the integrity of the muscle ring. Disrupted sphincters can be surgically repaired. Atrophy is irreversible and cannot be locally treated. When a torn sphincter is also atrophic the surgical repair has poor outcome. In atrophic sphincters with or with-out tears, other surgical techniques like artificial sphincter implants, sacral neurostimulation or dynamic graciloplasty should be considered. In faecal incontinence due to local sphincter dysfunction, the local high spatial resolution of endosonography and endoanal MRI makes both techniques particularly suitable for diagnosis. Endoanal MR imaging is preferable for external sphincter disorders while endoanal US is preferable in cases of internal sphincter disorders, although this is influenced by personal experience. Endoanal US can be used as primary technique with endoanal MRI as second line technique, depending on local expertise and availability. When surgical repair is considered for a sphincter tear endoanal MRI should be performed as it is the only technique to exclude sphincter atrophy, a predicting factor for negative outcome. For coronary imaging, multi-detector row helical CT operates with an acquisition mode called retrospective ECG gating. With exposure times as long as 200 ms, the newest generation of multi-detector row CT allows for consistently good image quality when regular sinus rhythm is present and the heart rate is in the range between 40 and 60 beats per minute. The use of beta-blocker may become necessary for patient preparation aiming at a heart rate of 60 beats per minute or less. Patient room time is approximately 15 minutes and image reconstruction and post processing can be performed within approximately 10 minutes. The radiation exposure of a coronary CTA investigation and a diagnostic coronary catheter procedure are comparable (~5 mSv). A series of authors meanwhile have compared CTA and cardiac catheter to detect coronary artery stenosis. Because of the limited spatial resolution in CTA the definitive assessment of the degree of coronary artery stenoses still remains problematic. In addition, extensive calcifications may hinder the detection of coronary artery stenosis. Therefore, coronary CTA will currently not be suited to determine the progression in patients with known CAD, typical angina or obvious myocardial ischemia. These patients are still better approached by cardiac catheter examination with the option to perform percutaneous coronary interventions in the same session. However, the negative predictive value of CTA is remarkably high, making it a favorable tool to exclude a coronary macro-angiopathy and to avoid unnecessary cardiac catheter procedures in patients with unspecific symptoms. Basically, cardiac MRI techniques rely on the same principles as MRI in other parts of the human body. The heart, however, is one of the most difficult organs to study with MRI. Problems are related to cardiac and respiratory motion, variable pulsatile flow patterns, the large size of the chest cavity, the presence of often abundant surrounding mediastinal fat and difficulties to catch the electrical activity of the heart in a magnetic environment, etc. In the last two decades several techniques have been developed enabling the study of the heart in a reliable and accurate fashion. At present, not only can information be obtained on cardiac morphology, but also myocardial and valvular function. Myocardial perfusion and viability can also be studied and quantified. Imaging of smaller cardiac structures such as coronary arteries, is no longer a domain of specialized research centers, but can be performed on clinical MRI scanners equipped with cardiac MRI software. In this lecture an overview is given of the different cardiac MRI techniques Although diagnosis of hilar cholangiocarcinoma (or Klatskin tumor) is a domain of MRCP, demonstration of vascular compromise (i.e., non-resectability) is generally difficult. Single-slice CT is limited for assessing resectability (accuracy, 60%), because proximal tumor extent is underestimated. Preliminary experience with MDCT indicates that the extent of bile duct involvement may be better displayed due to multi-planar imaging capabilities. Single-slice CT is a very sensitive method for detection of pancreatic cancer. Axial CT images reveal tumor involvement of vessels running perpendicular to the slice. However, it is more difficult to assess tumor contiguity with vessels running parallel or oblique to the slice (hepatic artery, portal vein). CPRs along the ducts and peripancreatic vessels display extension of tumor much better for the surgeon. Isoattenuating tumors may be visible only by the presence of mass effect and obstruction, which is better displayed by CPRs along the pancreatic duct.

In conclusion, the role of MDCT in the detection and staging of cholangiocarcinoma and pancreatic cancer is emphasized. Information of a multitude of axial MDCT images can be condensed into a few CPRs along the ducts and vessels. Learning Objectives:

1. To learn about MDCT imaging protocols optimized for imaging of the pancreas and biliary ducts. 2. To learn about the usefulness of curved planar reconstructions for visualization of biliary and pancreatic abnormalities, especially for demonstration purposes.

A-017 C. Liver F. Caseiro-Alves; Coimbra/PT Multirow detector technology is a major breakthrough for liver imaging using computed tomography. Advantages rely upon an increased speed of data acquisition, z-axis coverage and/or high quality longitudinal resolution. MDCT permits not only to define the original beam collimation but also the desired final slice thickness by recruiting the appropriate combinations of individual X-ray detectors. The most striking applications in liver imaging results from the clear separation of the three distinct phases of contrast enhancement: the arterial phase, the portal venous inflow phase, and the venous phase of parenchymal enhancement. All phases can be acquired in two breathhold periods (B1 for arterial and portal venous inflow phase and B2 for parenchymal enhancement) using reduced slice thickness (typically from 2.5 to 5 mm) with free definition of overlapping reconstructions. For liver imaging, MDCT can provide enhanced focal lesion detection and characterization, and high-quality vascular studies increasingly requested namely in the context of liver transplantation. Due to the high speed of data acquisition, robust injection protocols must be designed in order to be able to exploit its potentialities. Since there is a high variability of individual phases of liver enhancement among patients, the use of an automatic bolus triggering recognition software is encouraged. Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the basic principles of MDCT for liver imaging. The field of diagnostic brain imaging has undergone astonishing progresses in the last decade, unveiling structural details and functional processes of the human brain with unprecedented and unparalleled sensitivity and precision, and providing revolutionary contributes to neuroscience research. The diffusion of high field MRI units for human studies throughout the world, with very high field MRI units, up to 8 Tesla, working in a few research centers and a larger number of MRI units with field intensity ranging between 3 and 5 Tesla, has permitted studies of brain cortex and of subcortical structures with high spatial resolution. The use of high definition three-dimensional acquisition sequences has, in turn, allowed accurate reconstructions of brain surface, also used as input of morphing algorithms to produce "inflated", "flattened" or spherical models of brain hemispheres. In these unconventional spaces, the investigation of brain functional processes is made much easier and more accurate. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) has become the most widely used approach for studying brain functions in humans. The rapid and widespread diffusion of fMRI has brought the functional examination of the brain within the reach of the whole neuroscience community and have appreciably stimulated research on the functional processes of the living brain. A further, very promising advancement of MRI, diffusion tensor imaging, has opened entirely new avenues to neuroscience research, permitting to highlight white matter bundles which connect brain areas to each other providing, in single living individuals, the demonstration of anatomical connectivity. Learning Objectives: 1. To examine the potential of new MRI techniques in the study of brain cortical and subcortical anatomy and in the evaluation of white matter connections. 2. To integrate the growing knowledge on brain anatomy with the evaluation of brain functions with fMRI.

A-022 B. Brain stem and cranial nerves J. Casselman; Bruges/BE The nuclei of cranial nerves III-XII are located in the brain stem and cervical medulla. The nuclei cannot be identified on MR but their location can be deduced if one can visualise the surrounding myelinated structures. This is best achieved using high resolution thin proton density and T2W TSE images with a long TR. In the same way, their fascicular course inside the brain stem can be found. The cisternal segments, surrounded by CSF, are best seen on axial high resolution GE or TSE T2W images with a thickness of 0.35-1.0 mm. The parasellar course of nerves III-VI, the complete course of the olfactory nerve and optic nerve and tract and the extracranial course of all nerves are best seen on coronal highresolution gadolinium-enhanced T1W SE images. The function of nerves V-VII-VIII-IX and X are more complex and must be known so that the neuroradiologist is aware which nerve (segment) he must visualise to find the cause of a certain clinical sign. This is sometimes impossible as the correlation between "clinical sign" and "involved nerve branch" can be poor (e.g. trigeminal nerve). Moreover, connections exist between cranial nerves (e.g. V-VII-IX) and their brain stem nuclei (e.g. IX-X-XI). Therefore certain nerves are best imaged as a group. Small peripheral branches of the cranial nerves and the connections between the cranial nerves must be known as lesions and tumors can involve/follow these branches and connections. Learning Objectives: 1. Learn how to localize nuclei and fascicular segments of the cranial nerves in the brain stem. 2. To find out which technique must be used to visualise the different cranial nerves and nerve segments. 3. To know the major connections between different cranial nerves and brain stem nuclei. 4. To understand which clinical sign correlates with which nerve (segment) involvement.

The normal anatomy of the spine and its contents will be presented in terms of function with respect to the biomechanics of the skeletal structures as well as the movements of the spinal cord and the cerebral spinal fluid. It is shown how the spinal cord is adapted to these movements by tension, stretching and displacement. The biomechanical factors that are responsible for the development of chronic vertebrogenic myelopathy as well as the meaning of the axial spinal load will be explained. The anatomical background for loading tests is elucidated. The involvement of different anatomical structures such as viscous, elastic and bony elements is analyzed with regard to the explanation of the functional spinal unit and spinal instability and regions of motion.
body_text.section: C. Spine, spinal cord and circulation of cerebrospinal fluid M. Schumacher; Freiburg/DE

body_text.text: Learning Objectives: 1. To learn how anatomy and function in diseases of the spine are related to each other. 2. To learn that static investigation of the spine and spinal cord is not enough and how it has to be combined with functional tests. 3. To know how biomechanical stress produces pain and immobilisation. Several imaging modalities are used to visualize salivary glands including plain films, conventional sialography, ultrasound, CT, CT sialography, MRI, MR sialography and nuclear medicine studies. For a rational, cost-effective use of diagnostic imaging it is necessary to tailor the imaging approach to the patient's clinical problem/presentation. Two main clinical syndromes determine the appropriate imaging approach: inflammatory/obstructive syndrome and mass lesion syndrome. Whereas patients presenting with inflammatory/obstructive syndrome are best evaluated with ultrasound and some form of sialography, patients presenting with mass lesion syndrome are preferably evaluated with CT or MR. Sialolithiasis and several infectious and non-infectious sialoadenitis are the most common entities presenting with obstructive/inflammatory syndrome, whereas benign and malignant neoplasms present with mass lesion syndrome. Imaging differentiates sialolithiasis from other causes of sialoadenitis, identifies the location and number of calculi, detects post-obstructive changes and may establish the etiology of a few acute and chronic sialoadenitis. Patients with mass lesion syndrome present with a palpable mass. Imaging is tailored to characterize that mass (cystic/solid, benign appearing/aggressive) to determine its precise anatomic location and to determine whether it is single or multiple; features which help narrow the differential diagnoses. It may also be used to guide fine needle biopsy. Learning Objectives: 1. Become familiar with the most common clinical presentations of salivary gland pathology. 2. Be able to do a cost-effective imaging approach of the most common salivary clinical syndromes. 3. Understand the advantages and limitations of the available imaging modalities. 4. Be able to built a clinically useful differential list based on imaging features.

body_text.text: A-025 B. The value of MR sialography today M. Becker; Geneva/CH Similar to MR cholangiography, MR sialography is based on the priciple that stationary fluids are hyperintense on heavily T2 weighted images. This lecture will first review the different pulse sequences that can be used to perform MR sialography, such as 2D and 3D FSE, RARE, HASTE, GRASE, 3D CISS and 3D EX-PRESS. It will discuss their relative advantages and disadvantages, as well as their performance in the diagnosis and management of non-neoplastic diseases affecting the major salivary glands. Emphasis will be placed on the assessment of sialolithiasis, chronic recurrent sialadenitis and sialodochitis, autoimmune diseases, sialosis and cysts. Data from the literature comparing the performance of MR sialography with conventional X-ray sialography will be discussed. Sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative predictive values of the most useful MR sialography sequences will be discussed, as well as how to integrate the information available from these imaging studies with the clinical findings and non-radiologic diagnostic tests. Emphasis will be placed on the correlation between clinical and pathologic presentation and MR sialography findings. In addition, the implications of a precise pretheraputic work-up, as well as the key questions the radiologist has to answer in a specific clinical context will be discussed with respect to treatment. Learning Objectives:

body_text.text: A-026 C. Differential diagnosis in major and minor salivary gland tumors N.J.M. Freling; Amsterdam/NL Differential diagnosis of salivary gland masses depends largely on the location of the lesion: preauricular area, parapharyngeal space (PPS), oral cavity (OC), sublingual / submandibular space (SMS). Depending on the tissues within these specific areas, one may assume a different origin of the lesion: major or minor salivary gland, lymph nodes, bone (mandible, skull base), odontogenic, masticator muscles, PPS, subcutaneous origin, vascular. Imaging will help differentiate a solid from a cystic or vascular lesion, and solitary from multiple lesions. To differentiate benign from malignant salivary gland lesions is not always possible. Salivary gland tumours are rare and make up about 3% of all tumours in the general population. About 1% of all head and neck tumours are of salivary origin. Parotid tumours are benign in up to 75%, submandibular and minor salivary gland tumours are malignant in about 50%, sublingual gland tumours are malignant in more than 90%. The age of the patient at presentation will greatly influence differential diagnosis: although solid salivary gland tumours may also occur in children, most of the mass lesions presenting at a very young age are due to vascular or lymphatic malformations. In the adult or elderly, solid salivary tumours outweigh vascular lesions.
body_text.section: C. Spine, spinal cord and circulation of cerebrospinal fluid M. Schumacher; Freiburg/DE

To make a differential diagnosis in view of patient data, clinical data and imaging results. 4. To advise next steps in making a final diagnosis (more imaging, FNAC, biopsy, medical treatment). 5. To consider rare minor salivary gland disease at specific anatomic locations.

body_text.text: The development of wireless networks and terminal devices has made mobile communication to image archive systems possible. The access is nowadays possible outside the fixed hospital network and even outside physical hospital boundaries. The mobile teleradiology units are based on different technical platforms ranging from laptop computers to mobile phones. Most promising terminal types for medical purposes types are smartphones with computer functions, personal digital assistants (PDA) with phone capabilities or tablet PC devices with networking capabilities. Various wireless networks are available ranging from WLAN to GSM and GPRS. The main limitations of current technology are relatively slow network speed, restricted computational power and a small display for image viewing purposes. For selected tasks their service is acceptable even today. The clinical needs are basically twofold: within a hospital there is a need to serve the users of electronic record with radiological images. A tablet PC might be one mobile tool replacing a paper journal on wards. On the other hand, mobile teleradiology terminals have so far been used for viewing images needing a secondary consultation. A neuroradiologist on duty can make his remarks on an emergency CT scan with a help of a image phone. A neurosurgeon can make decisions based on image data even before entering the hospital. The benefit of mobile devices will be greatest, if they can be connected to a comprehensive electronic patient record. Especially well they perform together with a web type multimedia medical record where only a thin client software is needed. Learning Objectives:

body_text.text: A-029 C. European Union perspective L. Beolchi; Brussels/BE The European Commission is one of the major public research funding provider in the World. Through the 6 th Framework Programme for Research and Development (2002 Development ( -2006 it has identified the medical sector as one of the major of area of interest, medical imaging representing a large part of it. In the past 5 th Framework Programme more than 50 large scale research projects were centred on medical imaging, mainly through the programmes managed from DG INFSO (Information Society) and DG RTD (Research). In the 6 th Framework Programme brand new instruments supporting the already existing ones are the Integrated Projects (very large scale R&TD projects) and the networks of excellence as synergetic cluster of Institutions creating all together the critical mass for fostering research on specific topics. Among the challenges for medical imaging in the on coming programme, biomedical informatics, biomolecular imaging, micro and nanotechnology and specific applications of the GRID technology to medical imaging were identified. The regional aspects and the international co-operation are to be considered as peculiar and promising feature of the European Programme. Occlusive aortoiliac disease has been treated in the past by open surgery. Regardless of the type of open surgery, it always carries a considerable morbidity and mortality, 9-20% and 1-5%, respectively. In comparison, the perioperative mortality associated with aortoiliac interventions, including PTA and stenting, is less than 1% and the morbidity is limited to 10%. Personal experience from percutaneous stent recanalization of 76 occluded iliac arteries resulted in anatomical success in 74 (97%) limbs, no perioperative mortality and 10% major complications. The patency rate in surgically placed grafts is generally higher than that for endovascular interventions. The latter, however, do not preclude subsequent endovascular reinterventions and, if these fail, open surgery. The patency rate in the above-mentoned percutaneously stent-recanalized occluded iliac arteries was 79% primary and 87% secondary patency at 1 year, and 69% primary and 81% secondary patency at 3 years.

body_text.text: The less invasive nature of endovascular interventions, including stenting, makes them the first option of treatment in aortoiliac occlusive disease. Open surgery today is reserved for very extensive occlusions of the aortoiliac segment and for those in whom endovascular interventions may fail. Patients suffering from ischemic symptoms of the lower limb can present with acute, sub-acute or chronic symptoms. According to the clinical status, appropriate management should be discussed on a multi-specialist approach in which interventionnal radiologists play a full role. This requires well understood imaging technique in which arteriography still plays a central role. In case of acute ischemia, aspiration and lysis are feasible, useful and less invasive than surgery. In case of critical ischemia the consensus favours endovascular intervention in the first line and primary bypass is less commonly indicated. In case of chronic ischemia such as severe claudication, angioplasty is the technique of choice but medical treatment is also often appropriate at least in the beginning. Stents can be used selectively but less often than in the aorto-iliac segment. Appropriate clinical knowledge of the general features of atheromatous disease and the ability to manage a patient globally including consultation are important features that interventionnal radiologists should maintain and teach. A-032

Carotid stenting is more and more indicated in the treatment of carotid bifurcational disease as an alternative to open surgery. More and more data is becoming available that shows no significant difference between surgery and PTA in early follow-up, but recently also in the longer term (CAVATAS). One study showed advantages of stenting over surgery in early follow-up (SAPPHIRE). The technique of carotid stenting is pretty straightforward but the potential risks of embolization have led to an increased use of protection devices. Their role is still ill-defined and some complications may be related to those devices. Appropriate manual handling techniques for devices, guiding catheters and stents are mandatory for success in carotid lesions. A new approach is offered by virtual reality training facilities that allow safe training of basic techniques prior to real clinical application. Learning Objectives: 1. New developments in carotid stenting: Strategies for using new generation protection devices and new self-expanding stents. 2. Potential techniques to reduce risk of particle embolization. 3 . New ways to establish training among starters by computer-assisted training and training seminars. 4. At the end of this presentation the audience will be up to date with the technology and techniques. This review includes infections of the vertebral body (spondylitis), intervertebral disc (spondylodiscitis), ligaments and paravertebral soft tissues, epidural space (epidural abscesses), meninges and subarachnoid space, and the spinal cord (myelitis and spinal cord abscesses). A wide range of infective organisms may be implicated and the incidence of some, notably tuberculosis, is rising due to increased immunocompromise and other factors. Imaging plays a key role in early diagnosis of these diseases, which may be severe and potentially life threatening. Infection may be acquired by the haematogenous route, by infection from contiguous structures or from direct inoculation. Of available imaging techniques, computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) offer the clinically most valuable methods of evaluating all the structures potentially involved in infection. Other imaging modalities such as plain X-ray films, skeletal scintigraphy and PET are briefly discussed as well. Although many signs are non-specific, indication is given of where appearances raise strong suspicion of infection. The extent of the inflammatory process is well evaluated by imaging, particularly in terms of severity and morbidity of clinical sequelae, which may be severe. Systematic analysis of the imaging findings as well as the most relevant clues to differential diagnosis are included in this lecture. In conclusion, spinal and spinal cord infections represent severe pathologic conditions that should be diagnosed in an early stage, avoiding serious musculoskeletal and neurological complications. MRI has nowadays the key role to play and should be employed as soon as infection is clinically suspected. A-041 C. Radiation issues and economic aspects F. Stacul, D. Dibilio; Trieste/IT Unenhanced helical CT (UHCT) is now considered the gold standard for imaging patients with renal colic. However some disagreements exist on the radiation dose to patients undergoing the procedure and on the cost of the examination. Different CT techniques are used; not surprisingly the X-ray dose calculations in the literature vary to a large extent. The delivered dose can be up to 5 times higher than that delivered by excretory urography. With single-detector helical scanners the dose can be significantly decreased by increasing the pitch; some authors report that the accuracy rate for stone detection is not affected. Multidetector scanners provide an increased radiation dose if CT parameters are unchanged. The dose could be lowered by decreasing the mAs, with individual optimization related to body size or using a geometric X-ray modulation. However there is concern regarding alternate and additional diagnoses that could be missed if the dose is lowered too much. The cost of a CT procedure in patients with renal colic can be compared with other radiological procedures following a careful analysis of the differential costs of each investigation (equipment, variable costs, personnel) and their common costs. In our environment UHCT has a cost which is 8% lower as compared to IVU. However multiple variable factors, both for the dose and cost analysis, suggest the data cannot be simply applied to other environments and similar evaluations look worthwhile in other departments. The plain film anatomy of the stomach and small bowel will be presented. Pathological causes of dilated stomach and small bowel will be be discussed as well as distinguishing features which may be present on plain films. Small bowel obstruction and its causes will be extensively illustrated as well as those conditions which cause abnormal small bowel mucosa such as mesenteric ischaemia. In the current endoscopic and cross sectional imaging era, upper gastrointestinal barium studies are being less and less requested. Trainees are less exposed to the techniques and the barium studies have become somewhat devalued. However these studies do have some advantages over other imaging techniques and will continue to be performed in the foreseeable future. Whilst endoscopy, with or without biopsy, is undoubtedly the prime method of upper gastrointestinal diagnosis, barium studies give a valuable overview of both anatomy and function. Compared to endoscopy they can give information about motility, identify subtle strictures, fistulae and positional abnormalities. Sometimes submucosal or extrinsic disease is better visualized and analysis of mucosal patterns (including areae gastricae) provides clues unavailable to the endoscopist. Occasionally large lesions are paradoxically to big for accurate analysis with the limited field of view of an endoscope. The third part of the duodenum and beyond are outside the reach of a standard diagnostic endoscopy, and the luminal views of these parts of the small bowel remain the domain of the barium radiologist. Unfortunately they probably represent the areas where radiological accuracy is at its lowest, and attention to technique is important in achieving the most from these studies. Besides surface coating, current research has primarily been focused on matrix selection, stent platforms, drug transportation and distribution, types of eluted drugs, and clinical randomized studies. The first clinical trial of sirolimus-eluting stent in PVD has showed promising midterm results. Late thrombosis/ hyperplasia secondary to delayed endothelialization remains the potential problem with this technique. 5. Brachytherapy has proven effective for in-stent restenosis. However, they have not been demonstrated to be valuable in the treatment of "de novo" lesions of the peripheral vessels. 6. Stent-based gene therapy is developing as a future concept. Intensive research is exploring its potential clinical values. It may not become reality within the next few years. 7. The sharply increasing number of commercial stents leads to the greater stent selection for PVD. Among these competing technologies, drug-eluting stents appear to be the front runner in achieving major breakthrough in maintaining post-stenting vascular patency. However, each above mentioned technique may find a niche in the treatment of PVD. The primary technical success rate for PTA of iliac artery stenoses is 95% (88-99%), in occlusions 83% (78-98%). The technical success rate for stents in iliac artery stenoses is 99% (91-100%), in occlusions 82% (80-92%). The complication rates are between 3% and 6%. In iliac arteries the reported 1-year primary patency rate is 78% (67%-92%) and 90% (78%-97%) after PTA and stenting, respectively. The Dutch Iliac Stent Trial demonstrated 2-years patency rates of 71% versus 70% in the stent group versus PTA group with optional stent placement. In superficial femoral artery (SFA) obstructions and IC the 1-year primary patency rate of PTA vs. stents seems to be equal (65-77% vs. 73-75%). However, in CLI the patency rate of stents seem to be better compared to PTA (73-74% vs. 47-60%). Randomized trials comparing PTA vs. stenting in SFA obstructions revealed similar 1-year patency rates of 25-85% for PTA and 63-75% for stents.

body_text.text: Peripheral stenting with short stents C.L. Zollikofer, M. Pfyffer, E. Schoch, R. Jenelten; Winterthur/CH Introduction: Stents have been advocated to improve longterm patency after infraingunal angioplasty. However, controversial results of primary stenting versus PTA alone have been published in randomized studies, the main problem being stent induced intimal hyperplasia. On the other hand the implantation of stents has proved an effective treatment to salvage insufficient results of femoropopliteal PTA due to elastic recoil, excentric calcification, or dissection/intimal flaps with a tendency for better results with shorter stents. With the assumption that short stents may cause less intimal hyperplasia we designed a study to salvage insufficient angioplasty results of the femoro-popliteal artery by placing one short balloon-expandable stent of only 10-17 mm in length at the area of greatest residual stenosis. 51 claudicants (Fontaine stage IIB) and 17 patients with critical limb ischemia were treated with one short stent (four patients needed more than one stent) for significant (> 50%) residual stenosis or intimal flaps after the initial treatment in the same session. The primary patency at 6, 12 and 24 months was 85.5%, 75% and 67% respectively. The respective values for the secondary patency were 95%, 93% and 93%. Conclusions: Though also short stents are not immune against intimal hyperplasia they seem efficient for salvaging unsatisfactory results of recanalisation and PTA also of long-segment lesions in the femoro-popliteal artery. Particularly the secondary patency at two years seems remarkable with no unplanned amputation in view of the fact that stents were used only in bail out situations and complex lesions. Our results compare favourably with the literature. Learning Objectives:
1. Indications for stenting in femoropopliteal angioplasty.
2. Techniques to deal with unsatisfactory PTA and possibly improve longterm patency.

Are stent grafts of any benefit in the femoropopliteal artery? D.K. Tsetis; Iraklion/GR Stent-grafts are an effective and minimally invasive alternative to surgery in peripheral aneurysms, traumatically induced lesions and arteriovenous fistulas of large caliber vessels. However their role in the inhibition of intimal hyperplasia remains controversial. Theoretically, a stent-graft excludes much of the atherosclerotic material in the arterial wall and potentially creates a substrate for a neointima to form. A pore size of 60-90 ìm is optimal for promotion of graft healing. The most well studied design is the Hemobahn self-expanding stent-graft composed of a thin-walled expanded ePTFE tube inside a nitinol sinusoidally shaped helically wrapped stent. This device has good radial force and is very well suited to popliteal artery applications due to its very high flexibility. Dacron-covered stent-grafts implanted in the femoropopliteal artery are associated with postimplantation fever and local pain in up to 40% of patients. Stent-graft related infection is a rare but serious complication. There is insufficient evidence to advise routine use of prophylactic antibiotics.
How to prepare a case that will be published in EURORAD

How to prepare a case that will be published in EURORAD J.-C. Kurdziel 1 , R.C. Sigal 2 , D. Caramella 3 , A.L. Baert 4 , R. Passariello 5 ; 1 Luxembourg/LU, 2 Villejuif/FR, 3 Pisa/IT, 4 Leuven/BE, 5 Rome/IT http://eurorad.org/ is the peer-reviewed online radiology database of the European Association of Radiology which hosts more than 2000 cases. Since its development in 1998-1999, submission has been fully electronic over the Internet and since 2003, DICOM images and videos have enhanced the content. The process of edition is comparable to the one of a conventional paper journal, with 144 peer-reviewers under the authority of 13 section editors and one editor-in-chief. Adhesion to the instructions to authors is key for getting a case validated and then published rapidly. The session will provide detailed tips and tricks to ensure a fast turn-over of a submitted case, especially for the case selection, the preparation of images, selection of references and preparation of texts. Learning Objectives:

To make participants familiar with: 1. What is EURORAD? 2. How to select a case for EURORAD? 3. How to prepare the texts for the case? 4. How to prepare images for the case? 5. How to select references and mesh tree numbers? 6. How to proceed with an online submission?

Since the early seventeenth century intellectuals have developed the use of measurement to determine the causes of disease and to evaluate the benefits or harms from various measures used to treat people. The science of "statistik" evolved into probability theory which led to mortality tables and the discipline of "public health". This in turn led in the twentieth century to clinical epidemiology and now currently to evidence based medicine. Doctors have struggled uncomfortably for over half a century with the knowledge that half of what we know is not true, and with the ethics of when and how to introduce measures that are probably, but not certainly, helpful. However it is unusual for solid evidence to precede the introduction of a new measure, and a large scale preventive medicine programme gains an almost unstoppable forward momentum, provided by the happy combination of probably doing good and the accrual of personal prestige and/or financial reward, supported by industry and politicians. Data from clinical epidemiology and especially randomized controlled trials can identify major error, but it may take decades of evidence before cherished notions are abandoned, as with the recent about turn on promotion of hormone replacement therapy for post menopausal women. This lecture will examine some of radiology's contributions to preventive medicine, especially tuberculosis, cancer, osteoporosis and pregnancy. The "doctor's dilemma" is as acute today as it was a hundred years ago. Learning Objectives: 1. To appreciate the problems inherent in evaluation of benefit versus harm in medical intervention. 2. To recognize the difference in ethics of screening versus clinical medicine. 3. To understand how often adequate data is lacking to know whether net harm or net benefit is accruing from some of our current practices. 4. To gain an appreciation of the value of evidence based radiology in trying to chart a course through conflicting data.

The barium enema is the standard contrast examination of the large bowel, either in single or double contrast. Water soluble contrast agents are indicated where there is a risk of perforation. Single contrast shows fine mucosal detail only where the beam is tangential, whereas double contrast shows fine mucosal detail both en face and tangentially. The mucosal surface is normally smooth, though lymphoid hyperplasia and the innominate groove pattern may be visualised.

A systematic method of interpretation and review of normal findings on the double contrast barium enema (DCBE) will be presented. Pathological changes may be considered as either elevated or depressed, or causing deformity of the bowel wall. Distinguishing features of polyps (elevated) from ulcers or diverticula (depressed), and the differential features of strictures will be presented. A detailed review of neoplasia (polyps, polyposis syndromes, diagnostic features and cancer risk; cancer and other tumours such as lymphoma), colitis (early diagnosis, differential features between ulcerative and Crohn's colitis, the acute attack, complications) and diverticular disease (features of muscle thickening, diverticula, complications) will be given and the differential features of extrinsic disease discussed. Vertebral injuries occur in a predictable and reproducible manner that is dependent upon the mechanism of injury. Each mechanism of injury leaves distinct imaging "fingerprints" regardless of the location in the spine. Basic principles include abnormalities of alignement and anatomy, bony integrity, cartilage or joint space, and soft tissues. The imaging features will indicate stability of the spine following injury and classify spinal injuries into two categories -"major and minor". The task of radiology is to establish the radiological diagnosis, classify it, judge stability and instability and lead further radiological evaluation in cases of nonagreement between the radiological diagnosis and the clinical (neurological) findings. Until the introduction of spiral-CT into clinical routine-work, conventional radiographs were accepted as the first-line "gold standard" imaging modality in severe spinal trauma, this is no longer acceptable. The false negative reports with the single use of conventional radiographs may reach 57%, which is unacceptable. Therefore today in severe injuries, the first-line imaging gold standard is (multi-detector) spiral-CT followed by MRI. While, CT allows exact visualization of all bony abnormalities, MRI will be used in all cases with an unclear neurological deficit, cord injuries, vascular problems, disk herniation, haematomas, bone marrow edema and ligament-problems. But in all these cases one must be aware that MRI and some CT-abnormalities may be seen only on delayed 24 hr images. So what is the problem and, with increasingly sophisticated technology, surely it is simple to roll out screening tests for all cancers? But screening is not without risk and must be done well to be successful. There is no place for the amateur radiologist "doing a few mammograms" a year. Those involved in breast screening must be part of a multidisciplinary team and their results subjected to regular audit. Only by such scrutiny will the false positive and negative results be within acceptable limits. Even in the best hands, most women subjected to regular screening between the ages of 50 to 70 will have at least one false positive mammogram result at some stage during their twenty years of screening. Three presentations will precede an opportunity for debate. Amongst topics to be considered will be the whole issue that while screening may lower mortality from an individual cancer, it may not necessarily lower overall mortality. Some patients may die from unrelated causes, rather than from the cancer that was 'cured' through screening. Another topical issue is the question of walk-in screening centres which claim to save lives by whole body CT or MR screening.
Ethics and science X. Bonfill; Barcelona/ES

The provision of public health services in Western countries at the beginning of the 21 st century is determined by the need to make the services ethically justified and economically sustainable. There are many strategies for deciding which health services are really effective, cost-effective and have the best opportunity cost and whose provision should be maintained, versus those which are ineffective or have a low cost-effectiveness or cost-opportunity ratio, and should be progressively discarded from public funding. In this context, evidence-based medicine has been proposed as a renewed methodology to inspire sound decisions, either at an individual or community level. However, modern, educated societies are far from passively accepting such restrictions. People are very sensitive and demand whatever seems capable of providing hope or avoiding suffering, particularly in relation to severe diseases. Culturally, the concept of prevention has been progressively accepted and many people are predisposed to undertake the different tests or treatments that technology is incessantly producing. On the other hand, less educated or wealthy people often face a diversity of barriers for benefiting from preventive services and interventions of demonstrated effectiveness. Screening is a paradigmatic intervention in that context, in part because is usually offered to millions of apparently healthy people. Therefore, any screening strategy should balance the methodological requirements of evidence-based medicine, the specific needs and health priorities defined by each particular country, the cultural values more prevalent in the correspondent society, and the struggle for keeping the concerned individuals informed. Learning Objectives: 1. In this presentation, screening will be discussed from the perspective of the balance between methodological requirements, cultural values and health priorities. 2. Concepts and details will be illustrated with examples taken from cervical, breast, prostate, and lung cancer.

The use of MR for whole body cancer screening S.C. Göhde; Essen/DE Coupled with a rolling table platform with an integrated surface coil, the fast imaging abilities of state-of-the-art scanners permit "whole body MRI". Data acquisition is based upon the 2D steady state free precession (TrueFISP) and the 3D VIBE (volumetric interpolated breath-hold examination) sequence, a fat saturated 3D gradient echo sequence with nearly isotropic resolution. Beyond a description of the technical requirements, this presentation will focus on two possible uses of whole body MR: Whole body 3D VIBE metastatic staging and whole body screening. For metastatic staging five slightly overlapping 3D VIBE data sets are collected following the administration of paramagnetic contrast. Preliminary results indicate that 3D VIBE whole-body MRI has the potential to emerge as an all-encompassing alternative to conventional multi-modality tumor staging. Beyond whole body coverage, the technique even permits dynamic imaging of parenchymal organs in the abdomen to enhance specificity.

For tumor screening special attention needs to be focused on two organ systems: the lungs and the colon. TrueFISP lung imaging is highly accurate regarding the detection of mass lesions beyond 5 mm. For MR-colonography the colon is distended with a water enema. Following the administration of paramagnetic contrast colorectal mass lesions become visible due to their inherent enhancement. Preliminary results document an excellent accuracy for this technique. Most breast cancers (between 65% and 80%) occur as sporadic malignancy among women without any elevated risk. The risk increases with age. Prolonged exposure to endogenous hormones increases the risk: early menarche and late menopause, nulliparity, late first full-term pregnancy and lack of breast feeding. The breast cancer risk is elevated in women who have a first degree relative (mother, sister or daughter) with breast cancer. Inherited mutations of BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes account for a very high relative risk of breast cancer. However, only 5% of all cancers are considered to have genetic background. 10% to 20% of breast cancers are DCIS, which carriers a 30% chance of developing into invasive disease. LCIS is considered not to be a precursor lesion, but it is associated with an increased risk. Some biopsy proven benign proliferative changes, in particular ADH or ALH, increase breast cancer risk. Ionizing radiation, for instance treatment for Hodgkin's disease, increases risk. Increased weight in menopause, western diet, alcohol, dense breast parenchyma, HRT and oral contraceptives are considered to have weak association to increased risk. The total average risk is 1 per 9 (11%). The risk of secondary cancer in the same (10% -35%) or in contralateral breast (1% -15%) depends on the size, histological type and grade of the tumour, completeness of tumour removal and postoperative therapy. Total "oestrogen burden" is undoubtedly the major risk factor for developing breast cancer. This is affected by reproductive history, exogenous hormones (oral contraceptive pill and HRT) and "lifestyle" e.g. obesity and alcohol which effect oestrogen metabolism and cellular sensitivity. HRT usage in the western population has become endemic (20 to 50% of women 47 -70 years of age). Oestrogen/ progestogen combinations (to protect the endometrium) have superseded earlier oestrogen only preparations for women with intact uterus. More recently synthetic oestrogen (Tibolone) has been introduced. It has been known for a long time that current HRT usage is associated with increased risk of breast cancer. This has been reinforced by WHI study (USA) and the Million Women Study (UK). The later implicates all preparations but combined oestrogen progestogen cause 4 times as many extra cancers as oestrogen on its own. In the UK current users are 66% more likely to develop breast cancer and 22% more likely to die from breast cancer than never users. The effect on incidence increases with increasing duration of use and wears off with in a few years of stopping therapy. Additionally HRT decreases both the specificity of screening mammography (i.e. increases recall rates) and reduces its sensitivity (i.e. increases interval cancer rates). Increasing affluence is associated with the benefits of planned families but also the problems of increasing obesity and alcohol consumption, all of which increase breast cancer risk. All these risks are amenable to change but the choices are not necessarily straightforward. A-062 C. Physician-patient relationship R. Chersevani; Gorizia/IT Radiologist -breast patient relationship may differ from that of other physicianpatient situations as it is not continuous, but sometimes rather brief, or with no real meeting among the two actors; there usually is no choice on behalf of the patient; imaging production is considered a technical and rather automatic procedure -depending mostly on "machines"; the perception or misperception is that diagnosis will always be achieved as the sensitivity of imaging techniques is always 100%. We are surely responsible for some of these issues as we have pushed women to early diagnosis indicating our best results and not the drawbacks. Patients want to trust their doctors, but in order to achieve this they need information. Women coming for breast diagnosis differ not only as far as being symptomatic or not, but also for age, health literacy, level of anxiety and fear, previous experiences with illness. There must be time for dialogue: to communicate results, to explain our diagnostic workup, obtain informed consent, explain causes of false diagnosis, show care and empathy in case of "bad news". This will not avoid the invitations women receive from the media and the web for a review of their results, will not change the very easy to apply hindsight analysis -no matter the bias -or pure mathematical concepts on cancer doubling time.

A correct approach requires dignity, respect, understanding and caring, for the patient and her needs, and it may not necessarily be a one-way relationship. Diagnosis and characterization of fat in the liver is a diagnostic challenge because with most diagnostic techniques the presence of fat in the liver will significantly impair the quality of the examination. MRI offers significant advantages in that setting. There are two basic MR techniques that can be used to detect and characterize fatty lesions in the liver: Chemical shift imaging and fat saturation techniques. Chemical shift imaging techniques take advantage of the difference in resonance frequency between triglycerides and water protons. In in-phase images the signal from water and lipid protons is additive leading to a high signal intensity of fatty lesions. In opposed-phase images tissues containing fat and water show a significant loss of signal because the signal from water cancels the signal from fat. Liver steatosis is defined as an abnormal accumulation of triglycerides within hepatocytes. US and CT examinations are severly impaired in case of steatosis and the ability to detect focal lesions is decreased. Both focal fatty change and focal sparing of the liver parenchyma may have troublesome appearance that may lead to a misdiagnosis of hepatic mass. MRI can readily differentiate these lesions from other tumoral lesions because focal fatty change is hyperintense on in phase sequences and hypointense on opposed phase sequences. The differential diagnosis of incidental fat-containing liver lesions includes focal fatty change, hepatic lipoma, angiomyolipoma, liver cell adenoma and hepatocellular carcinoma. In the setting of chronic liver disease a fat containing focal liver lesion is highly suggestive of HCC. Pulmonary infections are among the most frequent causes of morbidity and mortality throughout the world. In the non-immunocompromised-population, pneumonia is one of the top two infectious diseases and represents the most prevalent community-acquired infection (CAP). Nosocomial pneumonia (NP) is the leading cause of death from infection acquired in the hospital. In CAP, most individuals are infected through person-to-person transmission of microorganisms bound to or suspended in water-mucus droplets. NP is the result of aspiration of gastric contents or contaminated oropharyngeal secretions. Infections in CAP are commonly caused by gram-positive bacteria, atypical bacteria, and viruses. The most important pathogens in NP include aerobic gramnegative organisms and staphylococcus aureus. Viruses, protozoa, and fungi play an increasing role in patients with impaired defense mechanisms. In CAP and NP, the typical radiologic findings include lobar pneumonia, bronchopneumonia (lobular pneumonia), and rarely, diffuse bilateral interstitial disease. Nodules may be seen in mycobacterial infections. Complications include necrosis, cavitation, bronchopleural fistula, and pleural effusions. In both entities, the role of radiology includes detection and exclusion of pulmonary infiltrates (which may be difficult in NP), narrowing of the differential diagnosis, guidance of additional (invasive) procedures, and patient follow-up. Pulmonary infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with impaired immune function. In the last several decades, AIDS epidemic, advances in the treatment of cancer, organ transplantation and immunossupresive therapy has resulted in large numbers of patients who develop abnormalities in their immune system. High-resolution CT can be helpful in the detection, differential diagnosis and management of immunocompromised patients with pulmonary complications. The most common patterns seen at HRCT in acute pulmonary infections in these patients include nodules, tree-in-bud appearance, ground-glass attenuation, consolidation and airway disease. A systematic approach to the radiological evaluation of these patients is essential and includes not only HRCT pattern recognition, but integration of available demographic, clinical and laboratory information.

A specific pattern of involvement can help suggest a likely diagnosis in many instances. In angioinvasive aspergillosis, the characteristic CT findings consist of nodules surrounded by a halo of ground-glass attenuation (halo sign). Other fungi, nontuberculous mycobacteria, and viruses may also present as nodular opacities on HRCT. A "tree-in-bud" pattern was first described in diffuse panbronchiolitis and endobronchial spread of tuberculosis; however, this appearance can also be seen in bacterial, fungal, and viral infections. Ground glass attenuation is a common but nonspecific HRCT finding. In AIDS patients, PCP is the commonest cause of this pattern. Lobar or segmental consolidation are the most commonly encountered radiographic findings in parenchymal lung infections. Airway infections, presenting as bronchitis or bronchiolitis, are becoming increasingly more frequently recognized in immunocompromised AIDS and non-AIDS patients. Learning Objectives: 1. To summarize the high-resolution CT findings of some of the most common infectious processes seen in AIDS and in immunocompromised non HIV patients. 2. Describe some complications associated with pulmonary infections. 3. Learn key points in distinguishing infectious diseases from other non-infectious pulmonary disorders.
A-068 C. The spectrum of tuberculosis and non-mycobacterial tuberculous infection S.M. Ellis; London/UK

The spectrum of radiographic findings in pulmonary infections due to M.tuberculosis (TB) and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) are being increasingly discussed, primarily as a result of the increasing prevalence of these infections. NTM organisms are often overlooked as potential infecting organisms, diagnosis is often delayed and radiologists tend not to include NTM in their differential diagnosis. The literature on the imaging appearances of NTM pulmonary infections is now sufficiently large as to identify some features that would help to distinguish an NTM infection from conventional pulmonary tuberculosis (TB), allowing the radiologist at least to raise the possibility of NTM infection. This review is intended to describe the radiological features in the immunocompetent host, that accompany TB and NTM pulmonary infections and highlight the imaging features that would favour an NTM as the causative organism. A-070 B. Adult non-glial brain tumors A. Drevelegas; Thessaloniki/GR Non-glial brain tumors of adults include: meningeal and mesenchymal tumors, neuronal and mixed neuronal-glial tumors, cranial nerve tumors, hemopoietic neoplasms and pituitary tumors. Meningiomas and acoustic schwannomas are the most common non-glial tumors. These brain tumors produce symptoms and signs due to tissue destruction, local brain infiltration, or secondary effects of increased intracranial pressure. The symptoms of patients are dependent on the anatomic location of the tumor. Headache is the first symptom and with growth of the tumor, is present in the majority of the patients. Focal cerebral signs or seizures may also occur. In the evaluation of patients with brain tumors CT and MRI represent the two most important and commonly used imaging modalities. They have a significant impact on patients care. The technical improvement of CT and MRI and the introduction of new imaging techniques (SPECT, PET, fMRI) have significantly improved the detection and the evaluation of brain neoplasms. The goal of this lecture is to identify the adult non-glial brain tumors, to determine the role of imaging in the evaluation of patients with brain tumors and to show how to use the available information in order to determine the location and the extent of the tumor, to identify complications, to establish a differential diagnosis spectrum and to provide a non-invasive assessment of lesion grade. This information is very important and crucial in deciding between the different forms of therapy such as surgery, radiation and chemotherapy. Learning Objectives:

1. To define and classify non glial tumors. 2. To introduce clinical presentation in order to correctly manage the timing and type of radiological approach. 3. To provide basic information on semeiotica and explain radiological potentials in differential diagnosis, classification and staging. 4. To explain "how to correctly manage" a CT-MRI study (planes, sequences, c.e. meanings, needing extension of examination to the spine, etc). 5. To explain "how to" offer the best informative package for surgical planning (anatomical landmarks, conventional scan planes, 3D CT and MRI techniques for neuronavigation).
A-071 C. Brain tumors in children W. Reith; Homburg a.d. Saar/DE

The incidence of brain tumors in children is about 2.5 per 100,000 per year. Primary brain tumors are more common in the first decade than in the second; the peak incidence is between 4 and 8 years of age. Neoplasms under the age of two years are uncommon. About 400 children will be diagnosed of having a brain tumour in Germany each year. About half of them are located in the supratentorial region. Slightly less than half of all supratentorial tumors are astrocytoms, most are pilocytic or low-grade in origin. The optic chiasmatic-hypothlamic area is the most common location. Craniopharyngiomas represent another eighth of supratentorial neoplasms in children. Ganglioglioma, ependymoma, oligodendroglioma, meningioma and miscellaneous other uncommon tumors account for the remainder. About one third of posterior fossa tumos are cerebellar astrocytomas, and one third to one quarter are PNET/medulloblastomas. Brainstem gliomas represents another quarter, one eighth are ependymomas. Most cerebellar astrocytomas are pilocytic astrocytomas; intrinsic pontine gliomas are infiltrative and are malignant regardless of their histology at time of biopsy. Medullary gliomas behave more benignly. More than 90% of medulloblastomas (posterior fossa PNET) arise in the vermis. About 7% are found in the cerebellar hemisphere. Despite the fact that brain tumours are the most common solid tumour in childhood they are very heterogeneous, regarding clinical symptoms, pathology, treatment and prognosis. Imaging studies play an important role for diagnosis and follow-up. Head and neck cancer is uncommon, accounting for only 3% of newly diagnosed cancers per annum. Benign disease far outweighs malignant disease in general ear, nose and throat surgical practice and the radiologist has an important role in alerting the clinician to the possibility of underlying malignancy. Some "benign" presentations, for example middle ear effusions, sinus opacity and cystic neck masses, may indicate underlying malignancy and the radiologist needs to be aware of these potential pitfalls.

Once diagnosed, direct inspection provides excellent assessment of the extent of mucosal involvement by squamous cell carcinoma, but imaging is essential for evaluating the deep extent of disease and involvement of adjacent critical structures. Because these are uncommon cancers, the evidence base for treatment is small with few randomised controlled trials, and there is considerable variation in treatment strategies. The radiologist must be aware of local treatment protocols so that imaging is tailored to evaluate the critical radiological features which may affect the treatment offered to the patient. The status of the cervical lymph nodes is the single most important prognostic factor. Clinical assessment is generally regarded as inaccurate (sensitivity and specificity 60-70%) and radiological staging is used to increase accuracy. It has a particular role in upstaging disease in the clinically negative neck and the detection of contralateral disease, both of which will affect therapy. It is also important that radiologists and clinicians working together in this field use the same system for describing the sites of abnormal nodes for surgical planning. Learning Objectives:
1. An appreciation of the clinical context of head and neck image interpretation. 2. Awareness of radiological features which will influence treatment.

3. An understanding of the value of clear communication between radiologists and clinical teams. The nasopharynx forms an important boundary zone between the anterior and middle skull base and the parapharyngeal space. Diagnostic imaging is used in this region for morphologic evaluation, localization and staging of primary lesions of the nasopharynx. The nasopharynx forms the upper portion of the pharynx and is continuous anteriorly with the nasal cavity. The roof is formed by the sphenoid bone, while the floor and junction with the oropharynx are at the level of the soft palate. The pharygeal recess (Rosenmüller fossa) is a pouch-like recess in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx directed toward the parapharyngeal space and lying directly adjacent to the eustachian tube orifice. This region is a common site of origination for nasopharyngeal malignancies. Five percent of all malignant tumors of the head and neck originate in the nasopharynx and more than 90% of these are carcinomas. MRI is extremely helpful to demonstrate the extent of a mass in three dimensions and, most importantly, MRI can define the relationship of the mass to cranial nerves V, IX and X. However multidetector CT (MDCT) is also helpful in the evaluation of the nasopharynx, especially if multiplanar reconstructions are used. This presentation will focus on normal anatomy, benign and malignant tumors, congenital variations and malformations as well as the differential diagnosis. A-074 C. Oral and oropharyngeal cancer R.C. Sigal; Villejuif/FR In the oral cavity and oropharynx, cancer most often arises from the oral mucosa. Therefore the radiologist plays a minor role in the detection of the disease but helps to define the exact extent of the lesion. Imaging plays an important role in therapeutic planning. The choice for the various type of surgery (partial or complete glossectomy, mandibulectomy) is dictated by invasion of the muscles of the tongue, neurovascular bundle of the tongue, as well as the various sub regions of the oropharynx (faucial area, soft palate, posterior oropharyngeal wall). Evaluation of the mandible is of paramount importance. Computed tomography and MR imaging are the imaging modalities of choice. Imaging is also important in followup and in early tumor recurrence detection. Learning Objectives:

1. To present the CT and MR techniques in the exploration of the tongue and oropharynx area. Squamous cell carcinoma arising from the mucosal surface accounts for more than 95% of laryngeal cancers. Nowadays, therapy of these carcinomas aims to retain laryngeal function, so correct staging is essential to determine the accurate therapeutic modality. Deep tumoral spread is difficult to establish by direct laryngoscopy alone, so imaging modalities, including CT and/or MR are absolutely necessary to establish this staging. In this lecture, the tumoral appearance and deep spread at the levels of supraglottis, glottis and subglottis will be described on CT scan as well as on MR imaging. Respective role of these imaging modalities will be also discussed. Treatment of symptomatic patients with a carotid artery stenosis > 70% has been proven to be useful in 2 large prospective randomized trials. In these studies DSA was used to show the stenosis so this method became the gold standard. This method however is invasive, has a small complication rate and due to the limited number of projections, crossectional methods could be more reliable in showing the degree of stenosis. In the last 5 years MR angiography first without and later with contrast seems to be an acceptable alternative for angiography although claustrophobia and artefacts can obviate diagnosis in up to 20%.

The use of conventional CT and spiral CT to visualize stenosis has been unsuccessful due to swallowing, metal artefacts and calcification. Recently multislice CT offers new possibilities but its usefulness has not yet been proven in larger studies.

Since new techniques will never have a similar accuracy to the gold standard angiography, cost effective analysis is necessary to prove that the advantage of the non-invasive character of the new techniques (less complications) outweighs the disadvantage that it does not have as similar an accuracy as the angiogram. The aim of this presentation is to discuss the latest developments and studies combined with personal experience concerning carotid artery stent placement in the treatment of carotid artery occlusive disease. Due to the high technical success rates of 98%, the few peri-and postinterventional complications, the relatively fast procedure in experienced hands and the high patency rates, carotid stenting has become a substitute for carotid endarterectomy for symptomatic patients, even with high medical comorbidities. Today only a few exclusion criteria for carotid stenting exist, like the floating thrombus and the pseudo-occlusion at the carotid bifurcation and the occlusion of the arterial access (iliac arteries and aorta). The use of distal embolic protection systems has decreased the complication rates for carotid stenting by approximately 50% to 2-4% for most major centers. With the new and improved technologies concerning stent design, guiding catheters and cerebral protection devices, carotid stenting has become an option also for asymptomatic patients, especially those with high surgical risk. Early results for patency and neurological follow-up in these asymptomatic patients group have also been encouraging. Learning Objectives: 1. In experienced centers carotid artery stenting is currently a safe and reliable treatment for symptomatic, even at high-risk patients. 2. Cerebral protection devices should be used for the procedure. Osteoporotic vertebral fracture occurs in 25% of women and 5.4% of men older than age 50.
