Fifteen percent of these fractures do not respond to conservative treatment, and in this situation vertebroplasty began to be used as a treatment in the early 1990s. Indication: Persistent incapacitating pain caused by vertebral fracture that fails to remit on conservative treatment. Also acute fractures requiring hospitalization and parenteral narcotics. Contraindications: Coagulopathy, extensive vertebral body destruction, significant compromise of the neural canal. Method: Percutaneous injection of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) into the fractured vertebral body for the dual purpose of analgesia and stabilization. Success of the method requires suitable visualization of the cement and monitoring of the injection. There is no relationship between the amount of cement injected and the therapeutic efficacy of the procedure.

Complete or partial improvement in ≥ 80% of cases during the first 24-48 hours. The best results are obtained for collapse of less than 70% of vertebral body height and the presence of bone edema on MRI. Complications: Infrequent (0-5%) and mostly mild (temporary locoregional radiculopathy). Conclusion: Osteoporotic vertebral compression fractures are a common and significant public health problem, and vertebroplasty has proved to be a safe and effective therapeutic option. Adherence to rigid patient selection criteria is essential to ensure clinical success. More studies are needed to establish in exactly which patients vertebroplasty should be performed, long-term therapeutic efficacy, the cost-benefit ratio, and the role of biocements and kyphoplasty. Learning Objectives:

1. To understand the role of minimally invasive image guided treatment for spine instability due to osteoporosis. It consists of a direct puncture of the concerned area using a 10-15 G needle followed by an injection of bone cement into the weakened parts of the bone. The injection is performed under fluoroscopic control and the cement is set to harden within 7-10 min. During the injection, close watch on the draining veins is advised to avoid leakage of cement to nearby compartments where contact with the temporarily heated cement (PMMA, exothermic reaction) may lead to irritations. Leakage also may lead to pulmonary embolism. If leakage accounts for most complications, other risks include allergic reaction to bone cement, procedural complications related to needle positioning, or anaesthesia complications. To reduce the risk of leakage, we advocate using the injection of contrast material prior to the cement injection. In our experience, this predicts reliably the areas of leakage and allows to adjust the cement injection technique accordingly. In our experience of over 400 patients treated, the majority of lesions were oncologic, followed by osteoporosis, rarely due to vertebral hemangioma and nonpathological fracture. Overall, vertebroplasty has an immediate and lasting success rate of approximately 90%. Treatment failure may be related to not treating patients at all levels involved (multiple lesions) or for pain which can not be treated by vertebroplasty, such as due to associated degenerative spine lesions or due to retroperitoneal tumour spread. Complications are seen rarely (overall less than 2%, with a higher incidence in oncological patients). The diagnosis of osteomyelitis remains a difficult diagnostic dilemma. In this review, that is particularly aimed at those whose practice does not include a large pediatric population, we will review the pathophysiology of pediatric osteomyelitis and contrast that with the available imaging modalities. What we can do and the use of each modality will be the focus of part 1. Secondly, we will review the different clinical scenarios such as acute, subacute and chronic, as well as specific forms of osteomyelitis. The latter will include subacute chronic ostemyelitis, toxic synovitis, spondylodiscitis as well as the congenital inflammatory disorders such as rubella and syphylis. The most useful imaging findings to look for and their significance will be assessed and we will evaluate their usefulness in each case. Close cooperation between clinicians and imagers remains the key to early and adequate diagnosis of pediatric osteomyelitis. Learning Objectives: 1. To review the pathophysiology of pediatric inflammatory musculoskeletal disease as a whole. 2. To discuss how to optimally image the changes caused by the inflammatory process. 3. To assess how to practically and efficiently structure the imaging sequence for optimal contribution to the therapeutic process. The presentation is based on a three year longitudinal study of the implementation of PACS in the region of Scania, Sweden. The implementation can be seen as a part of building a common network (HIS) for the entire healthcare. Such a system makes it possible to deepen and develop different cooperation-constellations and change the functional infrastructure. A introduction to a PACS environment is not a change for just the X-ray departments, but for the whole hospital. It seems to be one of the most dramatic changes in radiology (Osteaux, 1997). In spite of this there is still a lack of knowledge of how this change effects the organisation and the professions in radiology.

In the literature, the implementation of PACS is described from different aspects. A great number of articles describe and explore the technology of PACS. This is very natural because PACS is very technically complicated and is still under development. Another aspect is the cost-benefit (Bryan et al, 1999). It seems like the arguments for the introduction of PACS have changed, from a tool to decrease costs in radiology to a medium to increase the efficiency. Large investments are necessary, and this makes the digital examinations still more expensive then the analogous examinations. Published articles show, not surprisingly, a wide range of results, from large savings to that you never get back made investments (Arenson, 2000). Many authors show a need to that PACS is analysed not only from economical and technical aspects, but also that it is important that organisational aspects will be illuminated (van Gennip, 1996 & Foord, 1999 . Further aspects that speak for this is that PACS is to compensate an, what many thinks, already well functioning organisation of handling images in a radiology department. Learning Objectives: 1. Identify the process of change: What are the obstacles and possibilities, and how is it experienced? 2. See different ways and outcomes of the process.

A-086 B. The workflow in a digitised radiological department M.K. Selim; Örebro/SE Radiographers have worked with digital techniques for procedures such as computer tomography, magnetic resonance imaging and digital fluorography for several years, but these examinations were presented and reviewed on hardcopy film and archived as such. With the new digital technology, images and patient information, including X-ray request forms, are integrated and saved in a digital archive. The areas with most changes for the radiographer in the digitised environment are viewing and post processing of general radiographic examinations. With the new digital system, the radiographers have adapted their way of working and also changed the workflow throughout the whole process immensely. I will present our experiences from working in a film-free digital department, how the radiographers have developed their professional roles and taken responsibility for the whole process while working with the patient, and the difference in workflow compared to traditional X-ray departments. The radiographers experiences from the digitised environment will be compared to working with the traditional analogue techniques. This new professional role gives the radiographer a better patient contact and an increased responsibility for both image production and nursing care during the whole examination. The radiological department has also achieved a simpler workflow without duplication of work. Learning Objectives:

After session completion, the participant should be able to understand: 1. The difference between digital and analogue working. 2. How digital radiography can develop the radiographer's professional role.
3. How digital radiography can achieve quality control, without double-checking the work.

The final diagnosis of prostate carcinoma still requires histological examination of transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) guided biopsy cores, either targeted at a hypoechoic peripheral zone lesion or obtained by any set of at random biopsies. Even though the majority of TRUS examinations of the prostate is performed by urologists, radiologists must gain experience to serve referred patients in the best possible way, including the performance of transrectal guided biopsies. Since US contrast agents are more generally used by radiologists, and since there are promising data on the use of contrast agents in prostate US, patients could benefit from radiologists' experience in the use of contrast agents for prostate scanning to improve lesion detection, characterization and targeted biopsies. With the growing awareness of prostate cancer and the tendency towards earlier detection, more patients will probably be referred for MRI of the prostate, in particular patients with repeatedly negative biopsies and increased PSA.

Radiologists must know what can be expected from MR (i.e. detection of peripheral zone lesions), how to perform and how to use intravenous contrast to differentiate between benign and malignant focal lesions in the peripheral zone (i.e. dynamic contrastenhanced MR). Perhaps in the near future, MR may be used for detection and characterization of cancer in the central gland. MR prostate imaging is the greatest challenge for radiologists. Radiologists should be aware of the proper indications and patient selection for (endorectal) MR imaging for T-and N-staging. A-089 C. New developments J.O. Barentsz; Nijmegen/NL This course will present new developments in MR in prostate cancer and its subsequent clinical role. The use of USPIO in detecting lymph node metastases in small (5 mm) nodes will be discussed. The role of endorectal coil MRI, dynamic MRI and MR-spectroscopy will be illustrated. Fusion of CT with functional MR images, allowing for more precise radiotherapy will be shown. Finally advantages of 3 T endorectal coil MRI with high spatial, spectral and dynamic resolution are presented.
Moderator: J. Damilakis; Iraklion/GR
Radiation protection (Introduction) J. Damilakis; Iraklion/GR

The development of multislice computed tomography (MSCT) systems permits rapid scans, ease of use and improved image quality. However, dose incurred with CT studies accounts for a significant proportion of medically induced diagnostic exposure. It is important to optimize CT examinations and develop tools for patient dose reduction. Digital techniques may deliver lower doses to the patient compared to conventional techniques, providing that digital technology is used effectively. The correct use of the characteristic curve of digital detectors and the proper utilisation of processing capabilities of computers are prerequisites for optimisation of "digital" examinations. Due to the complexity of the interventional procedures, the screening time involved may be long. Thus, doses to patients and staff for interventional radiology may be high. Occupational doses can be reduced by reducing unnecessary patient dose, correct use of equipment and the application of radiation protection measures. Irradiation of unborn children do occur in clinical practice, either accidentally or because of urgency. These cases require estimation of dose and risk to the conceptus and proper management of the patient. Lack of knowledge may lead to unnecessary termination of pregnancies. Four speakers will cover the above topics discussing optimization strategies for MSCT examinations and application of new techniques for patient dose reduction such as mA modulation; the effective use of digital technology for minimization of patient dose; strategies for radiation protection of personnel exposed during interventional procedures; issues relating to the exposure of the pregnant patient to diagnostic X-rays. Learning Objectives: 1. Learn new methods and techniques that offer the opportunity for reduction of patient dose from MSCT examinations without compromising image quality. 2. Understand how digital techniques such as digital radiography and digital fluoroscopy can be used effectively for reduction of patient dose. 3. Explain the various methods that may be used to reduce the exposure of the staff during an interventional procedure. 4. Learn issues related to conceptus dose and risk in case of (a) intentional and (b) accidental exposure of a pregnant woman to diagnostic X-rays.
MSCT: Can radiation doses go down?

The discussion on patient dose in CT has heated up, since the introduction of multislice spiral CT (MSCT) has led to a significant increase in the frequency of CT applications with a concomitant increase in dose per capita. It is the goal of this presentation to review the situation for MSCT and to point out possibilities and concepts for dose reduction. In general, the situation with respect to dose is F F F F Frida rida rida rida riday y y y y

the same for single-as for multislice spiral CT. The problem of "overbeaming" which was reported in the literature for some scanners has been reduced meanwhile and becomes less important for detector arrays acquiring more slices. What has changed with MSCT is the fact that very often whole body scans are taken with the result that the effective doses related to single-organ examinations add up. There are a number of technical developments linked to spiral CT which allow reducing patient dose and, at the same time, guaranteeing constant or improved image quality. This includes tube current modulation and noise-reducing image reconstruction approaches. The necessary concept for the future is an automatic exposure control (AEC) for CT. These ongoing technical developments indicate that patient dose values can go down. This has to be assured by constant efforts of radiology, medical physics and the CT manufacturers.

How to use your digital technology effectively for dose minimization J.R.G. Persliden; Örebro/SE With digital technology we have new ways of optimising radiology. In film-screen radiology an overexposure results in a too dark film. This is not the case in digital radiology due to the wide dynamic range of the detectors and the possibility of adjusting the image on a computer. A high dose can in fact result in better image quality (less noise), however, better than is actually necessary and in contradiction to the ALARA principle (The dose should be kept As Low As Reasonably Achievable). A low-dose ("underexposed") image does not have to be retaken. Instead it can be adjusted by post-processing (window/level) and still be used for diagnosis (if the noise in the image isn't too high). It is of utmost importance that image quality is followed in the optimization process so the resulting images are not of inferior quality, depending on the type of examination and the referral question. The EU criteria of good image quality can be used here. Examples will be given of some ways to optimise digital fluoroscopy (upper and lower gastro-intestinal system and paediatrics) and coronary angiography. In digital radiography, examples will be given from urography (going from film-screen to image phosphor plate to flat panel detector) and pelvis. These methods can then be applied to various X-ray examinations.

Measures of dose reduction for the occupationally exposed personnel during interventional procedures E. Vano; Madrid/ES Occupational doses in interventional procedures guided by fluoroscopy are the highest doses registered among medical staff using X-rays. If protection tools and good operational measures are not used, and if several complex procedures are undertaken per day, radiation lesions may result after several years of work. Training in radiation protection (RP) and personal dosimetry are key issues. New interventional systems are sophisticated; however, a lack of RP knowledge and the detailed operation of these systems can sometimes prevent interventionalists from gaining their full advantage. The use of two personal dosimeters is recommended. Some practical advice to improve staff RP can be stated: to increase distance from the patient, use suspended screen and other personal shielding tools available, minimize the use of fluoroscopy and use low fluoroscopy modes, acquire only the necessary number of images per series and limit the number of series, consider the size of the patient and the position of the X-ray tube, collimate the X-ray beam to the area of interest, and a final general recommendation: be aware of the RP of your patient and you will also be improving your own occupational protection. But correlation between patient and staff radiological risks is not simple. Learning Objectives: 1. To realise that occupational radiation risk during interventional procedures can be quite high. 2. To understand why patient and staff doses are not always correlated. 3. To learn the importance of radiation protection training and personal dosimetry. 4. To become familiar with the measures to reduce occupational doses.

All you need to know about exposure of the pregnant patient to diagnostic X-rays J. Damilakis; Iraklion/GR Sometimes women are irradiated at the beginning of their pregnancy before they are aware of their condition. After these accidental exposures, radiological physicists are requested to estimate the dose and risk to the unborn child. The anticipation of dose and risk to the conceptus is also necessary for a woman who is known to be pregnant for whom a diagnostic X-ray examination is considered to be beneficial. Then, the conceptus dose should be estimated so that physicians can take decisions about performing or delaying a study or carrying out an alternative examination. Prenatal doses from examinations of areas remote from the unborn child are very low (< 1 mSv). In such cases, accurate estimation of dose to the conceptus is not necessary. When diagnostic X-ray examinations involving the abdomen or pelvis are carried out to pregnant patients, doses to the conceptus may be considerably higher than 1 mSv. Then, accurate estimation of conceptus dose is possible using methods developed for that purpose. Doses to the conceptus below 100 mSv should not be considered a reason for termination of pregnancy. Deterministic effects of in utero irradiation have a threshold of 100 mSv or higher. This dose is higher than that expected from the vast majority of diagnostic X-ray examinations. Stochastic effects (carcinogenic and hereditary effects) of radiation are possible but, when the conceptus dose is low, these risks are minimized. The conceptus risk for stochastic effects is assessed on the basis of dose using appropriate risk factors. Learning Objectives:

1. Learn how to manage and counsel a pregnant woman in case of (a) intentional and (b) accidental exposure. 2. Understand the factors that influence radiation dose to the conceptus. 3. Learn how to estimate the amount of radiation absorbed by the conceptus from diagnostic X-ray examinations. 4. Learn how to assess the risks to unborn child from diagnostic X-ray examinations utilizing appropriate risk factors. Images of different types of pleural and pulmonary calcifications accompanied by multiple-choice questions will be presented. During the workshop, the instructors will discuss the cases with the audience and will expand the teaching points with further images and references. At the end of the session attendees will receive a CD with the answers, additional images, and a list of references.

Learning Objectives: 1. The detection of calcium in a pleural or pulmonary lesion does not necessarily guarantee that the lesion is benign. 2. The presence of calcium in pulmonary and pleural lesions does not imply that such lesions are inactive. 3. Computed tomography is an essential complement to conventional radiography in the detection and analysis of pleural and pulmonary calcifications. CT is the imaging modality of choice in the assessment of patients with clinical or radiographic findings suggestive of aortic injury, bone fracture, or diaphragmatic tear following blunt chest trauma. The use of multislice CT allows for rapid examination of the thorax and adjacent anatomical regions, while providing thin section images. Optimal CT assessment requires optimal technique, including the use of iv contrast material and multiplanar and 3D reconstructed images, as well as an awareness of potential pitfalls. CT has greater sensitivity than radiography in the detection of pulmonary lacerations and pneumothoraces. Contrast-enhanced volume CT allows detection of both subtle and more obvious aortic tears. Tracheobronchial tears appear at CT and radiography with persistent pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum, subcutaneous emphysema, "fallen lung" sign, and malposition of endotracheal tube. The ruptured diaphragm, which tears more often on the left, appears asymmetric, irregular, or discontinuous, with herniation of bowel or viscera into the chest. CT provides visualization of thoracic spine fractures and assessment of suspected sternal fractures or sternoclavicular dislocation. The availability of new imaging modalities has altered the diagnostic approach to patients with abdominal and pelvic trauma. CT and ultrasound have largely replaced diagnostic peritoneal lavage. Ultrasound is used in most trauma centers as the initial imaging technique for the detection of hemoperitoneum and helps to determine the need for emergency laparotomy. CT allows for an accurate diagnosis of a wide range of traumatic abdominal and pelvic conditions. The speed of single-slice helical and multi-detector row CT (MDCT) permits a rapid CT examination of the seriously ill patient in the emergency room. In particular, the technology of MDCT permits multiple, sequential CT scans to be quickly obtained in the same patient, which is a great advance in the rapid assessment of the multiple injured patient. The evolving concepts in trauma care promoting non-operative management of liver and splenic injuries creates the need for follow-up cross-sectional imaging studies in these patients. CT and, less frequently, MR or ultrasound are used for this purpose. Learning Objectives:

1. To understand the role of imaging in patients with abdominal or pelvic trauma. 2. To discuss imaging strategies in trauma patients. 3. To describe imaging features that allow diagnosis and influence management of blunt abdominal and pelvic injuries. 4. To review cases illustrating the spectrum of abdominal and pelvic injuries.

A-098 C. Imaging of pelvic fractures N.H. Theumann; Lausanne/CH Pelvic trauma includes a great variety of very polymorphous lesions, differing from each other by their anatomical aspect, their context and therapeutic implication: In order to be efficient, the radiologist first has to know the diagnostic value of each radiological technique, in order to suggest the investigation strategy ap-propriate to any clinical situation. Then, he must be able to accurately describe fractures and to include them into a classification in agreement with the clinician. Pelvic fractures form a polymorphous group. In the isolated acetabular fractures, function is mainly at stake. Radiological assessment relies upon good-quality plain films completed by CT imaging in fine slices with multiplanar reconstruction. Letournel's classification remains the reference standard. Management consists mainly of re-establishing a joint congruence to prevent early coxarthrosis. Pelvic fractures often occur in violent trauma and are associated with visceral lesions, putting vital prognosis at stake. Radiological assessment must be included in multidisciplinary management and CT imaging stands for the most complete and least time-consuming device, allowing for investigation of both visceral and osseous lesions. In cases of hemodynamic shock, external fracture stabilization and embolization of pelvic bleeding are preponderant. Tile/Association for Osteosynthesis classification is the most used presently. It allows good description of mechanisms and lesions and more adapted management. Imaging studies may be performed in patients with suspected or definite arthritis to: * determine the presence of an arthritis * establish a diagnosis * determine the extent of disease * assess disease activity * evaluate progression * select patients for surgery * determine the type of surgical proceedure This talk will concentrate on the radiological differential diagnosis of an inflammatory arthritis. This is achieve most effectively by: * determining what tissue within a joint is primarily affected * identifying which joints are involved For a radiological analysis there are esentially three sites of involvement within a joint that can be differentiated: * the "bare" area, where synovium directly contacts bone * hyaline cartilage and the immediate subchondral bone * the enthesis Once the principal site of involvement has been determined a series of further questions need to be asked: A. Synovial disease. Symmetrical or asymmetrical soft tissue swelling. Erosionswell defined, ill defined, proliferative or non-proliferative. B. Cartilage disease. Loss of cartilage, thickening of cartilage or calcification of cartilage. Secondary bone changes. C. Entheseal disease. Non-erosive or erosive. Symmetrical or asymmetrical. Using this combination of binary analysis in conjuction with the distribution of joint involvement a specific diagnosis or short differential diagnosis of an arthritis can usually be made. The group of seronegative joint disorders encompasses the great group of seronegative spondylarthopaties (SpA) in addition to rheumatoid factor negative rheumatoid and juvenile arthritis, and other more rare disorders. Imaging of SpA, especially in the early stage of the disease, has improved during the last years by the use of MRI. The increased diagnostic sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing SpA are mainly due to a better diagnostic accuracy regarding involvement of the sacroiliac joint (SIJ). MRI gives the possibility of visualising both joint destruction and signs of disease activity, and can detect inflammatory SIJ disorder before it has resulted in osseous destruction visible at radiography and CT. Furthermore MRI can be of help in differentiating between the different forms of SpA including ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic, reactive, enteropathic, pustulotic and unclassifiable arthropathy, and gives the potential for monitoring disease during therapy. MRI may also be valuable with regard to the detection of early spinal lesions, in addition to evaluation of discovertebral or other lesions later in the disease. More recently it has been demonstrated that the suppression of disease activity will slow or even halt progression of bone damage although there was poor correlation between clinical response and radiological change in these studies. Such clinical and radiographic observations, where synovitis and bone damage are seemingly independent processes, have been supported by experimental models of RA where joint damage may be uncoupled from synovitis. However, all studies have used either indirect or insensitive measures of synovitis and bone damage or have imaged complex joints such as the wrist which makes interpretation of any imaging findings difficult. An understanding of the inter-relationship between synovitis and bony damage is critical for the optimal management of patients, especially in determining a logical approach for drug treatment, and provides the model for all disease where chronic inflammation is a prominant feature. This lecture focuses on the use of MRI and ultrasound in the assessment of rheumatoid disease with specific emphasis on the detection and potential impact of diagnosing subclinical synovitis, pre-radiographic erosion and complications. A list of relevant references will be provided. Learning Objectives: 1. The relationships between imaging abnormalities and the rheumatoid disease process. 2. The diagnostic and therapeutic impact of imaging in the rheumatoid patient. Colorectal diseases are so common that any radiologist should be familiar with occurrences like tumors, obstruction or inflammation. A renewed interest in this field was brought by the onset of high resolution ultrasound, multislice CT and MRI. These methods proved useful in the screening and/or detection of tumors (CT colonography), presurgical staging (MRI of rectal tumors), and evaluation of inflammatory disease activity (US, CT and MRI). CT, associated with PET, is another recent advance in the case of the cancer patient, and soon in the field of inflammatory disease. Not all results are yet validated and clinical strategy remains to be discussed, but it is very clear now that colorectal imaging is going to be complementary to endoscopy in many clinical situations, although technique and interpretation of these examinations may not be so simple, and the quality of images might heavily rely on the radiologist's skill. This is why a special focus session is dedicated to colorectal imaging. Practical tips, image interpretation, clinical strategy, as well as future developments will be presented during this session.

Possibilities and limits of ultrasound G. Schmutz; Caen/FR Sonography, an inexpensive, widely available and uniquely non invasive staging imaging modality, has the ability to detect and to characterize pathologic colonic processes, but it cannot compete with barium studies or colonoscopy in the analysis of mucosal repercussions of colonic diseases. Much like CT, sonography has the ability to evaluate the bowel wall itself as well as the adjacent mesentery and peritoneal fat. Sonographic findings in many colonic disorders are non specific and therefore multiple pathological processes may present with the same pattern. Nevertheless sonographic evaluation of the colon can be quite rewarding and it is important for sonographers to recognize the colonic origin of the sonographic findings in order to provide a definitive diagnosis and to appropriately guide further investigations.

Possibilities and limits of CT H. Fenlon; Dublin/IE Developments in multislice CT acquisition have greatly enhanced and facilitated cross-sectional imaging of the gastrointestinal tract. In particular, high resolution images of the colon that are free of respiratory and misregistration artefact can now be rapidly acquired. Soft copy viewing of these thin-section images directly from a workstation monitor facilitates study interpretation, dramatically reducing the need for complex 3D imaging and hard-copy images. In this lecture I will discuss the possibilities and limitations of CT in the evaluation of both benign and malignant colonic pathologies. Techniques discussed will include standard CT imaging of the colon with both IV and oral contrast, colon CT with rectal contrast, CT colonography, and minimal preparation CT. Challenges and limitations of these techniques including threshold polyp size, flat cancer detection, radiation dose and requirement for bowel preparation will be outlined. Logistical difficulties including access to CT scanners, coordination of "one-stop shop" evaluations with local endoscopy services, and cost will also be reviewed. The appropriate use of

Possibilities and limits of MR C. Catalano; Rome/IT Magnetic resonance imaging is still in most centers under-utilized in the assessment of abdominal diseases and even more in the evaluation of the gastro-intestinal tract. Nevertheless recent technical developments now allow routine 3D acquisition, at high resolution, of large anatomical tracts, avoiding respiratory artifacts. Magnetic resonance imaging can exploit, as compared to other modalities, its great intrinsic contrast which can provide excellent visualization of colon walls and relationship with surrounding structures. Image analysis is crucial also in MR imaging, in order to achieve all the neccessary information and avoid misinterpretation errors. In this session, I will go through the technical details, including the basic hardware requirements, the main sequences and modalities of acquisition, patient preparation and data set evaluation. I will also discuss the possibilities and limitations of MR imaging in the evaluation of benign and malignant diseases of the colon and rectum. Practical hints will be given especially to avoid common practical problems. Review of the literature and economic problems will also be reviewed. Finally, based on technical and clinical advantages and limitations, indications to MR imaging of the colon will be given. During the last few years cardiac MRI has become almost the modality of choice for myocardial viability assessment. Cardiac MRI showed a similar sensitivity and specificity even in comparison to the so called "gold standard" of viability assessment, F-18 FDG-PET (1), with the introduction of the easy to perform method of "delayed enhancement" 10 -20 minutes after the administration of Gd-DTPA intravenously (2) . Whereas myocardial perfusion analysis, both with qualitative (visual) and semiquantitative assessment, has still to prove its reliability for the primary diagnosis of coronary heart disease (3). The different methods of stress testing in MRI (dobutamine -adenosine) with wall motion and perfusion analysis to detect myocardial ischemia will be described as well as different methods of viability assessment. Furthermore, different approaches to analyse the achieved data and its pitfalls will be discussed. Finally the present indications and the value of the different methods in comparison to other modalities especially PET and SPECT will be argued. A-108 C. MDCT J. Bremerich; Basel/CH Positron emission tomography (PET) and single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) are well established for imaging of myocardial perfusion and viability, they are considered the gold standard. These modalities, however, are limited by 1) poor spatial resolution, 2) radiation exposure, 3) restricted availability of PET, and 4) attenuation artifacts in SPECT which can produce false positive interpretation.

Other techniques such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and multi detector computed tomography (MDCT) have been introduced for perfusion or viability assessment. Both modalities provide better spatial resolution and complimentary information on cardiac function and morphology. Perfusion imaging with dynamic contrast enhanced MRI is hampered by complex distribution kinetics of standard extracellular compounds with non-linear relation between signal enhancement and regional contrast media concentration. MDCT, on the other hand, has a linear relationship between radiation attenuation and iodine concentration, moreover a superb spatial resolution. Viability imaging late enhancement MRI has become a reliable tool in clinical routine and allows distinction of transmural from non-transmural infarction and thus can predict outcome after revascularisation therapy. The role of MDCT in viability imaging, however, has yet to be established. Contrast enhanced applications similar to MRI or a rest/stress test similar to echocardiography may be useful.

In conclusion, MRI and MDCT can provide perfusion and viability imaging with superior spatial resolution as compared to PET and SPECT. Today, MRI is accepted as a powerful and reliable tool, the future role of MDCT has yet to be established. In some patients, this technique may also be the final examination. The addition of colour and pulsed Doppler sonography has contributed to assessing tumour involvement of vascular structures such as the portal and mesenteric system. However, a sonographic diagnosis of suspected pancreatic disease depends on patient-related factors and is not always straightforward. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) eliminates the problem of overlying bowel gas and allows for focussed high-resolution imaging. This technique is well suited to detect vascular invasion and EUS-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy can further increase the diagnostic accuracy in pancreatic cancer. When compared to US the performance of computed tomography (CT) is less operator-and patient-dependent. The value of helical CT in the management of acute pancreatitis and pre-operative staging of pancreatic neoplasms is well established. Moreover, multislice helical CT using narrow collimation and thin slices, provides excellent spatial resolution and three-dimensional reconstructions showing all relevant anatomical information.

Due to the introduction of (ultra)-fast MR sequences and the development of new, tissue specific contrast agents, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may currently be as accurate as spiral CT for depicting inflammatory and neoplastic pancreatic disease. Moreover MRI has the advantage of allowing simultaneous investigation of the pancreatic duct, pancreatic parenchyma and peripancreatic vessels ('all-in-one'). In other words MRI can provide all information required to differentiate resectable from unresectable tumours. Chronic pancreatitis is a common pathology with an essentially clinical diagnosis. This disease, besides creating an increased risk of the onset of ductal adenocarcinoma, sometimes shares similar aspects at imaging. The problem of differential diagnosis between the various forms of chronic pancreatitis and tumors often arises in daily practice. The segmentary form of chronic pancreatitis, focal autoimmune pancreatitis, and the solid variant of cystic dystrophy of the duodenal wall (aka "groove pancreatitis"), can especially mimic a ductal adenocarcinoma. Recognition of these inflammatory forms, or at least suspicion of them and their subsequent classification by needle aspiration, radically modifies the therapeutic approach. It is even more difficult to recognize a ductal adenocarcinoma arising in chronic pancreatitis. Finally, the problem of the differential diagnosis between chronic obstructive pancreatitis and intraductal papillary mucinous tumor of the main duct often occurs. Learning Objectives: 1. To describe the pathological aspects of chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic tumors. 2. To present imaging findings useful for the differentiation of focal forms of chronic pancreatitis from ductal adenocarcinoma. 3. To supply the CT/MR criteria which allow for the differential diagnosis between chronic obstructive pancreatitis and IPMT of the main duct.

A-111 C. Uncommon pancreatic tumors T.K. Helmberger; Munich/DE Pancreatic tumors may arise from the duct cells, the acinar cells, and the endocrine cells. The "classic" ductal adenocarcioma of the pancreas accounts for about 80% of all pancreatic tumors, with important variants such as mucinous noncystic carcinomas (1 -3%), adenosquamous carcinomas (3 -4%), and undifferentiated (anaplastic) carcinomas (2 -7%) adding another 10% to the ductal tumors. These latter tumours together with endocrine tumors (2%), mucinous cystic tumors (2%), intraductal papillary-mucinous tumors (1%), serous cystadenomas (1%), acinar cell carcinomas (1%), solid-pseudopapillary tumors (1%), pancreatoblastoma (< 0.5%) and other rare entities represent the "uncommon" pancreatic tumors. Some of these uncommon tumors may mimic the clinical findings and appearance in imaging of ductal adenocarcinomas. Nevertheless, the knowledge of specific imaging features of the uncommon pancreatic tumors may help to differentiate them from the classic ductal carcinomas. This can especially be crucial because some of these tumors present a much better prognosis than the, in general, dismal prognosis of ductal adenocarcinomas of the pancreas, while others do not need therapy at all. Collapse is defined as a state in which lung tissue has undergone complete atelectasis. Evaluation of patients with radiographic suspicion of lobar collapse represents one of the most important daily challenges for the radiologist. A wide range of abnormalities has been described characterizing the appearance of lobar or segmental collapse as well as secondary changes. Conventional chest radiography remains the most commonly performed study although CT has proved to be an essential adjunct to routine radiography. Lobar collapse results from different mechanisms: Resorption or obstructive atelectasis, resulting from endobronchial obstruction; compression or passive atelectasis, which is collapse caused by extrinsic compression, such as from pleural fluid or air, or the presence of any space-occupying intrathoracic lesion resulting in extrinsic compression of adjacent parenchyma; cicatrization atelectasis, resulting from parenchymal fibrosis; and adhesive atelectasis, which is collapse resulting from loss of surfactant. The presentation highlights concepts and signs that are important in assessing the presence or absence of lobar collapse. The signs discussed and presented include opacity of the collapsed lobe, hilar vascular alterations, hilar bronchial alterations, compensatory overinflation, fissural alterations, juxtaphrenic peak and rounded atelectasis. Learning Objectives: 1. To describe the main anatomical landmarks for understanding the mechanisms of lobar collapse. 2. To review the most common radiographic signs of lobar and segmental collapse. 3. To emphasize the role of CT as a useful adjunct in the diagnosis of lobar collapse.

Diffuse opacities consist of seven radiographic patterns: Consolidation, groundglass, nodular, reticular, reticulonodular, honeycomb and cystic. Careful analysis of the radiographic pattern and its distribution taken in conjunction with ancillary radiographic and clinical features permit a limited differential diagnosis to be advanced. In patients with evidence of diffuse lung disease on the chest radiograph, HRCT is often required being both more sensitive and accurate. Acute and chronic disease should be considered separately. Acute causes of diffuse pulmonary opacities include: Pneumonia, pulmonary oedema, pulmonary haemorrhage, and drug reactions. The radiographic pattern, its distribution and associated features often enable the correct diagnosis to be suggested. For example, although consolidation is non-specific, a perihilar distribution with cardiomegaly and septal lines is typical of hydrostatic pulmonary oedema. Similarly, a linear or reticular pattern in a febrile patient is suggestive of viral or mycoplasma pneumonia. In chronic disease the radiographic pattern and its distribution also form the basis for diagnosis and associated radiographic features permit refinement of the differential diagnosis. For example reticulonodular opacities with a peripheral distribution are typical of usual interstitial pneumonia but if pleural plaques are present asbestosis is more likely. In contrast central, peribronchovascular, reticulonodular opacities, particularly in the presence of lymphadenopathy are typical of sarcoidosis.

Learning Objectives: 1. To describe a systematic approach to the evaluation of diffuse pulmonary opacities based on radiographic pattern. 2. To describe how radiographic pattern and distribution, ancillary radiographic features and clinical presentation limit the differential diagnosis.

A-114 C. Mediastinal abnormalities J. Cáceres; Barcelona/ES Nowadays, the study of the mediastinum is performed with cross-sectional imaging (CT or MRI), due to the lack of contrast among the different mediastinal structures in conventional radiography. Nevertheless, the PA and lateral chest radiograph may be very useful as the initial examination to detect mediastinal abnormalities and to suggest the next procedure to perform. The study of the mediastinum in conventional radiography starts with a thorough knowledge of the mediastinal radiographic anatomy and most common variants. Differentiation of pulmonary from mediastinal masses is easily made by knowing basic semiology (pregnancy sign). To facilitate the differential diagnosis among different pathologies it is convenient to divide the mediastinum into different areas (thoracic outlet, anterior middle and posterior, including supra and infravascular compartments). The presence of calcium in a mediastinal mass and its appearance (curvilinear, milk of calcium) may further contribute to narrow the differential diagnosis. Learning Objectives:
body_text.section: To appreciate the complementary role of CT in diagnosis.

body_text.text: 1. To review the anatomy of the mediastinum in the conventional chest radiograph. 2. To describe the signs that allow recognition of mediastinal pathology in conventional radiology of the chest. 3. To present mediastinal processes identifiable in the chest radiograph and signs that permit one to narrow the differential diagnosis. A-116 B. Cerebral aneurysms: Imaging and therapeutic options C. Cognard; Toulouse/FR Cerebral aneurysms are considered to be one of the major causes of subarachnoidal or intracerebral hemorrhage. Aneurysm rupture is one of the more common and unfortunate presentations of cerebral aneurysms. Unruptured cerebral aneurysms may be discovered when they cause neurological symptoms which depend on the location and size of the aneurysm. The diagnosis of a cerebral aneurysm is usually confirmed with an angiogram. Recent advances in CT and MRI scanning allow these techniques to also help diagnose aneurysms, but an angiogram or recently introduced 3-D angiogram usually provides the most detail of an aneurysm's size and location. For unruptured aneurysms, the goal of treatment is to prevent aneurysm rupture or growth. For ruptured aneurysms, the goal of treatment is to prevent further bleeding ("rebleeding"). Endovascular treatments for cerebral aneurysms have developed in recent years and can provide partial or complete treatment of many aneurysms. At present, they are regarded as an alternative to surgical clipping. The most commonly used embolic materials are detachable metallic coils deployed inside the sac of the aneurysm. In difficult cases such as wide necked or giant aneurysms, the balloon-assisted technique ("remodelling") or intracranial stent placement at the level of the neck are used. The recent experiences with liquid embolic agent -ONYX show its high efficacy and mark fast development of interventional neuroradiology. -MR for brain parenchyma, DSA to assert complete cure. Treatment: Embolization plays an increasing part in intracranial AVM treatment. Nowadays, it is extremely difficult to determine what the best therapeutic choice is in each patient. The therapeutic decision making depends on a very wide spectrum of clinical presentation, anatomical and morphological (angioarchitecture) considerations, but also on local technical equipment and operators' (neurosurgeons/neuroradiologist) skill and will. The goal of this lecture is to overview the up to date trends in brain AVMs therapeutic strategy. The following issues will be discussed:

body_text.text: In this lecture we'll describe the fundamental components of a flat panel X-ray and its operation and highlight the similarities and differences between the various detector configurations. We will also identify the characteristics of the detectors, compared to the screenfilm modality, in terms of modulation transfer function (MTF), detective quantum efficiency (DQE) and dynamic range. The implication of this technology on radiology workflow and radiographer's "way to work" will also be considered. The clinical presentation of renovascular disease can range from no hypertension to severe hypertension with progressive loss of renal function. A renal artery stenosis can be found independent of the clinical presentation. However, the majority of patients with hypertension do not have any renovascular disease. Only 3% -5% of patients with hypertension have renovascular disease. The relation between a stenosis of the renal artery, the severity of the stenosis and hypertension remains unclear. There are no diagnostic tests to identify a significant renal artery stenosis. Following this, the outcome after treatment of a renal artery stenosis in a hypertensive patient is still unpredictable. Although in a subgroup of patients with fibromuscular dysplasia the outcome is more favorable and durable. The pros and cons of treating, by drugs or by intervention, renal artery stenosis in hypertension will be discussed in this workshop. Early identification of renal artery stenosis might play an important role, in order to treat the lesion before irreversible renal damage, with subsequent sequela, has occurred. In this workshop the imaging modalities, the current literature on imaging of renovascular hypertension, the different interventional techniques, materials and future perspectives will be discussed. Peregrin; Prague/CZ It is believed, that about 10 -20% of dialysed patients aged older than 50 years lost kidney function due to ischemic nephropathy. Chronic hypoperfusion caused by renal artery stenosis (RAS) is usually accompanied by renal atrophy. This occurs even though normal kidneys remain viable with blood flows and pressures below those required for glomerular filtration, because less than 10% of oxygen delivery is required for kidney tissue metabolism. Even total occlusion of the renal artery does not always indicate irreversible parenchymal damage because the viability of the kidney can be maintained through collaterals. Chronic renal ischemia:

The use of self-expanding metallic stents (SEMS) in the palliation of dysphagia in patients with inoperable carcinoma of the oesophagus is well established. Almost half of patients benefit from palliative therapy rather than definitive surgery due to late presentation and advanced disease. Dysphagia is usually the first symptom experienced and without surgery it increases relentlessly. The main indication for placement of these stents is for alleviation of dysphagia. SEMS have been shown to be superior to radiotherapy, laser therapy and plastic endoprostheses in the palliation of dysphagia. The choice of available metallic stents is now large. Covered stents are superior at resisting tumour ingrowth than uncovered types but at the price of increased rates of migration. This complication is particularly frequent when the stents are used for the treatment of malignant strictures in the lower third of the oesophagus. Several advances in stent designs have been made including the availability of antireflux stents, coated stents and potentially retrievable stents. In our institution all oesophageal stents are placed in the radiology department under sedation and fluoroscopic control. The technique of stent insertion will also be illustrated and potential complications will be discussed. Whether or not a gastropexy is performed is slightly controversial, as many operators do not perform gastropexy. Newer developments include per oral placement of PEG tubes, which are more robust and have longer indwell times. De novo placement of button gastrostomy catheters have also been proposed. Button gastrostomies are low profile and do not clog but the balloon retention means that they do become dislodged. However, they can be easily replaced at the bedside. Gastrojejunal catheters are placed in patients with a history of hiatus hernia, aspiration or gastroparesis. The pylorus is cannulated with an angiographic catheter and a super-stiff guidewire is manipulated into the proximal jejunum. A long gastrojejunal catheter is then placed for gastrojejunal feeding. The interventional radiologist is in a unique position to offer placement of a number of different gastrostomy devices. The device to be used can be selected based on caregiver or patient preference. In childhood, tumors and tumor-like lesions of the neck are rare and they tend to be benign. Most of the median anterior neck masses represent congenital lesions (thyroglossal duct cysts, branchial cysts, dermoid cysts, lymphangiomas, cystic hygromas). The most common blastomatous lesions in children are laryngeal papillomatosis and haemangiomas. Less common benign blastomas are neurogenic tumors and tumors arising from major and minor salivary glands in children. The most common malignant tumors in the head and neck region are lymphomas and rhabdomyosarcomas. Lymph node-tumors (enlargements) -reactive and infectious -represent in the young and adult population very common abnormalities and account for a significant amount of lateral cervical masses. However, most of the soft tissue neck masses in the adult over the age of 40 are metastatic nodal lesions. First imaging modalities should be ultrasound. In thyroid abnormalities, a scintigraphic analysis is essential. Learning Objectives:
body_text.section: To appreciate the complementary role of CT in diagnosis.
