3. Differential-diagnosis.

A-128 C. Ultrasound of female genital anomalies I. Gassner; Innsbruck/AT Congenital anomalies of the female genital tract result from Müllerian duct anomalies and/or abnormalities of the urogenital sinus or cloaca. Failure of fusion of the Müllerian ducts results in a wide variety of fusion abnormalities of the uterus, cervix, and vagina. Müllerian duct abnormalities may occur alone or in association with urogenital sinus or cloacal malformations. Persistence of the cloaca is believed to be caused by an abnormal development of the dorsal part of the cloaca and the urorectal septum. Urogenital sinus malformations occur after the cloaca has been organized into the urogenital sinus and the anus. Early and complete assessment of the patients, including radiological and biochemical examinations, is mandatory to provide an optimal basis for treatment that will have a great influence on the quality of the patient's later life. Due to the close embryologic relationship between the urinary and the genital tract, malformations involving both organ systems are very common. Understanding the development of the urogenital system is necessary to comprehend the full spectrum of congenital anomalies of the female genitalia. This course reviews the appearance of developmental anomalies of the female urinary and genital tract and points out common associated malformations to allow an early and complete sonographic assessment of affected infant. Ovarian cysts are frequently seen during prenatal and postnatal pelvic ultrasound and have, therefore, been included in this course, although they are not closely related etiologically to the above-mentioned malformations and organ systems. In less than three decades AIDS has become one of the most devastating illnesses in human history. The AIDS epidemic differs from most others in many ways, has challenged conventional medical thinking and has broadened the boundaries of knowledge of human biology and medicine. The patterns of disease and pathological changes seen in AIDS patients can be perplexing and challenging, particularly in the medical imaging department. Although astonishing progress has been achieved during recent years in the treatment of patients afflicted with AIDS, with the introduction of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART), the epidemic still continues to spread. AIDS patients are no longer confined to a few specialized AIDS hospitals, and are now seen in general hospitals and clinics everywhere.The value of imaging of AIDS is well established. This CC provides a comprehensive overview of our current knowledge about radiologic imaging features of the wide range of gastrointestinal, hepatic, splenic, biliary and retroperitoneal manifestations in the immuno-compromised patient and how the role of modern medical imaging techniques and diagnosis and treatment can be applied. The imaging aspects (conventional double contrast gastrointestinal studies, ultrasound, CT and MR) of the diseases of the luminal gastrointestinal tract, liver, spleen, biliary tract and retroperitoneum will be systematically discussed. Candidiasis, herpes, cytomegalovirus, cryptosporidiosis, histoplasmosis, isosporiasis, salmonellosis, unusual mycobacterial and viral infections account for the majority of non-neoplastic disorders. This CC is not only comprehensive, but also practical and easy to apply to daily clinical problem solving. In this educational lecture the range of manifestations of tuberculosis (TB) of the abdomen will be discussed, including involvement of the gastrointestinal tract, the peritoneum, mesentery, omentum, abdominal lymph nodes, solid abdominal organs, the genital system and the abdominal aorta. Abdominal TB is a diagnostic challenge, particularly when pulmonary TB is absent. It may mimic many other abdominal diseases, both clinically and radiologically. An early correct diagnosis, however, is important in order to ensure proper treatment and a favourable outcome. Modern imaging is a cornerstone in the early diagnosis of abdominal TB and may prevent unnecessary morbidity and mortality. Generally, computed tomography (CT) appears to be the imaging modality of choice in the detection and assessment of abdominal tuberculosis, other than gastrointestinal TB. Barium studies remain superior for demonstrating mucosal intestinal lesions. Ultrasound (US) may be used for follow-up to monitor therapy response. The role of MRI has to be further defined. Ileocaecal involvement, free or loculated high density ascites with thin-mobile septa, omental thickening, a thickened and enhancing peritoneum, a misty mesentery and low density adenopathies, and focal hepatosplenic lesions are suggestive imaging findings demonstrated by either gastrointestinal series, US, CT and MRI. The diagnosis of abdominal TB should be considered if suggestive imaging findings are found in patients with a high clinical index of suspicion. Taking into consideration all clinical problems, adrenal disorders can be differentiated into two major scenarios: A smaller group of patients with clinical and laboratory findings of an adrenal endocrinopathy, and a second, much larger group of patients, with an incidental finding of enlargement of the adrenal glands. The diagnostic approach in these two groups is totally different; in the first category imaging methods are used for localization of an adrenal pathology, while in the second group the lesion is found in the course of a routine imaging examination or a staging work-up for a malignant primary tumor. Particularly among the non-hyperfunctioning adrenal lesions there are some conditions with a very low incidence that may pose serious differential diagnostic problems: Myelolipomas, adrenal granulomatous infections, cystic lesions (lymphangioma, cystic parasitic infections, pseudocysts), paragangliomas or lymphomas of the adrenal glands. Imaging features of these different entities will be presented and a differential diagnostic approach based on clinical and morphologic appearance will be discussed. For solid masses, problems concern the identification of small tumors, the differentiation among anatomical variants, the differentiation between some benign and malignant tumors. The contribution of colour-power Doppler and contrast media in the solution of the diagnostic difficulties will be illustrated. Problematic renal masses can be seen also with CT and MRI. Indeterminate renal masses on CT are due to very small size, internal septae, blood and debris. In addition, the differential diagnosis between some benign tumors (atypical angiomyolipoma and oncocytoma) and malignant tumors is difficult. MRI has similar difficulties but provides a higher contrast resolution enabling better characterization of hemorrhagic fluid content. Furthermore, with the use of dynamic sequences and gadolinium, MRI can demonstrate minimal enhancement in poorly vascularized tumors. The role of imaging in cervical spine trauma will be discussed including the methods of screening the acutely injured patient, strengths and weaknesses of imaging methods, types of fracture and injury, and potential pitfalls in interpretation. The material will be presented in an interactive way with audience participation and self assessment. Water diffusion MRI allows tissue structure to be probed and imaged at a microscopic scale well beyond the usual "millimetric" resolution, providing unique clues to the fine architecture of neural tissues, and to changes associated with various physiological or pathological states. The leading clinical application of diffusion MRI has been in the study of acute brain ischaemia. With its unmatched sensitivity, diffusion MRI provides some patients with the opportunity to receive suitable treatment at a stage when brain tissue might still be salvageable. Moreover, because diffusion is anisotropic in brain white matter, reflecting its organization in bundles of myelinated axonal fibres running in parallel, diffusion tensor MRI (DTI) can be used to map out the orientation in space of the white matter tracks in the brain. Fibre tracking, combined with functional MRI, opens a new window on the important issue of brain connectivity. Diffusion MRI is also a promising tool for the study of brain maturation and development, as well as functional disorders implying white matter. This session provides a basic introduction to the key physical concepts underlying diffusion MRI, as well as DTI and fiber tracking issues. Potential applications in the neurosciences and associated clinical fields, including psychiatry, will be highlighted. Learning Objectives: 1. To gain understanding of the general principles for obtaining diffusion MR images of the brain. 2. To become familiar with the main advantages and limitations of diffusion tensor MRI (DTI) and fiber tracking. 3. To identify clinical conditions in which DTI may be useful.

Basic principles and technical solutions O. Dietrich; Munich/DE Self-diffusion of molecules, i.e. their microscopic stochastic motion due to their thermal energy, can be measured with magnetic resonance (MR) methods. An important application is diffusion-weighted MR imaging (DWI) in vivo, because the diffusion of water molecules depends on tissue microstructure that is difficult to access with other non-invasive diagnostic methods. The basic principle of DWI is to add diffusion-sensitizing gradient pulses to MR imaging pulse sequences; this strategy can be employed for several different types of pulse sequences. In certain complex environments, the mobility of water molecules depends on the spatial direction, i.e. the diffusion is anisotropic. For instance, in muscle fibers or cerebral white matter, the mobility of water molecules is reduced in directions perpendicular to the fiber orientation. Therefore, several quantities are required to describe the magnitude, the degree of anisotropy, and the main directions of diffusion. This information is summarized in the so-called diffusion tensor. The diffusion tensor can be measured by repeated diffusion measurements in different spatial directions. Several acquisition schemes with different numbers of diffusion directions have been suggested in order to optimize the accuracy of diffusion tensor imaging (DTI). Although it is possible to visualize the complete diffusion tensor information in each voxel, typically only certain aspects of the tensor are shown in different kind of parameter maps. The most common parameters visualized are the mean diffusivity, the fractional anisotropy, or the main diffusion direction. Learning Objectives:

1. To comprehend the physical background of molecular diffusion. 2. To learn the principle and different realizations of MR diffusion measurements. 3. To understand the meaning of the diffusion tensor and the different possibilities of its measurement and visualization.

Diffusion tensor fibre tracking of the brain in different age groups D.K. Jones; Bethesda, MD/US Introduction: Undoubtedly the hottest topic in the field of DT-MRI is that of fiber tracking or "tractography".The term "tractography" is used quite generally to describe a family of approaches for studying aspects of the trajectories of white matter pathways in vivo. In this presentation, we will review the two main classes of tractographic methods -"streamline" and "probabilistic" approaches and compare their relative strengths and weaknesses. Applications: To date, the technique of tractography has predominantly been used to reconstruct the trajectories of large well-defined white matter fasciculi although a limited number of cases have been reported in which the information obtained from tractography has been employed in neurosurgical planning and assessment and in some neuropsychiatric applications. These emerging applications will briefly be reviewed. Artefacts: One of the dangers of tractography is that it produces extremely visually-appealing pictures of tracts and consequently, it is tempting to treat each result as "gospel" -without any regard for potential artifacts. It is essential to realize that there are many sources of artifacts inherent in the technique and these will be discussed in depth. Tracking in different age groups: Finally, we will consider the implications of these artifacts for comparing tractography results in subjects of different ages, focusing in particular on the developing brain and what special problems might be presented in addition to those present in the adult brain. Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the basic tractography problem and become aware of the different approaches which have been used.

To become familiar with the types of results that are achievable with tractography. 3. To be aware of the applications (and potential future applications) of tractography. 4. To comprehend the limitations and potential sources of artifacts in fiber-tracking. 5. To be able to discuss the potential problems faced in comparing tracts in different age groups.

Diffusion tensor MRI in neurological and psychiatric diseases M. Bozzali; Milan/IT Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) represents a powerful quantitative technique able to assess microscopic structural tissue characteristics and abnormalities. Its application to cerebral-vascular diseases and acquired brain injury can give additional information of diagnostic, prognostic and therapeutic utility. CNS inflammatorydemyelinating diseases have found in DTI a new quantitative approach to assess the microscopic damage in both lesional and normal-appearing brain tissue, with potential applicability to future clinical trials. In neurodegenerative diseases, DTI and DTI-based-tractography might contribute to detect the different pathological substrates underlying a non-specific parenchyma loss. In brain tumours, DTItechniques may contribute to histological subtype characterization and assessing the involvement (infiltration, mass effect) of spared parenchyma in pre-operative planning. Similarly, macroscopically invisible areas of abnormal development might be detected in some epileptic syndromes. In psychiatric disorders (e.g. schizophrenia, major depression) DTI has been used to assess the integrity of white matter connections suggesting interesting patho-physiological insights and correlations with pharmacotherapy responsiveness. Finally, in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and HIV, preliminary DTI studies showed intriguing findings of potentially diagnostic, prognostic and monitoring value. Learning Objectives: 1. To comprehend the meaning of the main DTI applications to neurological and psychiatric disorders. 2. To overview some potential DTI applications to neurological clinical practice aiming to add diagnostic/prognostic information and to address the therapeutic approach. 3. To comprehend the potential advantages of using DTI as a more sensitive tool for monitoring clinical trials. 4. To comprehend the more speculative potential role of DTI in clarifying the patho-physiological mechanisms of several poorly understood neurological and psychiatric conditions. Whole body MRI permits an assessment of overall disease burden. PET imaging in oncology enables radiologists not only to diagnose but also to assess the course of the disease process. Multislice CT of pulmonary nodules permits a more sophisticated analysis of focal lesions. High resolution chest CT supersedes many previous less specific investigations. Learning Objectives:

1. Participants will be made aware of the effect of rapid technical progress on their practice. 2. The intervention of radiology not only in diagnosis but throughout the full course of the disease process will be stressed.

Pitfalls of HRCT diagnosis S.R. Desai; London/UK High resolution CT (HRCT) is rightly considered to be an important tool in the investigation of patients with suspected diffuse interstitial lung disease. Indeed, in some cases a diagnosis can be confidently established on the basis of HRCT features, and more invasive procedures such as surgical biopsy can be avoided. However, before this can occur, the radiologist needs to be mindful of the potential difficulties which may hamper the interpretation of HRCT signs. Deciding whether there is a real abnormality on HRCT is not always a straightforward exercise. This can be exemplified by the scenario in which the radiologist is judging whether or not there is ground-glass opacification in the lungs; the phase of respiration (e.g. a suboptimal inspiratory effort), exposure parameters (an inadequate mAs), and body habitus can significantly influence the density of lung parenchyma and lead to spurious reports of infiltrative lung disease. Movement artefacts can also lead to false positive diagnoses; the appearance of parallel linear opacities close to the heart and caused by cardiac motion may lead to an erroneous diagnosis of bronchiectasis. Because the technique is sensitive, subtle abnormalities are frequently seen and thus, a more important problem (particularly for the clinician), is judging when an abnormality reported on HRCT is clinically significant. The specific problems of HRCT diagnosis, highlighted above, will be discussed in the presentation.

A B C D E F G many CP children had no adverse events early in life and were not imaged. The former children were considered to have CP from perinatal events while the latter were considered to have prenatal cause for CP, concepts so well established that neuroimaging of the child with CP was of no interest. Imaging is said to be expensive and unable to provide useful information influencing the diagnosis or treatment of a child with CP. Neonatal neuroradiology has shown that certain patterns of brain damage depend on selective vulnerability of various parts of the brain during maturation of the brain. Hence, the morphology of brain injury strongly relates to the stage of brain development achieved when the insult causing brain injury occurs. In addition to timing, duration and severity of a hypoxic/ischaemic event close to term determines the location and extent of grey matter brain damage. Applying this knowledge to brain imaging of patients with CP allows the neuroradiologist to classify most patterns of end-stage brain damage.

Correlating imaging to clinical observations shows MRI to be superior to any clinical evaluation in showing brain damage and hence indicating the cause of CP. MRI should be an obligatory component of any modern work-up of a child with CP. Learning Objectives: 1. To understand that neuroimaging is far superior to any other method in identifying the cause or cerebral palsy. 2. To understand that end stage neuroradiology provides other useful and important information concerning the mechanism behind CP.
The Globe
Radiology on the web
Radiology on the web D. Caramella; Pisa/IT

The Internet provides access to a huge volume of radiological information that is directed toward both health care professionals and the public, and that might not be readily available through traditional sources.

Radiologists are aware that a wealth of diagnostic imaging information is accessible on the World Wide Web: this material has the potential to empower the public by improving their understanding of the diagnostic procedures as well as to enhance continuing medical education for professional users. However, there is growing concern that a substantial proportion of such information that is free from rigorous editorial control might be inaccurate, erroneous, misleading, and thereby causing potential danger.

One of the initiatives that implemented a formal anonymous peer-review process to assure the scientific and educational quality of radiological material published on the Internet is EURORAD, the on-line educational database of the European Association of Radiology (ISSN 1563-4086) that can be accessed free of charge at the address: www.eurorad.org. EURORAD promotes interactive learning supported by the consultation of multimodality digital images illustrating common as well as unusual pathological situations.

Presently, EURORAD contains a large variety of teaching files (written in English, French, and Spanish) encompassing all radiological subspecialties and aims to stimulate the professional use of the World Wide Web, by providing sound and up-to-date information that can assist radiological practice and education. EURORAD exploits the powerful features of the Internet by combining co-operative work, peer review, and universal access. E-mail for communication is part of the daily practice of any radiologist. Using this facility in a clinical context has great potential but some specific problems are involved.The course will focus on using this communication tool in a radiology practice, after reviewing the procedures for attaching documents, and will especially focus on the precautions needed to ensure patient confidentiality and to protect the radiologist from medico-legal litigation.

A. Acute chest pain: Diagnostic strategies L. Bonomo; Rome/IT Acute chest pain may arise from any structure in the thoracic cavity so that a wide spectrum of disorders may manifest with this symptom, including both cardiac and noncardiac disease. From 10 to 31% of patients presenting to the emergency department with chest pain have acute coronary ischemia (i.e., acute myocardial infarction or unstable angina).

On the other hand, noncardiac chest pain may demonstrate a variety of characteristics with radiation and migration. Causes of noncardiac chest pain include aortic diseases, pulmonary embolism, pulmonary hypertension, pericarditis, pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum, esophageal disease, and chest wall disorders. Chest pain has also been described in patients with sickle cell disease and acute chest syndrome. The evaluation of patients presenting with chest pain is challenging for the clinicians. Although clinical history, physical examination, and the presence of risk factors are important in establishing the etiology of symptoms, imaging modalities are frequently utilized to confirm or to refute a provisional diagnosis. In fact, radiologists are commonly involved in the diagnostic work-up of patients with chest pain, particularly when a cardiac disease has been ruled out. This lecture focuses on noncardiac chest pain with a particular emphasis on aortic diseases and pleuro-parenchymal causes of acute chest pain. Children are not simply small adults and bone mineral density (BMD) measurements in childhood and adolescence are an extremely complex issue. Since bone size, shape and volumetric density vary substantially with age T-scores are of no use in this population. In addition timing of growth and puberty may also be variable. It is extremely important, however, to diagnose osteoporosis and osteopenia in these patients at an early stage since these deficits will translate into permanent deficits in bone mass in the adult. The ideal densitometric technique should (1) provide a low radiation exposure, (2) assess true volumetric BMD, (3) provide information on fracture risk and (4) be based on normative data collected from a representative healthy population with various age ranges. Such a technique, however, does not exist so far. Currently dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) is most frequently used, since it is fast, has a low radiation exposure and the best-established pediatric reference data. However, area BMD is extremely dependent on bone size, which may be a big handicap in children with accelerated or delayed development. Quantitative CT (QCT) provides true volumetric density but has a higher radiation dose and there are few reference data. Indications for bone densitometry in children and adolescents include chronic disorders such as anorexia nervosa, endocrine disorders as well as systemic diseases such as cystic fibrosis, rheumatoid arthritis, osteogenesis imperfecta and neoplastic diseases. In addition normal children with fractures due to low impact trauma and patients with the rare idiopathic juvenile osteopenia warrant study. For several years the role of imaging was primarily to confirm the diagnosis and to exclude other causes of neurological deficit. With the introduction of thrombolytic therapy, management can be dramatically affected depending on whether the stroke is haemorrhagic or thrombotic in origin. This has resulted in increasing pressure on radiology departments to provide rapid imaging within the first 24 hours and there is now pressure to reduce this timescale further. Traditionally, non-contrast enhanced CT has been the accepted optimum imaging method because of its speed, accuracy, relative low cost and accessibility.

With the introduction of newer sequences, research evidence indicates that MR can detect reduction in blood flow within minutes of the ischemic event and the use of FLAIR images has improved the detection of lacuna and small infarcts. Whether this additional patho-physiological information justifies its use outside the research environment is debatable. The appropriate selection of an imaging modality should be influenced both by the availability and the sensitivity of the technique concerned.

The requirements of an imaging service by a clinician C. Jack; Liverpool/UK Stroke is a major health problem for Europe with a stroke rate of one million a year. In Eastern European countries such as Hungary, Poland and Bulgaria, the age-standardized stroke mortality rates are increasing. Organised hospital based or stroke units have been shown to reduce death and dependency. In acute ischaemic stroke, early treatment with aspirin results in approximately 1% more independent survivors. Thrombolytic therapy can potentially re-open an occluded artery and may reverse a stroke if given immediately. For some patients this will mean that those with a severe disabling stroke recover quickly and are able to be discharged home within days, with little or no disability.

There have now been 18 completed, randomized, controlled trials on thrombolysis in acute ischaemic stroke and the results have undergone a meta-analysis. Thrombolytic therapy significantly reduced the number of patients dead or dependent at 3 months from 58% to 53.3% despite a higher risk of haemorrhage. To deliver this promptly, one needs to be certain of onset of symptoms, have a measurable neurological deficit and 24 hour CT scanning with radiologists skilled at interpretation. A fast track protocol needs to be agreed between primary care and acute stroke units. If the patient agrees and the CT scan signs are favourable, a loading dose should be given within the CT scanner to minimize delay. Direct transfer to the acute stroke unit for close monitoring, including repeat CT scan at 24-48 hours is a minimum.

How to use CT in acute stroke H. Traupe; Giessen/DE Two to 6 hours after acute stroke, post ischemic cytotoxic and vasogenic edema occurs which leads to a density decrease in the affected region. Early infarct signs are: blurring of the basal ganglia, decreased attenuation of the insular cortex, blurring of the gray-white matter junction and disappearance of insular or cortical sulci by tissue swelling. In about 15% of strokes, density increase indicating hemorrhage can be observed. Identification of degree and volume of early density changes (early infarct signs or hemorrhage) helps to decide if thrombolytic therapy of the middle cerebral artery is feasible. The basic CT examination without contrast helps to identify or exclude diseases mimicking acute stroke. In mammography reporting a classification, based on risk assessment is the cornerstone of good patient care, as it improves the clarity of the findings and leads to optimal interdisciplinary communication. The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System TM (BI-RADS) has been developed and revised three times since 1992 by the American College of Radiology. It is not restricted to final assessment categories alone, but also attempts to unify morphologic descriptive features, follow-up, and outcome monitoring. It has now replaced the classification systems in all institutions with high quality breast imaging in the US. Utilization of the BI-RADS system in Europe is limited at present. This presentation will outline considerations needed in order to consider implementing the use of BI-RADS in the European community. There are distinct advantages: optimal inter-professional and inter-institutional communication, standardization of reporting, and ease of outcome monitoring. On the other side, sometimes fine-tuning, tailored to local conditions, is missing. Also interobserver variability can hamper good comparison. One can discuss some morphologic definitions as well as definitions with respect to outcome monitoring. They are undoubtedly well-suited for the American system of health care, but sometimes need some adaptations in situations or studies performed on other grounds.The system is the product of an excellent collaborative effort between members of various committees of the American College of Radiology, but should also be discussed on European level, before full acceptance can be achieved. Learning Objectives:
1. Discuss the need of correlation between mammography, ultrasound and pathology reports. 2. Discuss the benefits and limitations of BI-RADS. 3. Propose a method for breast imaging audit.

Mammographic screening is only effective if client identification, client invitation, mammography, screen reading and assessment are all carried out optimally. This requires that radiographers and radiologists involved in screening are adequately trained, have an ongoing professional development programme and carry out a sufficient volume of work to acquire and maintain expertise. Factors associated with optimal radiologist performance include total life time number of films read, annual volume of films read and access to regular feed back. Radiologists involved in screening should therefore read a minimum number of films per year, carry out screen reading and assessment and preferably also undertake symptomatic work. There is evidence from the UK screening programme that screening performance in small units is on average worse than performance in large units. This may be because larger units have individuals with higher volume work loads and have more fully integrated multidisciplinary teams. Quality assurance should be an integral part of any screening programme. For QA data to be meaningful individuals and units have to carry out a sufficient volume of work to allow adequate quality evaluation. Planning for screening should therefore involve the creation of large breast care teams who carry out both screening and symptomatic work and where the individuals within these teams devote sufficient time to breast work to develop and maintain expertise. The peritoneal cavity lies between the two layers of the peritoneum, namely the parietal, which covers the abdominal wall, and the visceral, which envelops hollow and solid viscera. Peritoneum is reflected over the abdominal viscera to form a series of folds -known as ligaments, mesenteries and omenta -that attach, suspend and interconnect them. These peritoneal reflections subdivide the peritoneal cavity into compartments, meanwhile providing continuity of anatomic sites. They may become routes for spread of intra-abdominal diseases -more commonly malignancies -but they may also act as boundaries for pathological processes, especially for infections and abscesses. Normal peritoneal folds are not directly visible on CT/ MRI, but they can be identified by their typical position and organ relationships, or by anatomic landmarks, namely their major constituent vessels. However, abnormal folds due to edema, inflammation, or neoplastic infiltration are directly seen on CT/MR images. Spread of infections is determined by peritoneal "watershed" areas and it is influenced by gravity, hydrostatic pressure gradients and bowel peristalsis. Neoplasms can disseminate by direct invasion, intraperitoneal seeding, lymphatic permeation and embolic hematogeneous spread. Direct invasion may be contiguous or non-contiguous along specific mesenteric reflections and ligaments to involve other intra-abdominal organs. Intraperitoneal seeding is influenced by dynamic circulation and pooling of intraperitoneal fluid and by the course of peritoneal reflections. Imaging, using tailored CT/MR examination protocols, is important in disclosing the primary site of the disease, in demonstrating patterns of disease extension, in differentiating pathologies with similar appearance and in planning surgical intervention. Learning Objectives: 1. Review the normal and pathologic anatomy and the imaging characteristics of peritoneal and mesenteric diseases. The retroperitoneal region is located between the posterior parietal peritoneum and the posterior abdominal wall. It contains the kidneys, the adrenal glands, the ureters, the duodenum, the ascending and the descending colon, the pancreas, the large blood vessels, lymph vessels and nodes, and nerves. Thanks to the fundamental work of Morton A. Meyers and other authors, the anatomy of the retroperitoneal region is now well understood and its subcompartments, delineated by fascial layers, have been identified. These subcompartments (spaces) determine pathways, along which pathological processes from retroperitoneal organs preferentially spread, However, pathological processes can transgress the boundaries of the retroperitoneal spaces, depending on their aggressiveness.
body_text.section: A-161 C. Screening planning A. Evans; Nottingham/UK

body_text.text: Learning Objectives: 1. To recapitulate the complex anatomy of the different retroperitoneal spaces and to understand the pathway of spread of retroperitoneal diseases. 2. To explore the relationships between the retroperitoneal and the peritoneal spaces and to study how pathological processes can extend from one to the other (for example, ureteral involvement in primarily intraperitoneal diseases, such as Crohn's disease, endometriosis, peritoneal carcinomatosis).
body_text.section: A-161 C. Screening planning A. Evans; Nottingham/UK

body_text.text: A-164 C. Lymphatics S.C. Efremidis; Ioannina/GR Metastasis to local lymph nodes via the lymphatic vessels is a common step in the spread of solid tumors. The exact mechanism underlying this type of spread is currently under intense investigation. The lymphatic route is composed of lymph nodes and afferent and efferent lymphatic vessels. Lymph nodes in the abdomen are particularly numerous and lie within the subperitoneal space, the space beneath the peritoneum, forming discrete groups. Terminal groups are the pre-aortic, the lateral-aortic and the retroaortic group. These groups have their own large area of visceral drainage through intermediary groups of nodes representing steps of the natural lymph flow from the regional nodes of the abdominal organs to the cisterna chyli. Lymph vessels in the peritoneal cavity also course in the subperitoneal space, including the subperitoneal space of the peritoneal reflections i.e. ligaments, mesenteries and omenta. These anatomical structures make-up and seal anatomic compartments in the abdomen providing a natural barrier to the spread of an inflammatory, neoplastic or hemorrhagic process. However, they also bridge and interconnect the same anatomic compartments, providing important natural pathways for spread of a neoplastic process once the regional nodes of an organ afflicted by a malignancy are involved. The role of CT for the detection of this spread is well established. Lymph node enlargement at specific anatomic locations, as well as the sequence of their involvement facilitates the diagnosis of lymphatic spread of disease. This is particularly evident in cases of nodal dissemination of common abdominal malignancies. Learning Objectives: 1. To comprehend the complex anatomy of the lymphatic drainage of the abdomen. 2. To understand the pathophysiology of metastases using the lymphatic route. One of the index cases was admitted to our institution and initial measures implemented then were adequate in preventing any transmission. However, a month later, a patient with an atypical presentation of SARS triggered an outbreak of the disease in our institution. Three of our staff from the Department of Diagnostic Radiology were infected. In addition, two hospital staff, three outpatients and a patient's relative visiting the department were also afflicted. Within a matter of days, the practice of radiology within the hospital changed significantly. The immediate measures implemented in response to the acute outbreak, lessons learnt and the long term changes that are planned within the department to combat infectious diseases will be discussed. The reaction of radiology staff to this new and deadly threat and how we came to terms with our fears to battle against this disease will also be recounted. The emergence of SARS is a timely wake up call for all radiology departments to review their infection control practices. Learning Objectives: 1. To discuss the acute measures implemented in a radiology department during an acute SARS outbreak. 2. To relate the impact of SARS on the staff of a radiology department. 3. To discuss the long term changes that radiology departments should consider to combat infectious diseases.
body_text.section: To illustrate anatomy and pathology using the multiplanar capabilities of CT and MRI expanded with modern image reconstruction techniques.

body_text.text: Anatomy Hospital (04/03/03), subsequently infected over 100 others (medical students, healthcare workers and patients).
The radiology department played a crucial role in the diagnosis and management of SARS. A huge burden was placed on resources:

-urgent imaging on increasing numbers of staff/ patients (instantly reported) -satellite CXR facility set up immediately for personnel protection -vigorous infection control -routine services continued -fatigue, anxiety, fear amongst staff and patients -SARS website set up, sharing radiological features and infection control measures. Despite the challenge, staff performed admirably and sick leave/absenteeism actually decreased. Most stayed away from home, to avoid transmitting disease to families, and chose hospital dormitories and nearby hotels. A strong camaraderie emerged as we were all responsible for each other's well-being.

-hospitals/ public places considered dangerous and avoided by most -retail, restaurant and tourist industries at a standstill -schools and universities were shut (teaching done over the Internet) Recovery:
-extra expenditure, worsening economy and unemployment surfaced -community felt more united and stronger after overcoming the epidemic.
European curriculum and visiting programme P. Schnyder; Lausanne/CH

The goal of the topic is to provide detailed information for radiologists in training, staff and chairmen of radiology departments in Europe, about the present works achieved in these two fields by the EAR in conjunction with the UEMS radiology sections. The postgraduate programme for training in radiology will be discussed and provide information about morphology and function of interventional radiology and/or minimal invasive therapy, year by year. Topics of basic sciences to be taught and recommended rotations during the five years of residency, will be considered. The requirements for training facilities in general radiology and the resulting visiting programme will be also reviewed. The EAR has developed a European training assessment program which goal is to improve the quality of training in radiology through the members states of the EAR. This is achieved by experts undertaking reviews of individual training programmes. The programme is voluntary and visits are organized on request. The goal of the European training assessment is to harmonize educational standards. Once operational, this programme should undertake 10 visits a year during 4 years. Learning Objectives: 1. To comprehend the EAR recommendations for postgraduate training in radiology. 2. To understand the goal of the EAR training assessment programme in Europe.

Nuclear medicine training A. Bischof Delaloye; Lausanne/CH One of the first efforts of the UEMS section of nuclear medicine to harmonise training throughout Europe was to establish the minimal training requirements in a syllabus. This document is regularly updated to take into account changes in practice of the specialty. In parallel, the European Fellowship in Nuclear Medicine was introduced and the first European Board exam, consisting in a written and an oral part, was held in 1996. More recently, the accreditation of training centres on a voluntary basis has been introduced. In 2003 ,the 46 first training centres were accredited by the UEMS Section and Board of Nuclear Medicine (UEMS/EBNM). In 2004, the questionnaire has been updated and made available on the website of the EANM. Only centres offering the full spectrum of the syllabus either in the own institution or in a certified cooperation with another institution can get accreditation. These questionnaires give a good picture of the present situation of training in nuclear medicine. Accreditation is a dynamic process (the certificates are valid for 5 years only) and allows to follow-up the development of the specialty in Europe. Learning Objectives:
To be familiar with the training in nuclear medicine.
Training in radiology subspecialty: An example with neuroradiology O. Flodmark; Stockholm/SE

The UEMS definition of a medical speciality reads: A specialty is a(n)........... area of medical specialization for which a structured postgraduate training programme exists. It is obvious from this definition that a training programme is intimately associated with the identity of a medical speciality. In its infancy, every new speciality has to go through a period of separation from a parent speciality; e.g. neurology from internal medicine and radiology from surgery. The reason for any separation is the expressed need for extensive special training also in related subjects outside the speciality. Full training in the parent speciality may encroach upon resources available for special training. The possibility of training fully in the parent speciality and still having time to do extra training within the limited area of interest, constitutes a true sub-speciality. Problems arise when so much extra training is required that it becomes ridiculous to ask for full training in the parent speciality as a base. This balance is the reason why sub-speciality training is an issue. Using neuroradiology as an example, the difficult training issues between neuroradiology, radiology and neurosciences are illustrated. Recent advances in brain imaging, particularly the brain in function, highlights the shortcoming in today's training of neuroradiologists. Optimal training of academic neuroradiologists, is vital for the future of neuroradiology and all of neuroscience. Their training must be more broadly based within neuroscience than is possible in the present system. It is also vital to attract neurologists, neurosurgeons and neurophysiologists to practice in academic departments of neuroradiology. Learning Objectives:
To understand the complex issues related to conflicting demands for basic training in radiology and specialised training in sub-speciality areas.

European diploma and self assessment I.W. McCall; Oswestry/UK Educationalists differ regarding the value of examinations despite being used in all developed countries. Some European countries have national radiological examinations, others local and some none, while the timing and standard of examinations also varies. In radiology, testing knowledge, whilst important, is of limited value and it is essential to also evaluate competence. It is argued that radiology trainees are mature with much previous examination experience and that competence should be judged by continuous peer appraisal. However varying standards may result, while not inspiring confidence of other centres and National regulatory bodies. Thus, a European trainee self-assessment programme is suggested to (1) support harmonisation of training (2) enable trainees to test their competence and knowledge, (3) simplify radiologists' movement within Europe (4) raise standards of care. It must test the individual's ability to manage cases and reach sensible diagnoses. It must use a uniform language, be computer and preferably internet based and inexpensive. Knowledge is tested by multiple choice format, the questions being sought widely and agreed by a small panel of examiners. Competence would be evaluated using short and more complex cases via an interactive computer program whereby the trainee reviews the initial examination, describes the findings, produces a differential diagnosis, indicates further investigations, reviews them and produces a final diagnosis. Problems include computer program development and pump-priming resources. Initially trainees will not pass or fail but as a European diploma, strict quality controls, an appeal mechanism and a legal framework will all be required. CT angiography has been established as a standard technique for minimally invasive imaging of the aorta and pulmonary arteries since the mid 1990s. Imaging of other vascular territories with single slice CTA is possible but technically challenging. The advent of multislice scanning has made CTA much easier for almost any vascular territory and has substantially increased scan coverage as well as spatial resolution. Spatial resolution is now good enough to see very small vessels like the central bronchial arteries or the arteries of the hand. This course will discuss the technical challenges of multislice CTA, including the choice of scanning parameters and the concepts behind contrast administration. Postprocessing techniques will be reviewed, with a special focus on simple techniques that allow for quick and problem-oriented solutions for image display and evaluation. CTA can be used for stroke imaging, pulmonary embolism, a vast variety of aortic diseases, renal artery stenosis and mesenteric artery abnormalities. The latter can be examined as part of a standard arterial phase scan of the abdomen. Portal phase images allow for evaluation of portal hypertension, vascular occlusion or tumor involvement. Newer developments include CTA of the peripheral arteries of the lower and upper extremities as well as full body CTA. Compared to MRA, CTA has regained lost territory with the introduction of multislice scanning, but CTA should be used with care in young individuals and patients with impaired renal function. Percutaneous nephrostomy (PCN) is a simple interventional procedure when it is performed on a dilated collecting system to relief a chronic hydronephrosis. When the collecting system is not dilated, failure may occur if the interventional radiologist is not aware of some technical points which will be shown and which permit to achieve a PCN in virtually 100% of cases on a non dilated collecting system. In patients with complex pelvicalcyeal stones, including staghorn calculi, stones within a diverticulum, access to the collecting system is governed by a series of technical rules which will be exposed to show how to render stone-free a patient harboring the most complex renal calculi. Percutaneous stone extraction of the upper third of the ureter is also governed, in difficult cases, by technical endourological recipes which will be explained to show how to clear the ureter of stones embedded within the ureteral mucosa. Concerning ureteral stenting, most of the problems encountered are due to tight stenoses which may seem to be impassable, owing to a total ureteral obstruction. In these cases, performing an ureteroneocystostomy or using the rendez-vous technique, with a combined antegrade and retrograde approach, permits passage in 100% of cases of these totally obstructed ureters. Technical aspects of this technique will be shown. The rendezvous technique can also very succefully be used to stent ureters in case of ureteral fistula into the retroperitoneum. Other endoureteral manipulations will be shown such as ureteral embolisation in case of intractable vesico-vaginal fistulae secondary to pelvic malignancies in female patients.

B. Thermal ablation of renal tumors P.R. Mueller; Boston, MA/US This lecture will be an updated summary of where radiofrequency ablation stands in 2004. A review of the procedure with an overview of technique, results, complications and follow-up will be given. While there have been several articles in the literature on RF ablation, there has been very little description of the process and technical difficulties of performing ablation on difficult lesions in the liver and kidney. What are the most difficult lesions to treat in the liver? What are expected results with treating primary tumors of the liver vs. metastasis disease? How difficult is follow-up? What are the problems with imaging interpretation? Similarly, in the kidney: What lesion is best suited to be treated in the kidney? What are major problems with RF of the kidney? Can you treat a metastasis? These points will be emphasized and summarized in the lecture. Acute abdominal pain is the most common condition necessitating surgical admission to a pediatric hospital. The vast majority of cases are due to either appendicitis or acute non-specific abdominal pain. However, there are many other conditions presenting with acute abdominal pain in childhood which can mimic appendicitis. Some of these conditions are rarely encountered in adult practice. Plain abdominal radiographs are still obtained initially on many children presenting with abdominal pain. In the absence of associated symptoms such as vomiting, however, ultrasonography is more likely to elucidate the underlying cause of pain than plain film radiography. While computed tomography is being used extensively in investigating adults with abdominal pain, its widespread use in children is to be avoided in the interest of radiation protection. Learning Objectives: 1. To review the various radiological investigations which are performed on children with abdominal pain, and to become familiar with the relative advantages and disadvantages of each one in the paediatric setting. 2. To review the concept of recurrent abdominal pain in childhood, including its clinical management. 3. To review the causes of acute abdominal pain in children, and to learn which of the imaging investigations is most appropriate to each condition. 4. To appreciate the role of ultrasound in investigating children with abdominal pain.

Appendicitis is the commonest acute surgical emergency of childhood, and occurs in about 2-4 per 1000 infants. It is usually seen in infants older than five years, but can occur at any age. Atypical clinical findings are seen in about 30% to 50% of children, especially in the younger ones, and often lead to a delayed diagnosis. Preoperative clinical assessment alone has yielded an accuracy ranging between 70% and 90%, but is associated with a normal appendectomy rate of about 13% to 25%. Pre-operative imaging using the graded compression ultrasound technique (US) and/or different helical computed tomography (CT) techniques has been able to reduce this rate to 3% to 7% without an increase in perforation rate. An extensive review of the literature revealed several papers examining the accuracy of different imaging modalities and strategies of acute appendicitis in children. The reported sensitivity of US varied between 87% and 95%, vs. 95% to 97% for helical CT, while the specificity ranged between 85% and 98% for US and 94% and 97% for helical CT. Only one truly randomised study was found, showing that compared to US alone, a combination of US and helical CT increased the sensitivity from 86% to 99%, while the specificity decreased from 95% to 89%. Learning Objectives: 1. Imaging should be performed in all children with suspected appendicitis. 2. Ultrasound should be the initial procedure with CT as complementary tool.

body_text.text: A-180 C. Management of intussusception E. Sorantin, F. Lindbichler; Graz/AT Intussusception represents the most common abdominal emergency in infancy.
body_text.section: A-179 B. Specific imaging strategies in appendicitis K. Rosendahl; Bergen/NO

body_text.text: The classical clinical triad, consisting of abdominal colic, "red jelly" stools and a palpable mass is only present in about 50% of cases; 20% of patients are symptom free at clinical presentation. Primary imaging modality of choice is ultrasound scanning, which enables the diagnosis or exclusion of an intussusception at a sensitivity of 98-100%, specificity of 88% and a negative predictive value of 100%. In emergency cases, additional plain films are necessary to detect potential intestinal perforation, to identify intestinal obstruction or other diseases mimicking the clinical presentation. Once the diagnosis of an intussusception is established, non surgical reduction (NSR) will be used. A surgical approach is chosen in patients with signs of perforation, shock or peritonitis. Depending on the choice of imaging technique, different contrast media are used for NSR. Barium suspension or air with fluoroscopic guidance, or saline only or mixed with water soluble contrast under sonographic guidance has to be used. Regardless of the used contrast medium, NSR is an effective technique, being successfully in more than 90%. The role of imaging is early diagnosis, evaluation of extent of infection with special regard to potential neural compromise, differential diagnosis, guidence of diagnostic biopsy, planning of eventual operative procedures and assessment of therapeutic response. Imaging modalities include skeletal scintigraphy, radiography, computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). In practice usually a combination of a sensitive and a specific method is utilised. The only imaging modality which combines high sensitivity with satisfactory specificity is MRI. This is the reason that MRI has become the first imaging modality in clinically suspect spinal infection. MRI is the method of choice for demonstration of direct extension of infection, especially of secondary epidural abscess or phlegmon and consecutive neural compression. Using MRI monitoring of therapeutical efficiency is possible.

body_text.text: This lecture will centre around the pathological basis of soft tissue and joint infections. The reaction of tissues and the resultant changes on each type of imaging will be discussed. Then individual organisms will be considered with respect to the different imaging signs that may result. The role of imaging in planning and guiding treatment will be presented. Learning Objectives:
body_text.section: A-183 C. Soft tissue infections D.J. Wilson; Oxford/UK

body_text.text: 1. To understand the pathological basis for soft tissue and join infections. There is considerably greater radiosensitivity of the organs and bone marrow in children, because of rapidly dividing cells. Any radiation dose, small or large, is expected to produce a response and a cumulative effect. Therefore, every effort should be made in the radiation protection area to keep the dose as low as reasonably achievable, trying to retrieve the best possible information when performing indicated, justified diagnostic tests. Minimizing radiation doses should be a concept applied in a chain of actions, starting from the choice of equipment of the radiology department. Pediatric-oriented protocols, especially with regard to CT, regular quality assurance tests and continuous training of staff involved are important parts of this chain. Radiation protection rules should be meticulously applied in neonates and children. Justification of requested examinations, vetting of referrals for complex examinations, standardization of techniques and procedures as well as optimization of protection measures are crucial components for ensuring minimization of radiation exposure when imaging children. Special considerations include shielding of gonads, thyroid and lens, appropriate collimation, PA projections in females and grid removal. In addition, short exposure times, immobilization or sedation, entertainment or distracting devices should be applied in order to eliminate patient motion. All departments can benefit from self-audits and re-evaluation of their procedures. Many women are exposed each year to diagnostic X-rays as part of their work. The International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP) has recommended that for occupational exposure of a pregnant worker, the protection provided for the conceptus should be similar to that provided for members of the public. This protection is achieved by the application of a limit of 2 mSv maximum abdominal surface dose during the declared pregnancy. This dose limit usually ensures that the dose to the conceptus will not exceed 1 mSv. Thus, dose limits for the unborn child are comparable with those for the general public. Once a pregnant worker declares her pregnancy, a program should be established to calculate and monitor conceptus dose and counsel the pregnant woman. First, the conceptus dose from X-ray examinations carried out prior to declaration should be determined. Then, maximum procedure-specific permissible monthly workloads for the pregnant worker should be derived. In some cases, change in working duties might be necessary. It is important that the pregnant worker receives radiation safety counselling and understands the risk to the conceptus from X-ray radiation received as a result of her occupational exposure. Learning Objectives: 1. To learn dose limits, regulations and recommendations concerning occupational exposure of pregnant women employed in diagnostic radiology. 2. To provide a methodology for establishing a program to calculate and monitor conceptus radiation dose as a result of the occupational exposure of the pregnant worker. 3. To learn the effects that radiation may have on the conceptus. 4. To understand the radiation protection measures that will ensure that the conceptus dose from the mother's occupation is kept as low as practicably possible.

body_text.text: The organs of the upper abdomen, the liver, pancreas, small bowel as well as adrenals, spleen etc. and related peritoneal and retroperitoneal structures are the main target of abdominal imaging by CT and MRI. The typical indications are benign and malignant focal diseases of these organs, but also acute and chronic inflammatory and infectious diseases. This includes the primary diagnosis, the staging and follow-up in malignant diseases, the assessment of the extent and complications in inflammation, and in trauma. In terms of widespread availability, "intimacy with the technique" and cost-effectiveness, CT is the working-horse for abdominal imaging while MRI is still considered mainly as problem solver in ambiguous cases in spite of its accepted superiority in tissue characterization. Knowledge of the anatomical entities and the various pathological changes of the organs and structures of the abdomen is mandatory to read CT and MRI studies accurately with an improved diagnostic benefit. CT and MRI will provide sufficient diagnostic information only if performed adequately customized to the clinical problem and in a technically optimized and correct way. Therefore, one must be aware of the technical potentials and limitations of CT and MRI technique and also of how to adjust this technique to the specific clinical needs. The following issues of impingement syndrome of the shoulder are addressed: stage I to III, osseous and soft tissue causes (e.g. thickened low lying coracoacromial ligament), traumatic "activation" of pain in otherwise silent impingement, chronic and acute tear in impingement, soft tissue calcifications, tendinous retraction and fatty atrophy of the supraspinatus muscle, differential diagnosis. Other pathologic conditions described will be subscapularis calcifying tendinitis, coracoid impingement, traumatology of the athlete, entrapment syndrome, neoplasm and inflammation. Furthermore changes after surgery and complications after surgery will be mentioned. Technical considerations about MR sequences will only shortly be discussed with emphasis on TSE and STIR imaging as well as direct and indirect arthrographic techniques with internal-external rotation. Learning Objectives: 1. Basic and advanced diagnostic signs in impingement syndrome and diseases other than instability. 2. How to recognize a low lying coracroacromial ligament. 3. Learn about rarer sports related traumatic changes.

body_text.text: B. Instability J. Hodler; Zürich/CH Instability of the glenohumeral joint is determined by several factors. Bone-related factors include glenoid dysplasia, fractures of the glenoid rim and Hill-Sachs lesions. Labral lesions and abnormalities of the articular cartilage contribute to instability. The joint capsule and the glenohumeral ligaments are relevant stabilizers, with the inferior glenohumeral ligament being the most important structure. The rotator cuff and the biceps tendon are additional stabilizers. They press the humeral head into the glenoid cavity and directly guide the humeral head. Standard radiographs may sufficiently demonstrate relavant bone abnormalities. For subtle bone lesions CT or CT arthrography are required. For demonstration of joint capsule, labrum and glenohumeral ligaments, CT arthrography and MR arthrography are both adequate. When additional soft tissue factors, such as rotator cuff lesions, are of interest, MR arthrography is probably superior to CT arthrography. Standard MR imaging may be employed in the presence of joint effusion but may not be as consistent in the diagnosis of instability-related morphological changes as MR arthrography or CT arthrography. Ultrasonography is useful for the demonstration of rotator cuff lesions but has otherwise limited capabilities in the assessment of instability. Learning Objectives:
1. To know the relevance of various anatomical factors in shoulder instability.

However, the arthro-MRI represents the shoulder in its static form and, therefore, the surgeon must interpret the images and compare them to the clinical and arthroscopic results in order to obtain a complete diagnostic picture. The aim of our study was that of evaluating the diagnostic possibilities, with a functional study of the articulation and virtual arthroscopy.
