Today, there are a great number of techniques described for the application of percutaneous nephrostomy. The types of guidance varies, with ultrasound as well as fluoroscopy and CT being used. Regarding material, there are a number of nephrostomy sets available. The common factor for most techniques, however, is that they involve many steps and numerous needles, guidewires, dilators and catheters.

Over the years I have tried to simplify the procedure for myself, and above all for the patient. My goal has been to minimize the steps of the procedure. Indications: Percutaneous nephrostomy is a predominantly therapeutic procedure to relieve obstruction of the upper urinary tract. However it also provides access for further interventional procedures i.e. percutaneous stone extraction, antegrade placement of stents and dilatation of ureteric strictures. Radiological anatomy of the ureter is demonstrated using a combination of multidetector CT techniques facilitating 3D reconstruction and retrograde ureteropyelography. Understanding the anatomy of the ureter is fundamental to an effective interventional uroradiology practice. Ureter pathologies reviewed include malignant obstruction, iatrogenic injury, uretero-ileal stenosis, benign strictures and stone disease. Essential equipment needed to deal with possible complications will be discussed. Techniques reviewed include the optimum approach, stent placement, flexible ureteroscopy and biopsy and stricture dilatation. Double-pigtail stent placement is an established technique for treatment of malignant and benign ureteric strictures and ureteric fistulae. The retrograde approach is often the first choice approach to the ureter and may be achieved using a flexible cystoscope with digital C-arm fluoroscopy or fluoroscopy alone. Complications are few and procedures may be performed on an outpatient basis under sedoanalgesia.

The percutaneous antegrade route should be used if the retrograde approach is unsuccessful or impossible. High technical success rates (> 96%) are reported in patients with malignant ureteric obstruction. Developments in imaging equipment, catheters, guidewires, stents and delivery systems have contributed to improved technical success rates. Regular stent replacement helps minimize complications relating to stent encrustation, occlusion and fracture. A stent registry or database is needed for accurate stent tracking to allow timely recall. For stent or foreign body removal both cystoscopic and fluoroscopy-guided methods are required. Thermoexpandable nickel-titanium alloy stents have theoretical advantages over double-pigtail models by allowing maintenance of ureteric peristalsis but they are prone to migration. The first part of this talk will be dedicated to basic and application-oriented questions of the technology and physics of cardiac CT imaging. A review of current CT technology will be given which is a prerequisite for high-quality phase-selective cardiac CT imaging which involves subsecond scanning with multi-row detector technology and dedicated reconstruction algorithms. An assessment of patient dose issues and hints to possibilities for dose reduction will also be given. The second part is dedicated to quality assurance (QA). The necessity for QA is generally accepted in clinical imaging, and it is in fact regulated by the legislator and other agencies to a high degree. The necessity for QA in cardiac imaging in particular is not yet established to the same degree. We will point out specific problems inherent to the task of cardiac imaging, and we will go into the necessity for standardization and calibration for the quantitative assessment of coronary calcium specifically. Concepts and phantoms for quality assurance have been Research has shown that asymptomatic individuals at risk of cardiovascular disease benefit from agressive risk factor modification or further testing. Estimating cardiovascular risk by risk factor assessment can only predict approximately half of all coronary heart disease events. Furthermore, many subjects identified by risk factor assessment as being high-risk will never experience a coronary event.

Thus, there is a clear need for improvement of strategies for the primary prevention of coronary heart disease. Non-invasive evaluation of the coronary plaque burden may add to cardiovascular risk prediction. The most direct non-invasive measure of coronary atherosclerosis to date is the assessment of coronary calcification. This strategy is based on the close histopathological correlation between coronary calcium deposits and the total amount of coronary atherosclerosis. The development of electronbeam tomography has enabled accurate detection and quantification of coronary calcium, while also newest generation mechanical CT scanners have this ability. A number of studies has shown that increasing amounts of coronary calcium are associated with an increased risk of coronary heart disease. Relative risks for coronary events in asymptomatic subjects ranged from 2.3 to 22.2, depending on the population and the categorization of calcium scores. There is some evidence that calcium scoring can also have prognostic value in symptomatic subjects. Assessment of coronary calcification provides a non-invasive method to identify asymptomatic people at high risk of coronary events. The independent and additional prognostic value of calcium scoring in combination with risk factor assessment is under investigation. Learning Objectives: 1. To comprehend the magnitude of the current cardiovascular disease problem, and the strengths and shortcomings of the current cardiovascular risk assessment. The predictive value of 16-MDCT angiography to detect patients with no, single, or multivessel disease is 100%, 75%, and 74%, respectively. Overall predictive value is 78%. Development of postprocessing techniques will enable the automated anatomic selection of the coronaries out of a 3D data set, while further hardware developments are focussing on non-invasive 4D coronary imaging. Early comparative results between 16-MDCT and CAG show that 16-MDCT displays significantly more soft plaque coronary vessel wall abnormalities together with the visualization of coronary calcification. In MR imaging a complete new approach is developed with the use of contrast agents such as gadofluorine to directly enhance and image atherosclerotic plaques which enables improved soft plaque detection of even non stenotic lesions.

In time it will be proven that CAG significantly underestimates coronary pathology, although its flow information is unsurpassed. Non-invasive imaging of the coronary arteries is developing into a reliable standardized imaging modality. This will have a considerable impact on the management of the symptomatic cardiac patient in cardiology, but even more on the management of the asymptomatic population. Coronary and cardiac radiology are in the middle of these developments, because coronary calcification has been proven to be the strongest independent risk factor for coronary heart disease.

Therefore non-invasive strategies have to be developed for the management of high-risk groups for CHD. Preparation of the bowel: Small bowel and colon cleansing is essential before any intestinal examination. Administration of the endoluminal contrast medium: The trans-gastric catheter is mandatory to obtain adequate bowel distension. Nasal insertion of the catherter is much better tolerated than oral introduction. Infusion of the intraluminal c.m.: The endoluminal c.m. is infused at a constant 60-100 cc/min rate. The quantity to distend the small intestine properly is 1700-2300 cc (Rollandi 1995 , 1996 , 1999 , Schober 1996 . Endoluminal contrast medium: We prefer a "negative" contrast medium. CT Technique: The drug-induced hypotonicity reduces intestinal peristalsis and loop segmentation. One of the easiest false positives is to mistake peristaltic segmentation with an organic stenosis. The i.v. c.m. is injected after a portal phase delay. The volume must be acquired with 7 mm slice thickness, a pitch of 2, and at 3 mm reconstruction. Reduction in thickness or pitch improves the images quality. The new multislice detector bars allow better performances in terms of global scan time and scan thickness. Post-processing: The images from a volumetric scan allow high-quality multi-planar reconstructions. Dosimetry: Accurate measurements demonstrate that a greater part of the X-ray dose is due to fluoroscopy during catheter positioning. This dose is variable, depending on the operator but is similar in all techniques that are enteroclysisbased. The dose due to image acquisition is greater in conventional examinations than CT; fluoroscopy is present only in the acquisition phase of a conventional study. Firstly, the lack of radiation exposure is a fundamental point in favor of MRI, especially for studying young patients if one considers that CD lasts for the whole of a patient's life, and for therapy follow-up, since this examination can be repeated in short intervals of time. Secondly, the multiplanarity of MRI is similarly important, with the coronal plane crucial in the evaluation of the small and large bowel. Recent studies have confirmed the value of MRI not only in detecting the typical cross-sectional findings of CD (concentric bowel wall thickening, wall enhancement, creeping fat, etc.) but also in localizing the lesions in the small and large bowel, in assessing disease extent and in detecting intestinal and extraintestinal complications (abscesses, fistulas, phlegmons, urinary or hepato-biliary complications). Finally, the high intrinsic contrast and the possibility to evaluate wall inflammation with different MR parameters have allowed the assessment of CD activity and the differentiation of fibro-stenosing from inflammatory lesions. Therefore, MRI may have a predictive value on the effects of conventional or new biological drugs. For all these reasons MRI is destined to play a significant role in the management and therapeutic planning of CD patients.
Imaging of 13 C molecules: A new functional diagnostic method in radiology (Introduction) P. Aspelin; Stockholm/SE

The discipline of radiology is constantly increasing in size. We have gone from morphology via function to molecular imaging. We have proceeded from a diagnostic speciality and have included intervention, therapeutics and follow-up. With molecular imaging we now image the basic mechanisms of disease. Radiologists can, together with biologists, image activities of the interior of a cell, the cell surface and the outside of cells. The potential in the post-genomic area is immense and imaging of the genome and the proteomics (the signal substances in the body) will lead to individualized diagnostic therapy. This will lead to better diagnosis and more exact biopsy interventions and therapy. It is therefore important for radiologists to understand some of the chemistry and physics of these developments. Already today, radiologists can perform molecular imaging with all modalities. CT (iodinated nanoparticles) and ultrasound (acoustic nanoparticles) can be used. The two most used modalities, however, are PET and MRI. The success of molecular imaging is heavily dependent on signal/noise ratio and resolution. Today, PET has a high signal to noise ratio and can detect molecules at a molar concentration of 10 -11 , but has a poor resolution. MRI has a high resolution, but can only detect a molecular concentration of 10 -3 mols. Now a new possibility with 13 C MRI imaging exists to detect much lower molar concentrations and still keep the high resolution. The symposium will describe and discuss the method of 13 C and some of the future diagnostic implications for the radiologist and the referring medical community. Learning Objectives: 1. To comprehend the evalution and possibilites of molecular imaging. 2. To understand a new way of producing molecular imaging by ways of 13 C imaging. 3. To understand the basic physical and chemical principles of 13 C imaging. 4. To learn the possible clinical implications of this new method.

How to increase the MRI signal a million times! Visualization of molecules, a new functional diagnostic imaging tool K. Golman; Malmö/SE What is 13 C? 13 C is a natural part (1.1%) of all the carbon atoms in our body and a part of all organic molecules such as amino acids and carbohydrates. How can we image 13 C? We need a standard MRI instrument that can listen to the radio frequency of 13 C. The 13 C "radio station" has a frequency of ¼ of that of the proton station. How do I get the substance to inject? The 13 C enriched substance can be stored like other pharmaceutical substances in a "ready to use kit". Before use, the substance must be put into a "polarizer" placed close to the magnet. Push a button and you will get "the ready to use" injection syringe. Imaging must take place within the first few minutes after injection. 13 C-imaging has the advantage of using endogenous substances for imaging. This opens a door to untraditional medical diagnosis. 13 C-imaging offers the possibility of imaging the pathway of such molecules after injection into the body. MRI has until now not been sensitive enough to generate relevant information about events at molecular levels. "Hyperpolarization techniques" can increase the MRI signal more than 10 000 times, making it realistic to image the position of the molecules. The lecture will describe and discuss the new methods of imaging and future diagnostic implications for the radiologist and referring medical community. Conclusion: Finally we can do "real molecular imaging".

Methods to improve MR imaging and spectroscopy A. Bifone; Verona/IT Magnetic resonance imaging with optically polarized 3 He and 129 Xe is a promising, novel tool for the investigation of lung structure and function. Hyperpolarization of other low-sensitivity nuclei would dramatically extend the range of applications of MRI and MRS in medicine and biology. Among the NMR-sensitive nuclei, 13 C is probably the one with the best potential. Due to its ubiquitous presence in biological and organic molecules, and its rich NMR spectrum, 13 C is the nucleus of choice for many in vitro NMR studies. However, its low isotopic abundance and low gyromagnetic ratio make it challenging to detect 13 C NMR signals in living organisms, and to image 13 C distribution with MRI. Optical methods used for 3 He and 129 Xe cannot be extended easily to 13 C-containing molecules, and a number of other routes have been explored. The principles and the relative merits of the various hyperpolarization methods are presented. The 13 C spin-lattice relaxation time (T 1 ) is a critical parameter for in vivo studies. The spin-lattice relaxation time must be long enough to enable hyperpolarization methods to be applied and MR experiments to be performed before the enhanced polarization relaxes back to its equilibrium value. Thus, the 13 C relaxation times determine the time-scale of the physiological process accessible to hyperpolarized 13 C MRI. The implications for clinical and pre-clinical studies are discussed. Learning Objectives:

1. The audience will become familiar with the various hyperpolarization methods currently applied to 13 C, particularly for in vivo imaging and spectroscopy. 2. The physical mechanisms will be explained, to provide a basis for a critical discussion on the merits and limitations of the different methods. 3. The impact of physical parameters, like the 13 C spin-lattice relaxation time, on the hyperpolarization process, and on the applications of hyperpolarized 13 C MRI in living organisms, will be discussed.
Finally -quantitative measurements of perfusion?

The word perfusion is derived from Latin and French ("to pour over or through"). From feeding arteries, blood and plasma perfuse through the capillary bed, a complicated 3-dimensional network of intercommunicating paths. Capillary diameters are comparable to the size of red blood cells, the flow is slow and "plug"like and the blood/tissue volume ratio is typically < 5%. The challenging task of perfusion assessment can be undertaken using MRI as well as with techniques using ionizing radiation (SPECT, PET, CT). In MRI, one commonly employs dynamic T2* monitoring of an exogenous tracer (a Gadolinium chelate), in combination with tracer-kinetic models. This technique (dynamic susceptibility-contrast MRI, DSC-MRI) gives information about blood flow, blood volume and mean transit time (MTT). Absolute quantification is, however, complicated by sensitivity to vascular structure and difficulties to accurately register the arterial input function (AIF). By use of a tracer acting as a direct signal source several of these problems can be avoided, and dynamic studies of the 13 C-passage through the capillary system (in combination with a modified bolus-tracking theory) gives possibilities for quantification of blood flow, blood volume and MTT. Furthermore, new methods where the hyperpolarized signal is repeatedly destroyed using RF pulses open possibilities to assess the blood flow by measuring only the amount of tracer that arrives at the tissue during a short time interval. This eliminates problems associated with deconvolution and AIF delay and dispersion. In this lecture, the promising aspects of hyperpolarized 13 C as a new perfusion tracer will be discussed. After 6 months, regression is registered in 100% of free fragments and migrated disks, in 85% of T2W hyperintense extrusions, in 68% of extrusions in general and in 51% of clinically acute herniations. Minimally invasive procedures such as CT or fluoroscopy-guided radiofrequency diskoplasty, O 2 -O 3 or corticosteroid intradiskal and periganglionic injection will be specially discussed. Differential diagnosis with other forms of back pain is also mandatory in order to discriminate further forms susceptible to interventional therapy, like facet syndromes treatable by peri-facet steroid injection, synovial cysts by evacuation and steroid injection and sacro-ileitis by intra-articular steroid injection. Interventional approach has also been successfully and widely proposed in case of osteoporotic (or tumoral) vertebral fractures and 70,000 vertebroplasty per year are estimated in USA. All the above underlines the changing class of radiologists, switched from the single diagnostic role to the complete clinical one by adding the therapeutic management of several spinal pathologic conditions. 1. Stimulate interest for ISRRT history. TIPS is an accepted and standard therapy for the treatment of complications of portal hypertension. Major indications are: acute variceal bleeding not controlled with endoscopy, recurrent bleeding refractory to treatment, refractory ascites and hepatic hydrothorax and Budd-Chiari syndrome. Major contraindications are right sided cardiac failure, tumours or cysts within the tract, chronic encephalopathy and poor liver function (Child-Pugh score > 12). TIPS efficacy in controlling acute bleeding is higher than 90% with a rebleeding rate at one month of 15%. TIPS is more effective than endoscopy as prophylaxis for variceal rebleeding, however, survival rates do not differ among both treatment modalities and the rate of encephalopathy is higher with TIPS. Refractory ascites can be solved in 6 months in 50 -90% of the patients. The major disadvantage of TIPS is the need for follow-up by means of portography and/or ultrasound studies in order to check its patency therefore avoiding the risk of a rebleed. New refinements in technique and devices have widened the scope of percutaneous diversions of the portal system with more durable shunts. Learning Objectives: 1. It was also the main reason for relatively poor cost-effectiveness of TIPS when compared with endoscopic or surgical treatment of symptomatic portal hypertension. The exact pathophysiological mechanism of the bile duct injuries and bile influence on intraluminal thrombus formation and TIPS stenosis development is not known. In vitro studies revealed that bile itself paradoxically inhibits smooth muscle cells activity, and is perhaps more important for excessive thrombus formation. Bile in higher concentrations may inhibit endothelialization process of the shunt lumen. Although chest radiography remains important in the evaluation of pediatric lung disease, high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) is being increasingly used to investigate a variety of disorders such as large and small airways disease and diffuse interstitial lung disease. HRCT of the chest is a technique capable of imaging the lung with excellent spatial resolution and with a precise anatomic detail and is both more sensitive in detecting abnormalities and more accurate for differentiating between different causes than the chest radiograph. In children, experience with HRCT is limited. As HRCT provides more information, with comparable radiation exposure, it could be an alternative for routine use, especially in chronic pediatric lung disorders. All these reasons explain the increasing use of this technique in investigating and evaluating many pediatric lung disorders. Advances in CT technology allow images of sufficient diagnostic quality to be obtained in children during gentle and quiet respiration. In most cases these can be performed without sedation. Careful planning of the CT examination and the use of a proper technique is extremely important in obtaining diagnostic exams with very little radiation to the patient.

Learning Objectives: 1. To become familiar with the preparation, management and training of a patient before and during a HRCT examination to obtain a good and diagnostic quality exam. 2. To discuss the recommended parameters and protocols for HRCT examinations. 3. To discuss the special techniques used in HRCT to improve the diagnostic accuracy. 4. To learn the main clinical indications for HRCT in children. A-222 C. HRCT in interstitial lung diseases C. Owens; London/UK Diffuse interstitial lung disease (DILD) represents a heterogenous group of disorders characterised by restrictive lung function and impaired gas exchange. In childhood, these diseases occur on a background of developing lungs and an immature evolving immune system, so clinical presentation and disease progression is modified by comparison to adult equivalents. Hence, DILD often differs in presentation, clinical features and progress compared with adult interstitial lung disease and therefore it is not scientific to extrapolate known patterns of disease from adults to children. Once the diagnosis is suspected, the radiologist's task is to confirm the presence and severity of interstitial lung disease and to uncover predisposing factors identifying the dominant pathology. It may sometimes be possible to make a definitive diagnosis without biopsy, but the majority of patients require histopathological correlation using open lung biopsy, video assisted thoracoscopic, (VATS) or high resolution computed tomography (HRCT) guided lung biopsy. In general, classification of DILD in childhood, includes disorders of known aetiology (aspiration pneumonitis, chronic infection, chronic hypersensivity pneumonitis, lipid storage diseases), unknown primary pulmonary disorders with lung involvement or systemic disorders with pulmonary involvement, and finally those diseases unique to childhood. Learning Objectives: 1. To define the anatomy of the pulmonary interstitium. In an adult, the combination of fever, flank pain, frequency and dysuria is typical of acute bacterial pyelonephritis. This can be confirmed by bacturia, pyuria and the presence of leukocytosis within the blood. Patients with uncomplicated pyelonephritis who respond to treatment do not necessarily require radiological evaluation. In general imaging should be reserved to those patients in whom conventional treatment has failed or those who have recurrent or unusually severe symptoms. Occasionally patients may be referred for imaging at an early stage if the symptomatology or urinalysis is uncertain or if other diseases such as ureteric colic or renal infarction are suspected. In addition, in certain patients such as those with conditions that predispose to infection like diabetes mellitus or immunocompromised states, early imaging may be beneficial. Early imaging is also required if there is a clinical possibility of pyonephrosis which would require urgent drainage. In the paediatric population, imaging is important in the detection of structural abnormalities that predispose to infection/reinfection which may ultimately be amenable to surgical correction. This review will concentrate on the imaging of UTI in the adult population as the remit of paediatric imaging in urinary tract infection is outside the scope of this article. Learning Objectives: 1. To review the indications for imaging of patients with urinary tract infection. 2. To descibe the imaging findings of the various subtypes of urinary tract infection. 3. To describe the role of the interventional radiologist in patients with complicated urinary tract infections.

Pelvic infection affects approximately one million women yearly with rather serious consequences such as infertility, ectopic pregnancy and pelvic pain. Early diagnosis of pelvic infection leads to early and successful treatment with minimal, if any, complications. Imaging provides a significant assistance to the management of pelvic infection and appropriate selection and use of different imaging modalities and techniques is essential to the diagnostic management of pelvic infection. The purpose of this presentation is to discuss the approach as well as the use of different imaging modalities such as US, MRI, CT and hysterosalpingography in the management of pelvic infection. This presentation will give an overview of the key topics in PET methodology (tracer kinetics, acquisition parameters, image reconstruction and data analysis), and the physical and mathematical principles upon which they are based. Key determinants of the performance of a PET tomograph are the detector material and geometry. Currently, commercial scanners use four scintillator materials (NaI, BGO, LSO, GSO) and the relative merits of these materials will be compared to the latest detector materials, such as lanthanum halide. The geometry of the detector array is inherently linked to the detector material, with good timing and energy resolution being favourable for a large solid angle system. Such a system offers the possibility of fast whole body imaging and/or sensitive brain imaging for low uptake tracers. The various geometries will be compared, including the latest large area panel detector design. Small animal PET imaging in preclinical research is a rapidly expanding market and an increasing number of commercial vendors are producing these systems. Developments that are already being incorporated into these systems, such as avalanche photo-diode readout to improve resolution, may well be incorporated into clinical machines in the future, particularly those for high-resolution applications. New fast scintillators, such as lanthanum halide, may mean that time-of-flight PET is revisited to further improve the signal-to-noise ratio in the images. Although PET-CT scanners are already commercially available, there has been limited progress on the development of combined PET-MR systems. The problems and benefits of PET-MR systems will be discussed. Since then about 200 combined systems have been installed worldwide. Current commercially available PET/CT tomographs employ state-of-the art PET and multi-row CT technology, and buyers may choose from a range of mid-to high-tier combinations. An increasing number of publications demonstrate the benefits of PET/CT imaging and substantiate the hypothesis of its improved diagnostic accuracy and clinical value. By using multi-row CT complex CT contrast protocols can be followed in high-resolution mode as part of the combined PET/CT exam, thus rendering these exams "clinical" to the radiologists. CT information is also used for routine attenuation correction of the complementary emission data and standard PET transmission data are essentially no longer needed in the context of PET/CT. In addition, algorithms have been proposed to account for potential artifacts from CT contrast agents, truncated field-of-view, or artifacts from metal implants. A well-known challenge of combined PET/CT imaging is respiration-induced artifacts. These artifacts can, however, be limited considerably by careful patient preparation and the use of limited breath-hold techniques, and are further reduced by employing fast multi-row CT technology. Current hard-and software developments focus on increasing the throughput of PET/CT and offering alternative clinical acquisition protocols (e.g. emission only, low-dose CT in combination with PET for followup). Revised PET detector designs and a more integrated high-end combination of CT and PET technology may lead to a novel research tool for combined imaging of highly specific tracers. Positron emission tomography (PET) has gained a key role in oncologic imaging by providing accurate pretreatment staging, monitoring the response to therapy, and in the follow-up after treatment by precisely characterizing the function and metabolism of tumors, e.g. using the glucose analogue F-18-2-fluoro-2-deoxy-Dglucose (F-18-FDG).

body_text.text: There is now substantial evidence that the use of FDG-PET can improve the accuracy of lung cancer staging in a cost-effective manner due to the high sensitivity of the technique in detecting small-volume disease and to rule out tumors in enlarged, reactive lymph nodes and for metastatic staging. FDG-PET also provides high diagnostic accuracy (having substantial impact on clinical management) in: staging/restaging of high risk melanoma, esophageal cancer, high grade lymphoma and CUP; in detecting recurrences of lung, colorectal, breast, ovarian and oropharyngeal cancer; in the evaluation of residual masses after therapy of bulky lymphoma and testicular cancer and for early evaluation of therapy response; in the diagnosis of indeterminate SPN; for characterizing low grade brain gliomas (with radiolabeled aminoacids); and in differentiating brain tumor recurrence from radionecrosis. Increasingly, PET and CT or MRI scans are combined (anatometabolic image fusion), e.g., for molecular radiation treatment planning (MRTP) of radiotherapy. Integrated PET/CT may be able to pinpoint areas of subcentimeter disease before biopsy or excision is performed and soon might be routinely performed early in the diagnostic workup. In the future, immuno-PET and receptor-PET will improve dosimetry of radionuclide therapy and by using reporter genes, gene-PET will enable monitoring of gene therapy. Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the biochemical basis of PET imaging using metabolic tracers like FDG.

To learn about anatometabolic image fusion by using specific software and the added value of PET as a biochemical and functional imaging modality as compared to CT and MRI, which are more dedicated to anatomic details ("high sensitivity vs. high resolution"). 4. The choice of the correct bowel preparation will be discussed (PEG solution, phospho-soda or magnesium citrate and bisacodyl tablets) as well as methods to tag residual fluids, in order to improve polyp detection and to reduce the number of FP examinations. Initial results of fecal tagging, with complete avoidance of cathartic preparation, will be presented. Patient preparation prior to scanning consists of air insufflation, administration of an antiperistaltic drug, and i.v. injection of iodinated contrast medium, if required. Data acquisition protocols for CTC are in continuous evolution. The multiplicity of parameters of multidetector scanners allows different protocols to be optimized, ranging from high-resolution, to low-dose, to fast scanning techniques. Image analysis is performed on dedicated off-line workstations. Several studies have demonstrated the ability of CTC in the detection of colonic neoplastic lesions, not only large colonic carcinomas, but also polyps. If considering clinically significant polyps (> 10 mm), detection rate is rather high (> 90%). Today, the most widely accepted clinical indication for CTC study is incomplete or unsuccessful colonoscopy. The potential indication for the future is represented by colo-rectal cancer screening. Finally, different technical approaches for MR colonography will be presented ("bright" lumen vs "dark lumen" techniques) as well as imaging protocols and results from major series published in the literature. body_text.text: The lecture will provide the audience with a basic knowledge of: 1. Techniques for CT and MR colonography. The plain film anatomy of the solid organs within the abdomen and pelvis will be presented. The value and limitations of intra-abdominal fat lines will be discussed as well as a guide to the principles of organ identification. The numerous causes of intra-abdominal calcifications will be discussed. The more common pathological conditions of these solid organs which can be suggested from the plain film appearances will be presented. Atherosclerosis is a systemic disease of the vessel wall. Manifestations of atherosclerosis in the aorta, in the carotid, coronary and peripheral arteries may be associated with numerous complications, e.g. stroke, myocardial infarction, peripheral artery occlusive disease, aortic aneurysms and dissections. Plaque composition plays an important role for these complications. Assessment of atherosclerotic vessel wall changes may enhance our understanding of the natural history and pathophysiology of atherosclerosis. Moreover, it may enable for selection and monitoring. Intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) has a high spatial resolution in visualizing different layers of the vessel wall. However, IVUS is an invasive, high-cost procedure.

body_text.text: Recently, non-invasive plaque imaging using CT and MRI rendered promising results. The plaque composition (lipid core, fibrous, calcification) can be characterized by its density and signal intensities. Multislice CT and MRI hold great promise to achieve the spatial and temporal resolution required to assess vessel lumen and wall. In the coronary arteries, detection of "vulnerable plaques" is critical. They have a thin fibrous cap and a large lipid core. Acute coronary syndromes frequently result from rupture of such vulnerable plaques. Due to remodelling of the vessel wall, the thickening of the vessel wall is not associated with major stenosis. Disruption of vulnerable plaques may result in thrombus formation and distal embolization, as the lipid core is highly thrombogenic. Assessment and quantification of plaque burden aids in evaluating the cardiovascular risk. Molecular imaging with contrast agents targeted to specific cells, molecules or processes may also contribute to characterize atherosclerotic plaques.

body_text.text: Pathophysiology of plaques: Implications for diagnostic imaging G.C. Fernández; Vigo Pontevedra/ES Atherosclerosis and its complications represent the major cause of morbility and mortality in industrialized countries. For the radiologist is not only important to diagnose the disease when an acute event occurs, but also to adequate imaging methods for early detection of subclinical atherosclerotic plaques. In atherogenesis, the plaque begins by eccentric thickening of the intima due to injury in the endothelium. This endothelial dysfunction is followed by lipid accumulation in the intima (LDL-cholesterol) because of an imbalance between the mechanism of lipid accumulation and removal. Monocytes circulating in the lumen are adhered to the wall through selective adhesion molecules and engulf the excess of LDL. Theses monocytes became macrophages, charged with cholesterol (foam cells). An excess of this cells produce macroscopical changes called fatty streaks that can be already seen in the young or children. When this cleaning system is overhelmed, the macrophages die (apoptosis) and magma of cholesterol esters is accumulated in the intima forming a lipid core surrounded by a fibrous capsule. This plaque is called a vulnerable plaque because when the fibrous capsule is ruptured, the lipid core content is emptied into the lumen producing thrombosis. The imaging methods can be used to characterize plaque composition and detect vulnerable plaques in asymptomatic patients. Thus, early detection and treatment must be the new strategies in high-risk patients. The radiologist should not only report the stenosis percentage of the plaque, but also the suspicion of existence of a lipid core plaque implying the diagnosis of a vulnerable plaque. Learning Objectives: 1. To explain the pathophysiology of atherosclerotic plaque with radiological correlation. 2. To know the importance to detect vulnerable plaques in asymptomatic patients to permit optimal treatment and allow monitoring of the vascular response.

Multislice CT C.R. Becker; Munich/DE In asymptomatic patients with an intermediate risk for future cardiac events, nonenhanced low dose EBCT scans may be performed to detect coronary calcium as a surrogate marker of coronary atherosclerosis. Depending on the result, more or less invasive strategies for risk factor modification may be initiated and repeated scanning may control the efficacy of the therapy. However, the predictive value of coronary calcium for future cardiac events has not yet been determined in a large prospective cohort study. With contrast enhanced coronary MDCT, a more dedicated assessment of coronary atherosclerosis becomes possible. In patients with an acute coronary syndrome, MDCT may be able to demonstrate the location and extent of a coronary thrombus and may then be used to guide coronary interventions. In asymptomatic patients, coronary atheromas with a lipid core and fibrous cap may be detected, raising the suspicion of a vulnerable lesion that may rupture and may cause an acute coronary syndrome. In a comparative study such non-calcified lesions were detected significantly more often in patients suffering from an acute myocardial infarction than in patients with chronic stable angina. On the other side, calcified lesions were more often found in patients with stable than in unstable coronary artery disease. Furthermore, in heart specimen studies and in comparison with intra-vascular ultrasound the HU density in MDCT was significantly different in lipoid, fibrous and calcified lesions. However, the predictive value of the assessment of atherosclerotic lesions by MDCT angiography is currently unknown and requires further prospective cohort studies. Learning Objectives: 1. Learn about the assessment of calcified and non calcified coronary atherosclerotic lesions. 2. Understand current clinical value of coronary calcium screening. 3. Discuss the clinical potential of extended coronary atherosclerotic plaques detection.

Endovascular ultrasound H.I. Manninen; Kuopio/FI Endovascular or intravascular US imaging (IVUS) is performed with a catheter containing a miniaturised, mechanically or electronically driven US transducer at its tip. During imaging the catheter is slowly pulled back manually or by a constant speed with a motorised pull-back device. In addition to the raw data on axial plane, longitudinal and three-dimensional reconstructions are available. Normal arterial wall of elastic type arteries (e.g. common carotid and common iliac arteries) is homogeneous, while the muscular type arteries (e.g. internal carotid, coronary, and femoral arteries) exhibit a three-layered structure. The three basic types of lesions distinguished in IVUS are 1. loose, lipid rich plaques appearing with low echogenicity. 2. dense fibrous lesions with bright echo reflections, and 3. calcified lesions producing intensively bright reflections with acoustic shadowing. It is possible to discern a vulnerable plaque prone to rupture, responsible for acute coronary syndrome (a lipid laden plaque with a thin fibrous cap) by IVUS. IVUS facilitates definition of a possibly clinically important phenomenon -arterial remodelling, which can be either 1. positive, i.e. compensatory expansion of the arterial wall during the development of an atherosclerotic plaque, or 2. negative, i.e. arterial shrinkage. Serial measurement of the plaque area and/or volume (plaque burden) can be used as a primary efficacy parameter in pharmacological intervention trials on atherosclerosis.

Particular plaque configurations yield high risks for thrombosis independent of the degree of associated luminal narrowing. Several imaging techniques are available to assess atherosclerotic vessels. However, conventional luminographic techniques are ineffective in characterizing atherosclerotic plaque. Recognizing the need to shift emphasis from the vascular lumen to the arterial wall, high-resolution MRI has been increasingly considered for assessing the vascular system. High resolution MRI holds promise of non-invasively imaging vulnerable plaque and determining the different plaque components such as lipid core, fibrosis, calcification and thrombus. The assessment of plaque composition is regarded particularly important in determining the contributing factors related to plaque rupture. MR-based visualization of the vascular wall does, however, require high spatial resolution. Therefore, both external and intravascular surface coils have been used. Limited signal and depth penetration allows vessel wall imaging with external coils mainly for peripheral vessels, such as the carotid, femoral or popliteal arteries. Although intravascular coils can overcome this limitation providing sufficient spatial resolution to permit characterization of different plaque components, they do mandate an invasive approach. Alternatively, a functional strategy can be pursued. Based on the assumption that regions of active plaque formation harbor phagocytic cells, ultrasmall particles of iron oxides with a long intravascular half-life can be administered intravenously. Due to susceptibility effects associated with the accumulation of the iron particles in active plaque, rather small amounts of iron are sufficient to induce effects detectable by susceptibility-sensitive gradient echo MR images.

A 71 B C D E F G possibly using holography and automatic routine presentation of the multiplicity of information derived from present imaging technology. Sophisticated image fusion and processing may evolve into a new imaging quality. Progress in hardware and software has permitted introduction of molecular imaging. It maps differences in metabolism and biochemical composition of imaged brain or spinal cord. This has brought to reality in vivo pathological differential diagnoses of neoplasm, infectious, metabolic and ischaemic diseases. It also enables detecting activity of discrete parts of the nervous system, putting clinical speculations aside. A separate path of development is related to mapping of blood flow and volume in the tissue. On the horizon, there are new applications directly linking imaging with therapy. Tomo-therapy combines treatment planning, patient positioning and treatment delivery in one system. In vivo, real time MRI temperature mapping enables thermal transcutaneous ablation of brain tumours with focused ultrasound. Some of these fascinating new developments in neuroimaging will be presented during this session.

H1 MR spectroscopy of the brain in metabolic characterization of neurological diseases: State-of-the-art and perspectives J. Walecki; Warsaw/PL Although H1 MRS has been applied for many years there is still an ongoing debate whether this method can be the answer to accurate diagnosis of the stage and nature of the disease end. Based on published works and his 6 years experience in this field, the author would like to classify the criteria taken into consideration in four main groups of brain pathology: brain tumors, ischemic lesions, neuroinfections and degenerative diseases. In these cases, most frequently, the morphological examination remains insufficient. Whether the examination is correct or inaccurate depends on many factors, which contribute to the results, reproducibility and final diagnosis. To decrease the risk of potential errors the spectra must be performed on defined, identical level of well-localized VOI (an area of concern). It is evident from existing experience that many options can be applied to determine ratios. The author assessed relative ratios of selected metabolites (N-acetylaspartate/creatine, choline/creatine and myoinositol/creatine) and presented metabolic profiles typical for certain diseases (i.e. markers).

Highly specialized statistical analyses of spectral patterns as well as strictly defined procedures of MRS examination guarantee quality of MRS examination and consequently accuracy. It is quite possible that in diagnosis of major OUN disorders H1 MRS will soon become a decisive tool and the term "chemical biopsy" will cease to be an exaggeration. Learning Objectives: 1. To evaluate the usefulness of H1 MRS in differential diagnosis of brain diseases. 2. To present the most useful methodology, statistical analyses and "metabolic model" of normal and affected brain, in view of most frequent brain pathologies.

The role of fMRI and H1 MRS in diagnosis of brain tumors B. Góraj; Lódz/PL Role of diagnostic imaging methods is continuously evolving throughout many years of progress in radiology. As related to brain, it started with skull X-ray films, providing only indirect clues concerning existence and probable nature of lesions. With the advent of computerized imaging techniques such as CT and MRI, the whole approach to brain radiological diagnostics has been dramatically improved. Direct visualization of normal and pathological cerebral structures has been enabled. Clinical implementation of H1 MRS offered yet another diagnostic tool for brain tumors characterization. H1 MRS is a method of spectral analysis of selected tissue metabolites, particularly suitable for brain examination. It is able to yield data on metabolic contents of the examined tissue specimen with employment of single voxel or multivoxel techniques. Standard spectral patterns for many brain tumors have been already established. However, relying only on H1 MRS pattern is not advisable. Other "classical" imaging features should be taken into account in order to make final diagnosis. FMRI creates the possibility to acquire maps of the areas of brain activated when performing varied tasks. It therefore enables evaluation of the relationship be-tween brain pathological mass that is visualized with vital cortex centers in an individual patient; providing the possibility to assess their displacement or involvement, being a unique and reliable source of information of the actual functional burden tumor is causing to the brain. One of the greatest benefits fMRI has to offer is the option to plan neurosurgical procedures in a way to save cortex centers and to aim toward preserving patient neurological functions. Learning Objectives: 1. To present and discuss the H1 MR spectral pattern of the main brain tumor types. 2. To stress the diagnostic features allowing differentiation between varied brain tumors. 3. To point out the role of H1 MRS among the range of other factors applied for brain tumors diagnosis. 4. To demonstrate how fMRI methods can influence an approach to the neurosurgical treatment of brain tumors.

Evaluation of brain perfusion following carotid stenting T. Jargiello; Lublin/PL Stenosis of the internal carotid artery (ICA) a one of major cause of brain ischemia. During the last years, the number of patients diagnosed with ICA stenosis is growing mainly because of widely available duplex Doppler examinations. Endovascular carotid stenting (CAS) is now a fully accepted method of treatment as an alternative to vascular surgery. Its technical success rate reached almost 100%, when low-profile, especially dedicated endovascular equipment became available to perform these procedures. Introducing neuroprotection devices allowed to reduce embolic complications. Technical feasibility and overall low complication rates make CAS highly effective in ICA revascularization. Important issues remain qualification of patients for stenting considering the fact that not all ICA stenoses are to be treated. The main indication for CAS is hemodynamically significant ICA stenosis (> 70%) in patients presenting with neurological symptoms. Duplex Doppler examination is used to assess atherosclerotic plaque morphology and transcranial Doppler study can help in evaluation of circle of Willis hemodynamics. Brain perfusion techniques with multisliced CT brought new quality in assessing deficits in brain circulation caused by ICA stenosis. This method allows evaluation of cerebral blood flow (CBF), regional cerebral blood volume (CBV) and mean transit time (MTT). These parameters can be analyzed from the curve of inflow, peak and clearance phases of contrast enhancement. Comparison of the parameters obtained in both cerebral hemispheres gives good orientation on brain circulation deficit and enables treatment options to be decided. CT perfusion is very useful in monitoring the effects of endovascular revascularization when done before and after CAS. Acute intestinal obstruction is defined by the hindrance to progression of intestinal contents due to a mechanical obstacle. Abdominal plain films, ultrasound, contrast enema and CT are currently used in the evaluation of intestinal obstruction. The purpose of this lecture is to give the semiology, value and pitfalls of these modalities in answering the key questions in patients with suspected bowel obstruction: 1/how to differentiate obstruction from ileus?, 2/the level of the obstruction?, 3/the cause of the obstruction?, 4/are there bowel strangulation findings?, 5/is a medical or a surgical treatment recommended?, 6/in the case of a surgical treatment, what is the best approach: laparotomy or laparoscopy and what site of laparoscopy?. The role at these different steps of CT technical improvement will be underlined by illustrating the contribution of multiplanar reformatting and of 3D reconstructions. The impact of CT in the management of patients with suspected bowel obstruction will be analyzed, and finally a diagnostic strategy for imaging in such patients according to the results of clinical, laboratory and plain film evaluation will be suggested. MR imaging of the knee is the most frequently requested MR imaging study of the musculoskeletal system. Due to its multiplanar capabilities and excellent soft tissue resolution MR imaging has provided a new insight to the specific patterns of knee injuries produced by different mechanisms of injury. Normal and abnormal appearances of the ligamentous structures of the knee will be discussed, as well as ancillary findingsto the ligamentous injuries, such as meniscal tears and bone marrow contusions. Patterns of knee injuries will be identified in regard to different mechanisms of injury. In recent rediologic literature, it has been emphasized that the distribution of bone marrow contusions may be indicative of the forces that produced the injury. Awareness of the mechanism of injury results in higher detection rates of the abnormalities of the individual anatomic structures that have been involved in a knee injury.

B. Sports-related degenerative disease of joints C. Masciocchi; L'Aquila/IT Sports activities either professional or not are growing in importance into our day-life. This means a corresponding higher frequency of sport-related injuries, leading to muscles, tendons, ligaments and bone pathological involvement. Usually in these conditions an early and correct diagnosis is required to avoid subsequent joint instability and/or functional impairment. Many of the diagnostic techniques now available play an important role in sports-related diseases; however to choose the right diagnostic protocol it is always necessary to know how traumatic forces acted. The most frequently involved joints are those provided by the largest range of motion: shoulder, knee and ankle. As this field of diseases comprehend either acute and chronic traumas we will consider only the degenerative conditions caused by long-lasting microtraumas and overloads which may lead to stress fractures, synovial hyperplastic reactions, chondral and subchondral suffering, tendon's degeneration, impingement syndromes and entrapment neuropathies (typically involved structures narrowed into bony or ligament channels). Plain film is usually the first examination to perform as it allows the best detection of bony alterations as consequence of altered loads, being able to clearly depict osteophytes, bone sclerosis and osteochondral fragments. However in many cases plain film may result completely negative as in stress fractures, impingement syndromes and ligament derangements. In these cases Ultrasound, Magnetic Resonance and Computed Tomography allow a complete evaluation of all the remaining soft joint components. The clinical role in using contrast agents in ultrasound (USCA) diagnosis is not yet demonstrated. Significant indications seem to be present in echocardiography and in liver evaluation. In particular USCA seem to be very useful in the characterization of focal lesions of the liver parenchyma. The introduction of second generation USCA together with specific software applied to ultrasound equipment open up a new approach in this study modality. Second generation USCA are characterised by the greater persistence due to the bubble shell and the bubble content using specific gas instead of air of the first USCA generation. In breast diagnosis the use of USCA is limited to few experiences but seems to be very interesting in particular in the characterization of the nodular ultrasound images. This leads to an increased possibility to differentiate malignant from benign lesions.

To evaluate the clinical indications of USCA in breast diagnosis at the European Institute of Oncology a specific trial was conducted. Fifty patients with different ultrasound images were evaluated with a second generation USCA (SonoVue®-BR1) and specific software (CnTI®). Fifteen patients had suspicious images, 15 probably benign images (fibroadenoma), 10 suspicious recurrence and 10 with a cluster of microcalcifications. Breast MRI was also performed in this third group of patient. All USCA studies were performed with three different dosages (2.4; 4.8 and 7.2 ml). All cases subsequently underwent Mammotome or surgical biopsy. Quantitative and qualitative analysis of the uptake and wash-out curves is currently in its evaluation phase. Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance (MR) imaging is increasingly used as a complementary diagnostic modality in breast tumor imaging and seems to be the most important research area. Although the results of investigators to date have varied greatly, the sensitivity of breast gadopentetate dimeglumine-enhanced MR imaging for malignancy has consistently been reported to be excellent (88%-100%). The specificity of gadopentetate dimeglumine-enhanced MR imaging has been rather variable, ranging from 37% to 97%. Pre-clinical studies, however, demonstrate the advantages of macromolecular contrast media in the differentiation of breast tumors and in the monitoring of changes in tumor vessels after administration of angiogenesis inhibitors. Development of macromolecular contrast media has now advanced to the stage of clinical trials and the first contrast agents are approved. In addition to MR imaging of the breast contrast enhanced MR imaging of the axillary lymph nodes, the most common site of breast cancer spread, has emerged its clinical use. Gadolinium chelates and ultrasmall superparamagentic iron oxide (USPIO) particles are used to achieve this goal with promising results. Fluorochromes can be linked to specific ligands imparting probe selectivity for various targets of interest allowing e.g. the imaging of apoptosis or cancer related antigens (e.g. somatostatin receptor). Signal amplification by "Fluorescence resonance energy transfer"technology can be applied to synthesize "smart" probes, which allow for the detection of cancer related protease activity (e.g. cathepsin-B). Optical imaging marker genes such as green-or red fluorescent proteins can be exploited to monitor therapeutic gene transfer. Novel three-dimensional optical imaging technology will -in combination with the contrasting strategies mentioned above -have a significant impact on imaging breast cancer in the nearer future. Due to an inherently lower sensitivity of MRI to depict small (molecular) structures efficient signal amplification strategies are essential for molecular MR contrast agents. Various enzyme systems (e.g. Tyrosinase, ß-galactosidase, peroxidase) or internalizing cell receptors have been exploited for the detection gene expression by MRI. Strategies to reveal specific cell surface proteins by MRI include the application of targeted paramagnetic or superparamagnetic nanoparticles as well as "smart" probes, which alter their relaxation properties upon interaction with the molecluar target (f.i. "magnetic relaxation switches"). Moreover, approaches to imaging hyperpolarized 13 C or fluorine-labeled contrast agents have been pursued to improve SNR for molecular MRI. Pulmonary emphysema is a common, dangerous, and expensive disease. Because the definition of emphysema is based on pathological morphology, imaging techniques play a major role in the in-vivo assessment of pulmonary emphysema. Beyond a descriptive approach, these imaging techniques can be used to objectively quantify emphysema. This is at the base of the rational allocation of treatment, training or surgery. This presentation will detail the typical and atypical radiological presentations of emphysema. It will also emphasize the limitations of the subjective assessment of emphysema. To overcome these limitations, methods for the objective quantification of emphysema will be presented. Clinical and pre-clinical applications of objective quantification of emphysema will be presented. Finally, the potential impact of new technologies on the clinical work-up of pulmonary emphysema will be discussed. Response by the lung to inhaled cigarette smoke varies widely between individuals and can range from subclinical respiratory bronchiolitis through to end-stage Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The variety of interstitial lung diseases associated with cigarette smoking is wider than generally appreciated, and these often coexist. Although emphysema is a well understood consequence of cigarette smoking, its early pathogenesis and relationship to other smoking-induced infiltrative diseases is less clear-cut. An understanding of the pathologic basis of smokingrelated lung disease helps to explain the sometimes complex patterns encountered on high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT). The recent refinement of the classification of the idiopathic interstitial pneumonias and the longitudinal study of cigarette smokers with HRCT has furthered understanding of what can be regarded as an overlapping group of entities. The individual interstitial diseases ascribable to cigarette smoking, including respiratory bronchiolitis, desquamative interstitial pneumonia, Langerhans cell histiocytosis, and interstitial fibrosis are discussed in terms of their pathology and corresponding HRCT signs. Emphasis is placed on the frequent coexistence of various forms of smoking related interstitial lung disease. Learning Objectives: 1. To recognise the variety of interstial lung diseases that are encountered in cigarette smokers. 2. To understand the HRCT appearances of the "pure" smoking-related interstital lung diseases. 3. To appreciate the inter-relationship between the various smoking related lung pathologies, particularly the development of interstitial fibrosis.

A. Oikonomou; Alexandroupolis/GR Cigarette smoking accounts for most cases of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), a leading cause of disability and death. Anatomical sites affected in COPD are large and small airways (chronic bronchitis and bronchiolitis) and distal airspaces (centrilobular emphysema). The two major causes of airflow obstruction are: Increased airflow resistance related to luminal narrowing (chronic bronchitis) and reduced outflow pressure caused by loss of elastic recoil (emphysema).

body_text.text: In saber sheath trachea, which is strongly related to COPD, the coronal diameter of intrathoracic trachea is two-thirds of the sagittal one at the same level. Chronic bronchitis is a clinical diagnosis and radiography has little to offer. Its principal role is to exclude other diseases that may mimic chronic bronchitis. Limited information is also available about HRCT in chronic bronchitis, perhaps reflecting the nebulous nature of this clinical entity; the most common findings being bronchial wall thickening, air-trapping and bronchiolectasis. HRCT is more sensitive than radiography and PFTs in determining the type and severity of emphysema, and is the best noninvasive technique for detecting early emphysema. Localization of smoking induced emphysema within the secondary pulmonary lobule with radiologic-pathologic correlation and distinction from other types of emphysema (panlobular, paraseptal) as well as the functional -CT correlation will be explored. The entity of respiratory bronchiolitis, which is invariably associated with cigarette smoking, will be discussed as a possible mechanism of (early) mixed obstruction and restriction. Finally the emerging role of hyperpolarized 3He MRI ventilation imaging in the evaluation of COPD will be briefly reviewed. Learning Objectives: 1. To review the anatomy of the structures that can contribute to airflow obstruction as well as the pathophysiology of smoking-related COPD. 2. To discuss the radiologic and CT findings of specific diseases of the large and small airways (chronic bronchitis and bronchiolitis), and distal airspaces (centrilobular emphysema) that cause airflow obstruction in smokers and explore the functional -CT correlation. In AD, imaging studies may be normal or show general atrophy that is often more pronounced in the parietal and temporal regions, particularly the hippocampi. Temporo-parietal hypoperfusion is often found. Proton MRS may show low Nacetylaspartate (NAA) and elevated myoinositol. In frontotemporal dementia (FTD), the atrophy and hypoperfusion are predominantly frontal and temporal. Changes in the underlying white matter are seen in AD as well as in FTD. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rare disorder that is prion related. CT and MRI are often negative or show only atrophy in most CJD patients. Increased T2 signal in the cortex (particularly in the occipital lobes), thalami and basal ganglia is characteristic. MR diffusion imaging shows these abnormalities better.

body_text.text: The radiological report should describe the degree and location of atrophy (ventricles, cortical regions, hippocampi) and white matter abnormalities, as well as focal lesions. Comparison with previous studies should be included. In perfusion studies the degree and location of hypoperfusion should be described. The internal auditory canal (IAC) is studied using MRI: T1 without and with gadolinium injection, 3D high resolution T2 (HRT2). The anterior part of the IAC is occupied by the cochlear nerve and the facial nerve, the posterior part has the utricula ampullary nerve at the top and the saccular and postero ampullary nerve at the bottom. The main pathology encountered is a schwannoma of the eighth nerve which may originate in any of the vestibular and cochlear components studied by reformatted sagittal HRT2. The relationship of the facial, mixed nerves, and the jugular foramen must be precisely evaluated regarding the distance to the fundus of the IAC and the signal of the labyrinth. Other tumours that are not as frequent include the meningioma (whose diagnosis may be difficult compared with the schwannoma if located exclusively in the IAC), the lipoma (diagnosed using the fatty content) and vascular malformations (detected by angioMR). The size and structure of nodular arachnoiditis varies during the MR follow-up, lymphoma presents as enhanced nodules in both the IAC, outside the context of NF2. The appearances of metastasis is non-specific but the clinical history can leads to the right diagnosis. A-267 B. Large data sets: How to handle them in a PACS/HIS environment R.C. Sigal; Villejuif/FR In the last 5 years a dramatic increase in imaging modality performance, as well as image processing performance has occurred. This has resulted in more radiological procedures, more procedures per patient and more images per procedures. At the same time, there is worldwide shortage of radiologists. This presentation will expose some needs to overcome this actual and potential state of "image harassment". Display solutions, post processing and CAD technology will improve, allowing better handling of large image data sets. Solutions could include a variety of new tools such as combination of cine mode, 2D, 3D; paging on thicker slices; automatic registration; dynamic hanging protocols, and new input devices for navigation. PACS reading and advanced post processing capabilities should become functionally integrated in one software environment. Integration with Electronic Patient Record and link with reference knowledge should also help to interpret the radiological images. Distribution to referring physicians will change. Radiological images may be selected and presented under a variety of formats (2D, 3D, dynamic) with additional information (patient relevant clinical, biological and pathologic data) and knowledge references. One of the challenges will be the access of clinicians to advanced processed data, in their own clinical workflow. Solutions could be to customize data (full 3D sets) according to the needs of the clinicians. The data presented are meant to stimulate further thinking, particularly regarding clinical domains of application, tools, workflows and cost/revenues impacts of large image data sets. Learning Objectives:

The main indication for uterine artery embolization (UAE) is represented by a bleeding intra-mural myoma less than 10 cm in diameter, in patients with no wish of future pregnancy. The absolute contraindications are patients with asymptomatic uterine fibroids, pedunculated, subserosal and submucous myomas. There are relative contraindications (fibroids bigger than 10 cm in diameter, large submucous myomas, desire of pregnancy). Other contraindications are: contrast allergy, renal failure, bleeding diathesis, gynecological malignancy, active pelvic infection. Before the procedure, all patients require a gynaecologic history and physical examination to exclude other pathologies, laboratory test and cross-sectional images. Magnetic resonance imaging is more sensitive and accurate than US in evaluating the endometrium, excluding adenomyosis or any other pathologies. During the procedure adequate sedation and analgesia is achieved, in our practice, with midazolam and fentanyl. Concerning the approach, the unilateral right common femoral artery is preferred for access. We will discuss about which endpoint is the best? After the procedure the most important is to control the pain. The degree of pain is variable. We use nonsteroidal IV anti-inflammatory agents during 24 hours. After discharge the patient is switched to oral analgesics and anti-inflammatories.

The use of high resolution multislice spiral CT for volume imaging in spiral mode has led to a new enthusiasm for CT. Although CT examinations constitute only 4 -6% of all X-ray examinations in Germany, they cause more than 30% of the exposure due to medical X-ray applications. This background has added to the interest in reducing dose in CT examinations. Dose in multislice spiral CT can be reduced by online tube current modulation by typically 15 to 30%, depending on the patient shape and the anatomical region scanned. In general, no deterioration of image quality was observed. In some cases the noise pattern was improved because streaks along the direction of maximum attenuation were reduced. Additionally, a new method, the multidimensional adaptive filtering (MAF) technique significantly improves image quality and the diagnostic accuracy as compared to the standard reconstruction by reducing noise levels and by removing noise structures in the images. In clinical studies noise is reduced significantly for critical regions like the thoracic inlet and the pelvis without any loss of image sharpness, whereas the image quality of the upper neck or the abdomen remained unchanged. The differentiation of anatomical and pathological structures is enhanced in particular in the supraclavicular regions and the pelvis. Especially small lymph nodes in the supraclavicular region and perirectal can be reliably detected and distinguished from artifacts. When planning scientific study researchers typically try obtaining an overview of the specific literature related to their topic in order to identify key manuscripts, leading authors, or current trends. With today's Internet software it is quite convenient to access electronic libraries such as Medline or NLM/PubMed. Some of these libraries can be searched for references free of charge or at a low cost. Using the copy and paste function selected references may be downloaded into text software. State-of-the-art commercially available library software may be used to search and to download references into an organized electronic library including abstracts. Some journals provide access to or even downloads of complete articles.

The workflow in healthcare entities has to be supported by digital information systems of different vendors and characteristics. Those systems have to be carefully interconnected to provide a highly effective solution for the demand of a smooth and seemless information exchange supporting the complete workflow. However, current experience shows that this is seldom achieved and that more or less severe absence of interconnectivity occurs in several places. Renewal or more over a new launch of a radiology department gives you the unique chance to introduce new systems, which provide the required interoperability. This presentation will explain how to write a call for tender, how to talk professionally with vendors and how to make decisions about necessary systems and their configuration. We are confident about giving you valuable information about how to proceed in improving the functionality, economy and efficiency of your department and complete healthcare enterprise. Radiology plays an essential role in gastrointestinal hemorrhage (G-H) and ischemia (G-I). CT has as high a sensitivity as angiography in detecting vascular occlusions. Moreover, 3D CT-angiography provides additional information for planning therapeutic strategies. A bleeding source can be detected with CT and MR and a rapid intravenous bolus of contrast, with rates of less than 0.1 ml/min. Angiography with iodine or CO 2 has a comparable sensitivity (0.1-0.4 ml/min) but is superior in detecting indirect signs of the possible lesion. Endovascular techniques have an important role in G-I either alone or with surgery. In acute G-I there is a choice between surgical embolectomy or infusion of fibrinolitics. Patients with chronic G-I should be treated either with surgical revascularization or with dilatation and/or stenting. In G-E hemostasis can be obtained with embolization and its indications will depend on the bleeding source and the clinical situation. Embolization is particularly indicated in hemobilia, in aneurysms or vascular malformations of the gut, or in cases in which endoscopic techniques fail.
