body_text.text: B. Imaging and intervention in sepsis M.J. Lee; Dublin/IE Cross sectional imaging, and in particular CT, has become the main method of detecting abdominal collections. Indium labelled white cell scintigraphy and Gallium scintigraphy are reserved for those patients in whom there is a high clinical suspicion of abdominal sepsis but CT has not revealed a source of sepsis. Scintigraphy is also used in patients with suspected vascular graft infections or suspected infected hip prostheses. Percutaneous abscess drainage (PAD) has revolutionised the treatment of abdominal abscesses over the last 20 years with repeat laparotomy for post-operative abscesses becoming a rare event. Ultrasound or CT guidance can be used to guide PAD. Choosing an access route that does not cross intervening organs is of crucial importance to the safe performance of PAD. The Trocar or Seldinger techniques can be used with equal success. The cavity should be aspirated until dry and irrigated with saline. Repeat imaging after drainage is helpful to detect any undrained locules. PAD endpoints include patient defervescence, reduction in white blood cell count and catheter drainage of less than 10 mls per day. Details regarding PAD in specific abdominal regions are discussed. Success rate for PAD are high (close to 90%) in most abdominal organs. Slightly lower success rates are seen with PAD of pancreatic abscesses and abscesses associated with fistulas (60-85% success rates). Complication rates lie between 0-10%. Complications can be minimised by ensuring that the patient has broad spectrum antibiotic coverage before drainage, by carefully planning the access route and by ensuring diligent post-procedure care. Cinematic MRI examination allows to study both anatomy and functional changes during active and passive motion, improves the diagnostic accuracy of MRI especially in detecting dynamic instability patterns, transitory subluxation and bony or soft tissue impingement syndromes that affect the wrist and are not often sufficiently characterized using static view MR techniques. Dynamic MRI may passively and actively test the joint. The provocative test (acquisition performed under load or against stress) is the simplest dynamic MRI examination and may be helpful in some cases. The incremental passive positioning technique offers the possibility to evaluate the complex relationship between carpal bones; it can be performed in coronal plane images while the wrist joint is passively and incrementally moved from ulnar to radial deviation or in sagittal plane images while the the wrist is moved from flexion-neutral-extension position.

In the Departement of Radiology of the University "La Sapienza" we perform a particular protocol which allows us to obtain sagittal scans that visualize the same It has become an exciting and challenging goal for radiologists to assess the physiology of the tumor microcirculation by dynamic contrast-enhanced imaging (DCE imaging), in addition to the traditional morphology. Angiogenesis (the development of new microvessels), which is known as a key event for tumor growth and tumor metastasis, has been extensively studied either by CT or MRI with these new and non-invasive methods. It has been shown, first in experimental studies, followed later by clinical studies, that DCE imaging-based measures correlate well with angiogenesis and with survival in several types of tumors. Moreover, recent clinical studies have shown that DCE imaging can measure and predict tumor response to therapy, opening the ways to better treatment monitoring and to new evaluation tests for drug development. The goal of this session is, after a brief introduction on "what is angiogenesis?", to convince the radiologist that it will become possible to gain functional information during routine tumor imaging. Such information may become useful for the diagnostic, the prognostic and the therapeutic processes. In this fast growing field, many questions remain to be answered about how to extract data from dynamic imaging methods. The speakers will share and discuss their own imaging and data analysis strategies as well as the one's from other teams.
Tumor angiogenesis: Actors and roles C.-A. Cuénod; Paris/FR

The formation of new blood vessels is critical for tumour survival and growth. Tumour and stromal cells release angiogenic factors, which stimulate the proliferation, migration and morphogenesis of endothelial cells. Three processes are involved in vascular morphogenesis: Angiogenesis, sprouting of new capillaries from pre-existing ones; vasculogenesis, in situ differentiation of a primary capillary plexus from haemangioblastic stem cells; intusseption, branching of a capillary by longitudinal splitting. Hypoxia and acidosis, in the tumour microenvironment, strongly stimulate the release of angiogenic growth factors such as VEGFs and PIGF. Angiogenic stimulators include FGFs, TGFs, angiogenin, IL-8, HGF, GCSF and PD-ECGF. VEGFs, among the most effective agents, promote both angiogenesis and vascular permeability. Autocrine and paracrine processes are associated with endothelial cell activity involving cytokines, adhesion molecules and chemokines. Net neovascularisation is determined by the balance of angiogenic and angiostatic stimuli. The negative regulators include thrombospondin, angiostatin, and angiopoietins. A number of angiosuppressive drug are in development. Strong angiogenic activity (glioblastoma>renal>colon>mammary>lung>prostate) is associated with poorer prognosis and increased metastasis. Its evaluation can be used as prognostic marker. Techniques of proliferating endothelial cells labelling have been developed to specifically identify angiogenesis. The proliferating capillary index is used to compare tumour angiogenesis with physiological angiogenesis in the ovary. The faster the growth of the tumour, the less mature is the vessel bed. Immature microvessels are distorted irregular and hyper permeable, which has an impact on their efficiency and capabilities. The poor hemodynamic characteristics of the tumours can be non-invasively assessed by dynamic contrast-enhanced imaging. A simple and effective method for imaging tumour angiogenesis would not only provide an independent marker of cancer prognosis, but also be of benefit for monitoring anti-angiogenesis drugs. This presentation highlights the simplicity of dynamic contrast enhanced (DCE) CT for imaging angiogenesis. CT assessment of angiogenesis simply requires a bolus injection of conventional contrast material followed by either rapid imaging without table movement or a spiral volume acquisition at a time previously determined using a test bolus. Hence DCE-CT is widely available and readily incorporated into existing CT protocols that continue to provide the mainstay for size-based assessments of tumour response (e.g. RECIST) in both clinical oncology and research. The simplicity of DCE-CT favours successful and consistent data collection in multi-centre studies. Temporal changes in contrast enhancement are linearly related to changes in concentration making absolute quantification of tumor perfusion, blood-volume and permeability straightforward and reproducible irrespective of the observer or analysis methodology. Measurements have been validated against a number of reference methods and correlate with histopathological assessments of angiogenesis. Derivation of the Standardised Perfusion Value can correct for changes in cardiac output that may occur with some anti-angiogenesis drugs. A range of commercial software packages is now available for calculating functional CT parameters with generation of colour-coded parametric maps. DCE-CT can be performed on integrated PET/CT systems with the potential for advanced characterisation of tumour biology. CT-based angiogenesis imaging is similar in complexity and concept to routine CT angiography, but depicts the tumour microcirculation rather than discrete vessels. Learning Objectives: 1. CT-based angiogenesis imaging is similar in complexity and concept to routine CT angiography, but depicts the tumor microcirculation rather than discrete vessels. 2. Acquisition and processing protocols for CT angiogenesis imaging are straightforward, producing reproducible results that have been validated against reference methods including histopathological assessments of angiogenesis. 3. DCE-CT can be performed on integrated PET/CT systems with the potential for advanced characterisation of tumour biology through simultaneous assessment of tumour angiogenesis and glucose metabolism. Although cardiac ultrasound is applicable for the evaluation of cardiac function in a variety of disease states, the main issue in the pediatric age group is congenital heart disease (CHD). Till the 1980's cardiac catheterisation and angiocardiography (C&A) were the only means to establish a diagnosis in CHD. With the availability of 2D-echocardiography non-invasive diagnosis became possible and the subsequent evolution of 2D-echo, colorflow mapping and Doppler modalities turned it into the imaging modality of choice for infants and children.

The sequential segmental analysis forms the basis of CHD diagnosis. This analysis is based on the anatomic characteristics of the cardiac chambers and the various possibilities of connections between these chambers. Precordial and subcostal approaches should give a complete visualisation of all cardiac structures. The study starts with the systemic and pulmonary veins and works its way through the atria and the ventricles to the aorta and pulmonary arteries. 2D-echo depicts the anatomy and colorflow mapping, while pulsed & CW Doppler are added to assess hemodynamics. This approach requires multiple scans rather than just the recording of pre-defined imaging planes. The reliability of echocardiography for the primary diagnosis has been established through studies comparing echo with C&A and with intraoperative findings. However, echocardiography is an interactive tool and the reliability is highly operator-dependent. In the follow-up of postoperative and adult patients complete evaluation with echocardiography is not always possible. Additional imaging modalities are needed in this growing population. The population of adults with congenital heart disease is increasing and it is estimated that 80-85% of patients born with congenital heart disease survive to adulthood. In the U.K. alone an additional 2,500 patients are added to this population annually and over half of these need access to specialist attention. MR imaging offers much more utility and repeatability than cardiac angiography, and in some areas it can provide information not achieved by invasive techniques. The alternative non-invasive technique of echocardiography is frequently inadequate in adult patients with complex functional and anatomical problems. Cardiac MR offers a wide range of investigational options, each patient having unique individual problems. Fast gradient echo sequences can show structural (black blood static images) and functional (white blood ciné sequences) anatomy in complex oblique planes. Velocity encoding can measure volume flow at specific sites, enabling calculation of cardiac output, differential vessel flow and regurgitant fraction. Peak velocity measurement can estimate intracardiac pressure drops. Intravenous Gadolinium injection allows 3D volume acquisition of complex vessels as well as opening the way to myocardial perfusion and viability studies. These techniques offer a complex range of possibilities for each patient and hence an individual protocol is selected for each patient to optimise the benefits of the limited patient time in the magnet. A detailed audit of our GUCH MRI examinations has demonstrated the utility of the technique in a variety of conditions and reflects the clinical feedback from the paediatric cardiologists who use the service. In patients with a known primary extrathoracic malignancy, staging investigations will commonly include radiological examination of the chest. Whilst most patients will be referred for a plain chest radiograph, there is a limit to the size (typically around 1 cm diameter) of pulmonary nodules detectable by conventional radiography. Because the contrast resolution of computed tomography (CT) is higher and there is no anatomical superimposition, small intrapulmonary nodules will frequently be identified; this is particularly true with the wider availability of spiral (and now, multidetector row) CT machines and the concommitant capacity for subsecond image acquisition. However, determining the significance of focal intrapulmonary nodules in patients with a known extrathoracic cancer, remains a vexing problem for the radiologist and clinician. The significance of imaging findings (specifically at CT) in patients with underlying malignancy will be discussed. The potential importance of the multiplicity and size of pulmonary nodules will be reviewed. HRCT features, criteria to extablish the diagnosis and differential diagnosis will be discussed. Imaging findings will be discussed. MR imaging plays a major role in the diagnosis and management of patients with epilepsy, allowing the direct demonstration of the anatomical lesions which can be related to epileptic discharges. Negative or positive MR results are now considered for classification of epileptic patients as cryptogenetic or symptomatic. The best quality MR examination is mandatory and it should be focused on the area of the brain suspected as the epileptogenic zone (EZ), that is the cortical area of seizure generation and propagation. The definition of the EZ is a major task in patients candidated to surgery, since it can influence the surgical planning and the extent of surgical resection. Different pre-surgical strategies can be fol-lowed for this purpose, including clinical observation, electrophysiological and imaging modalities. MRI findings may influence the pre-surgical work-up, suggesting or excluding the need for invasive electro-clinical investigation. The emergence of functional MR (fMR) studies for localizing brain activity has significantly expanded the potential clinical role of MR providing information on the topographic relationship between the structural lesions and the eloquent areas of the brain. Various types of malformation of cortical development (MCD), particularly focal cortical dysplasias (FCD), together with tumours were the most frequent neuropathological substrates found in our surgical series. Correlation between MRI, histopathological and electro-clinical data in more than 450 patients, with refractory partial epilepsy, operated on since June 1996 at the Epilepsy Surgery Centre "Claudio Munari" of Niguarda Hospital in Milano, will be presented.

B. How and when to image epilepsy in the child C.A. Raybaud; Marseille/FR Introduction: Epilepsy is a chronic disease, different from acute symptomatic seizures. It is special in children because immaturity favours seizures, because the clinical pattern is age-related and changes with brain maturation, because of common neonatal developmental and genetic aetiologies and because deleterious effects of epilepsy on the psycho-intellectual development makes early and efficient treatment mandatory. Classified on electro-clinical data into benign idiopathic (normal brain), symptomatic (abnormal brain) and cryptogenic (abnormality likely but unproved) epilepsies. It is often associated with mental delay and/or cerebral palsy. Imaging tools: The best available technology, MRI, to be used first with proper reference planes, varied sequences adapted to the brain maturation (T2 with very long TR/long TE) and high resolution millimetric slices (cortical assessment). Cortex is blurred during the intermediate stages of maturation and use of FLAIR is uncertain before four years. Sedation, or preferably anesthesia, is mandatory in young or un-cooperative children. Indications: Preliminary electro-clinical assessment is always needed as imaging epilepsy is never an emergency. Idiopathic epilepsies by definition are not investigated. Symptomatic/cryptogenic epilepsies are investigated for diagnosis and for surgery, when needed.

-Non-specific: atrophy, abnormal signals (gliosis, abnormal myelination F G extra-temporal locations. The identification of the precise epileptogenic focus producing seizures is crucial to a good outcome. Identification of the eloquent cerebral areas near the region to be resected is also essential to prevent post-operative neurological deficit. MR imaging is the most important neuroimaging modality in the investigation of adult patients with the medically intractable epilepsy. Functional MR imaging has an established role in the evaluation of patients prior to epilepsy surgery by identifying language, memory and sensorimotor areas of the cerebral cortex. PET imaging may be more sensitive in some patients with unremarkable MR imaging findings, however it does not confer specificity of etiological diagnosis and it is technically demanding and cost intensive. This lecture highlights the role of modern imaging modalities in the work-up of adult intractable epilepsy, MR imaging techniques and findings in such cases and an overview of supportive data provided from functional MR, MR spectroscopy and PET studies. This lecture also briefly summarizes new developments about the imaging modalities and techniques in epilepsy, including advanced functional MR imaging, receptor PET studies, magnetic source imaging and high fieldstrength MR tools with magnets of 3 Tesla and above that are becoming clinical tools and have the promise of improving diagnosis. The normal radiological anatomy of the neck is reviewed, emphasizing spatial anatomy as defined by the neck fascial layers. Although the fascias themselves are not visible in the normal situation, such a spatial approach to neck anatomy gives a method to analyze the images and allows the building of a differential diagnosis of diseases unique to each space. Another point discussed will be the normal anatomy, classification and radiologic appearance of the neck lymph nodes. Imaging of the neck can be performed using different modalities, including ultrasonography, CT and MRI. As each modality has advantages and disadvantages, a well-considered choice, tailored to the individual patient, is necessary to get cost-efficient results. Furthermore, attention to technical details is essential to obtain images of sufficient diagnostic quality. Learning Objectives: 1. To provide a systematic review of neck anatomy from a radiological point of view, emphasizing spatial anatomy. 2. To become familiar with the relative advantages and disadvantages of the available imaging modalities for neck imaging. 3. To learn the basic technical requirements for adequate neck imaging.

B. Non-nodal masses R. Maroldi; Brescia/IT In most non-nodal neck masses imaging is necessary to suggest the proper diagnosis, rather than to detect the mass. Patient's age, history and symptoms will dictate the choice of the proper imaging modality. Neck masses in children tend to be benign; most have a fluid content and can be approached, at first, with US. In adults, non-nodal and non-thyroidal masses of the neck can be grouped into inflammatory, vascular, neural and other neoplastic lesions. Acute inflammatory neck lesions (cellulitis, abscess) can rapidly spread into the mediastinum or towards the skull base. Therefore, these lesions require a precise and prompt assessment of their extent, usually achieved by CT. The differentiation of a non-thyroidal, non-nodal neck mass among vascular, neural and other neoplastic lesions is a different problem. Generally, the diagnosis is adequately obtained by combining spatial information (i.e. the anatomic compartment from which the mass arises) with its intrinsic imaging findings (liquid/solid content, vascularization, degree of enhancement, margins). Particularly, the epicenter of the mass and the pattern of adjacent structure displacement play an essential role in the diagnostic process. US, CT and MR can be used. A part from submucosal (pharynx/larynx/oral cavity) lesions, which require cross sectional imaging (CT or MR), US is generally used for more superficial masses. If a vascular/highly vascularized mass is suspected on US, angio-MR or multislice CT are indicated. MR better examines lesions that bear potential relationships with the spinal cervical canal, the skull base or the brachial plexus. Learning Objectives:

1. To become familiar with the basic patterns of the different neck-spaces expansile lesions. 2. To review the imaging finding of inflammatory, vascular, neural and salivary gland neck masses. 3. To review the proper indications to the different imaging modalities on the basis of the specific clinical setting.

A-306 C. Nodal masses J.A. Castelijns; Amsterdam/NL Detection and further analysis of neck nodes can be performed with different modalities CT, MRI, US and UsgFNAC, which are all significantly more accurate than palpation for staging of the neck. In patients with larger oropharyngeal and laryngeal tumors, a CT or MRI will be obtained in most cases for imaging size and extent of the primary tumor. However, the accuracy of these modalities may be too low in many cases to differentiate between benign and malignant metastastic disease and additional imaging may be needed. UsgFNAC proves to be a more accurate technique for assessment of the status of the neck. Ultrasound guided fine needle aspiration cytology has gained popularity in staging the clinically N0 neck in patients with head and neck carcinomas, especially in patients in which a wait-and-see policy is considered. On the one hand it can be used to upstage the N0 neck, thus enabling adequate treatment, on the other hand it can give more certainty that the neck is really free of metastases and consequently the clinician may refrain from neck dissection and perform a strict follow-up.

Molecular imaging represents the most dramatic challenge for the future by aiming a few major strategies: direct imaging, visualizing the probetarget interactions that unmask disease specific molecules (tumor associated antigens, receptors, nucleic acids) or activated proteins featuring specifically disrupted transduction pathways; indirect/surrogate imaging, describing the detection of the downstream effects of gene products (protein-protein interactions, oncogene activity, receptor-mediated signaling, pro/antiapoptotic pathways, cell cycle, proteolytic cleavage). For instance, the use of "reporter-transgene" technology allows the imaging of transcriptional gene regulation or of the activity of specific cell signaling pathways. The major biological relevance of such molecular imaging strategies is their ability to improve early diagnostic detection (based on the occurrence of minimal functional lesions within the diseased cell population) and to monitor therapeutic responses at the molecular level (e.g. chemotherapy sensitivity of p53-mediated apoptosis). Learning Objectives: 1. To learn the molecular aspects of the major genetic and epigenetic changes associated to neoplastic disease. 2. To understand how the biological events responsible for neoplastic diseases can be exploited for molecular imaging-based detection of aberrant cell functions. 3. To learn the principles underlying the major techniques used in molecular imaging strategy.

Monitoring of angiogenesis using vascular, metabolic, and labelling MRI H.-U. Kauczor; Heidelberg/DE Tumor angiogenesis is initiated by hypoxia, vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), angiopoietins and the interaction of tumor and stromal cells. Using different dynamic MR-techniques, including BOLD imaging, the functional aspects of angiogenesis such as changes of tumor blood volume and flow ("perfusion") as well as vessel permeability and maturation can be visualized. To this end, macromolecular contrast agents such as gadolinium labeled albumin or labeled graft polymers improve accuracy. In addition, metabolic consequences of angiogenesis and its inhibition can be assessed non-invasively using proton-and phosphor MR-spectroscopy. The ratio of choline to (phospho-) creatine resonances and resonances of phosphodiesters change. This is a result of the altered metabolic turnover of phospholipid membranes and increasing fractions of lipids which are caused by regression of central vessels due to high intratumoral pressure and the development of necrosis. Specific imaging of angiogenesis may gain increasing importance as a novel field in functional imaging. Using anti-endothelial alpha-v beta-3 antibodies labeled with a paramagnetic contrast agent, highly detailed imaging of the angiogenic vasculature has been demonstrated in experimental tumors. As new targets for specific contrast agents, E-Selectin, intercellular adhesion molecule (ICAM) and matrix fibrin were identified and used in preliminary studies. Learning Objectives: 1. MRI is capable to monitor changes of tumor vascularization during different stages of angiogenesis and during anti-angiogenic therapies. 2. Metabolic changes during this process can be assessed by MR spectroscopy. 3. New contrast agents open the field for specific imaging of angiogenic activity, which may gain importance for detection, categorization and monitoring of tumors in patients.

Molecular imaging in oncology (I) H. Hricak; New York, NY/US Molecular imaging affords in vivo detection, characterization, and quantitative analysis of biological processes at the cellular and molecular levels. In a new imaging paradigm, it brings together multiple imaging techniques (namely MR, PET and optical technology) and multiple disciplines, including basic cell/molecular biology, chemistry, medicine, pharmacology, medical physics, biomathematics, and bioinformatics. In almost all molecular imaging assays, high affinity probes, developed with pharmacodynamics, provide the image signal for targeted cellular components (e.g., cell membrane, interstitial space).The exception is MR spectroscopy (MRS), where the imaging signal emanates from endogenous molecules. In cancer care, MRS is already in clinical use for the evaluation of brain, breast and prostate cancer. In the prostate, MRS provides metabolic information through the detection of the metabolites citrate, creatine and choline. The normal prostate gland contains citrate, while in cancer there is an increased amount of choline.

The method for depicting tumors is based on an increased choline-creatine / citrate ratio. A statistically significant correlation between the degree of metabolic abnormality and cancer aggressiveness (Gleason grade) has been shown. Furthermore, the addition of metabolic information from 3D-MRSI to the morphologic data obtained from MR imaging improves assessment of tumor location and the attendant risk of disease progression. Today's radiologists might think of clinical molecular imaging as a phenomenon of the future, but it is already here. Molecular imaging will likely come to dominate radiology, requiring expanded understanding and the development of a new generation of radiologists at ease with both molecular biology and imaging technology.

Molecular imaging in oncology (II) S.M. Larson; New York, NY/US At Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, we use molecular imaging to study key features of the cancer mass, including, cellular proliferation, apoptosis, angiogenesis, hypoxia, metastases, and invasion. Cancer biology: Gene expression imaging: Gene expression imaging in living animals was first performed at MSKCC in 1995 and 1996, based on radiotracer 2'-fluoro-2'deoxy-1-b-D-arabinofuranysl-5-iodo-uracil (FIAU), as reporter substrate and herpes simplex virus 1 thymidine kinase (hsvTK) as reporter enzyme. Cancer phenotype: The cancer's own biochemistry is used for "functional" tumor imaging, using positron emission tomography (PET), single photon emission tomography (SPECT), and magnetic resonance imaging/spectroscopy (MRI/ MRS). Drug development and assessment: Tumor response: The goal is to define characteristic changes in metabolism during treatment which best predicts response of an individual lesion to therapy. Imaging targeted therapy: Tracer studies demonstrated the degree of targeting to tumors and provided direct information about therapeutic index in vivo. Cell based therapies: Non-invasive imaging methodologies are being used to complement existing viral and cell-based gene therapy programs, and to explore the in vivo behavior of immune cells, stem cells, and cancer cells. Innovations in molecular imaging: Innovations include new vectors for gene imaging, radiolabeled drugs, and unique cellular systems with specific targeting capabilities. Taken together, these imaging methods provide the beginnings of a research tool kit with relevance to many facets of imaging the genotype and phenotype of human cancer. In the last few years, techniques for molecular biology have made enormous progress, with identification of several biological markers that can now be used for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. Among them, antibodies have raised lots of interest particularly with the purpose of using them for imaging purposes.

In clinical practice, there are already a few examples regarding imaging of tumors with nuclear medicine techniques (anti-CEA imaging, etc.), mainly based on the use of murine antibodies and humanized antibodies. There have also been attempts to utilize, exploiting techniques of molecular biology, human antibodies and their fragments, which have several advantages, amongst which are better patient tolerance, lack of adverse effects, especially regarding entrapping of the antibody in the reticulo-endothelial system (RES) in the liver and spleen. Antibodies and their fragments can be bound to contrast agents and radionuclides, although difficulties can be related to the stability in vivo of the compound. In this lecture we will look at the actual possibilities of antibody imaging and at future perspectives related to either development of antibodies or their binding with contrast agent in order to achieve a satisfactory and easily detectable signal. The society also has experience of hosting many international radiological assemblies including AOCR and WFTIN to name few. Members of KRS will also host the 11 th WFUMB in Seoul in 2006. Four distinguished members of KRS will present details of radiological review of cholangiocarcinoma, the second most common primary hepatobiliary tumor in Korea, a country along with Japan, which is known to be one of the most prevalent geographic areas for the cancer. It will cover in-depth review of the cancer including morphological classification, imaging diagnosis and interventional procedures using exquisite diagrams and images. The session will serve as a window to view the radiologists and their organization's responsibilities and achievements as well as new challenges ahead of us with solutions. Learning Objectives:

1. To learn about the activities and present standing of the Korean Radiological Society and its members. 2. To review the radiological aspects of cholangiocarcinoma covering from its morphological classification to interventional procedures.

Cholangiocarcinoma: Morphological classification according to growth pattern and imaging findings J. Lim; Seoul/KR Based on its growth characteristics, a new classification has been proposed by the Liver Cancer Study Group of Japan, with tumors being classified as massforming, periductal-infiltrating, and intraductal-growing types. Mass-forming intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma shows a large, well-defined, irregular mass with frequent satellite nodules; periductal-infiltrating cholangiocarcinoma results in obliteration of the bile ducts and proximal dilatation without an identifiable mass; intraductal-growing cholangiocarcinoma presents with focal or segmental bile duct dilatation with or without visible intraductal papillary tumors. Mass-forming extrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma results in bile duct obstruction by a small mass; periductal-infiltrating cholangiocarcinoma produce segmental or diffuse, concentric thickening of the wall of the bile ducts without a focal mass; intraductal-growing cholangiocarcinoma produce bile duct dilatation with single or multiple, papillary intraductal masses. This classification is considered to be the most reasonable because it describes the gross appearance, growing characteristics, biological behavior, and prognostic implication for patients and because it is helpful for radiologic interpretation. According to this new classification, the exophytic or nodular type matches the mass-forming, the infiltrating or sclerosing type matches the periductal-infiltrating, and the polypoid or papillary type matches the intraductal-growing type.

Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma: Imaging findings T.K. Kim; Seoul/KR Radiologic findings of intrahepatic cholangiocarcinomas greatly vary according to the location of the tumor. Hilar cholangiocarcinomas are adenocarcinomas arising from the confluence of right and left hepatic ducts and the majority of them are of periductal-infiltrating type. Non-union of the right and left hepatic ducts with or without visible thickened wall is a typical finding on imaging. Recent technical advances in imaging and surgical techniques have resulted in better patient selection, lower operative morbidity and mortality, and higher survival rates.

Multi-phasic thin-section CT, MRCP, MR angiography as well as direct cholangiography have been used to characterize the lesion and to determine whether or not they are resectable by assessing vascular and bile duct invasion and distant metastasis. On the other hand, cholangiocarcinoma arising from a peripheral, small intrahepatic bile duct usually appears as an intrahepatic mass that requires differentiation from metastasis or hepatocellular carcinoma. This type of cholangiocarcinoma is called mass-forming intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma and is usually large because they are rarely symptomatic early in their course. Because of its typical histopathologic nature including a white, firm, and solid tumor frequently with dense fibrous stranding in the central portion, mass-forming intrahepatic cholangiocarcinomas have typical CT or MR findings; marked low attenuation with thin, rim-like enhancement at the periphery during non-equilibrium phase and strong, prolonged enhancement of the tumor during delayed phase. Dilation of intrahepatic bile ducts is frequently associated with this tumor, especially in patients with clonorchiasis.

Intraductal papillary tumor of the bile ducts J.K. Han; Seoul/KR Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma is a type of carcinoma arising from any portion of the intrahepatic bile duct epithelium and is the second most common primary intrahepatic malignancy after hepatocellular carcinoma. Its incidence varies by geographic location, accounting for 6.4-25% of all primary hepatic malignancies. Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma is usually classified into two types, peripheral and hilar depending on their origin. Peripheral cholangiocarcinoma (PCC) usually refers to the tumor arising from the duct peripheral to the secondary confluence. While most PCCs develop in the small peripheral ducts and grow in a nodular, massive or diffuse pattern with early infiltration into the hepatic parenchyma, in rare instances, PCCs have the growth pattern of intraductal papillary cholangiocarcinoma; polypoid or papillary tumors arise from the peripheral duct and with tumor growth confined within the bile duct. Sometimes, these tumors form multiple tumor casts along the peripheral tributaries of the bile duct (upstream ducts). This type of the tumor has been named as an intraductal variant of PCC and this tumor comprised about 15% of all surgically resected PCC (not including hilar cholangiocarcinoma) in our hospital. Unlike the ordinary PCC, this tumor shows indolent biologic behavior and better prognosis, like polypoid cholangiocarcinomas arising from the hilum or extrahepatic bile duct. Dilated intrahepatic duct with intraductal papillary tumor, sometimes filled with tumor cast or mucin are characteristic radiologic features. Familiarity with these radiologic features can enable early diagnosis. Learning Objectives: 1. To become familiar with various radiologic findings of this uncommon type of biliary tumor. 2. To know the similarity of IPMT of the pancreas with intraductal papillary tumor of bile duct. 3. To know the differential points between intraductal papillary tumor and bile duct invasion of HCC.

Cholangiocarcinoma: Biliary intervention K.-B. Sung; Seoul/KR Biliary interventions are one of the most popular procedures in Korea. The main procedure for cholangiocarcinoma is percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage (PTBD). Purposes of biliary interventions in cholangiocarcinoma are palliative bile drainage, preoperative improvement of liver function, and evaluation of tumor extension into the intrahepatic duct with choledochoscopic direct vision with biopsy. Palliative PTBD is not an indication in the early stage with mild jaundice and in late stage with multiple separation of intrahepatic bile ducts. Indications of emergency PTBD are not only septic cholangitis, but also in the cases of failed insertion of nasobiliary tube after contrast injection into the biliary tree during ERCP, in patients with biliary obstruction, for prevention of septic cholangitis. Principle of PTBD is to drain the maximum area of the liver with the minimum number of drainage tubes. Do not insert more than one drainage tube in one session. Because of advances in drainage tubes, passage across the tumor is nearly always successful and drainage of right or left lobe can prevent aggravation of liver function. Left PTBD has an advantage in patients with ascites for prevention of ascites leakage through the PTBD insertion site. Left PTBD is indicated in most of the patients with hilar cholangiocarcinoma for palliation and preoperative management because the right anterior and posterior segmental ducts are more commonly separated. Internal drainage of bile has advantages physiologically but external drainage does not have serious problems. CT may be required for those patients with unusual presentation like emphysematous cholecystitis, perforation or abscess. Acalculous cholecystitis is a challenging problem. It sometimes requires percutaneous cholecystostomy for diagnosis or treatment purposes.

In patients with acute cholangitis, sonography remains the first step for imaging, but its diagnostic accuracy is disappointing. This is related to low sensitivity, despite a high specificity. CT carries a slightly better sensitivity, and again a high specificity but overall accuracy is not sufficient. MR cholangiography and endosonography are the best methods for the detection. Both have advantages and limitations, including cost and availability, but ERCP remains necessary for therapeutic purposes, especially stone extraction.

In conclusion, emergency radiologists should be able to drive the patient through multiple imaging modalities in order to make a prompt diagnosis with no delay, and be aware of the therapeutic options, including cooperation between radiologist, endoscopist and the surgeon.

B. Imaging and intervention in acute pancreatic conditions C. Procacci, G. Mansueto; Verona/IT Acute pancreatic conditions are common and can be catastrophic; even if there is a wide range in the severity of the clinical presentations, each can be potentially life-threatening. Pancreatic infections, involvement of adjacent organs, structures and spaces by pancreatic diseases and, lastly, vascular complications are considered as acute pancreatic conditions. The role of radiology in the management of acute pancreatic conditions is twofold. First of all, the radiologist must identify the lesion and secondly, once the diagnosis has been made, he must proceed with a correct therapeutic percutaneous radiological approach whenever an interventional procedure is preferable to surgery, or is performed preoperatively to optimize its results. Learning Objectives: 1. To become familiar with acute pancreatic conditions. 2. To understand the role of radiology and the integration of imaging and intervention in acute pancreatic conditions. 3. To comprehend the indications for the percutaneous management of pancreatic infection.

A-347 C. Imaging and intervention in acute urinary conditions R.H. Oyen, B. Van Cleynenbreugel; Leuven/BE Acute urinary obstruction is by far the most common acute condition requiring imaging and, eventually, imaging-guided intervention. Radiologists need to define whether or not there is obstruction, determine the level and the cause, estimate the duration, the presence of complications, and define whether intervention is required to relieve obstruction. Percutaneous nephrostomy is the interventional technique of choice. Numerous catheters are available for US-, fluoroscopy-, or CT-guided procedures. An individual tailored approach is feasible, and depends on the patient's condition and the experience of the radiologist. Co-operation with the urologist is essential. Although acute pyelonephritis is a clinical diagnosis, imaging is frequently performed (US /CT). It is essential to distinguish uncomplicated from complicated pyelonephritis. In complicated pyelonephritis (pyonephrosis, renal-perirenal abscess) imaging studies are essential to evaluate the extent, to decide whether intervention is required, and to decide the most appropriate approach. Acute renal/perirenal haemorrhage requires targeted imaging to evaluate the extent, the underlying cause (angiomyolipoma,...) and will guide diagnostic and therapeutic management (embolisation, urgent or delayed surgery). Acute prostatitis complicated with abscess formation has become very rare. Transperineal US-or CT-guided drainage may be indicated to relieve pain and to hasten cure. Likewise abscesses of the scrotal wall or of the scrotal contents may be drained percutaneously. (Partial) priapism is a very rare condition requiring imaging. Ultrasonography and MR-imaging is often performed to evaluate the extent of the thrombosis and this study serves as the base line for comparative follow-up studies. Three aspects of routine pediatric imaging are especially focused on: dealing with cranial trauma and its imaging interpretation; chest CT in some of its most common indications; abdominal ultrasonography. These three topics will be presented at the cutting edge of technique, technology and clinical application. With this, controversy between the lecturers and the audience may arise and should be articulated. How far can and should we go in the attempt to diagnose abnormality by imaging means? How specific can or must be our results? -Is the traditional rule "diagnose agressively -treat conservatively" still valid in pediatric radiology? Isn't it even enhanced by today's imaging options?

Imaging and interpreting intracranial trauma in children T.A.G.M. Huisman; Zürich/CH Traumatic brain injury is a leading cause of death and disability in children. The incidence of pediatric head trauma is estimated to be 300 per 100,000 children per year, with deadly outcome in 10 per 100,000 children per year in the United States. The three most frequent causes of injury are accidental falls, motor vehicle accidents and the so-called non-accidental trauma (child abuse). The cause of head trauma, the location and mechanism of injury as well as the reaction of the brain to trauma varies depending on the child's age. Different kinds of direct or indirect forces (acceleration/deceleration, rotational forces) result in structural brain injury. Next to the primary brain injury that is inflicted at the moment of trauma, secondary brain injury, resulting from the brain's response to the primary injury, determines final outcome. Neuroimaging should identify the extent of acute brain injury to guide treatment in limiting primary and secondary brain injury. Learning Objectives: 1. To discuss the imaging approach in head trauma. 2. To summarise the imaging features of traumatic brain injury. 3. To review the unique features of head trauma in children.

The need for chest CT in children C. Owens; London/UK This presentation will discuss applications of CT in the evaluation of chest disease in children. The majority of children requiring thoracic CT fall in to three basic groups, hence, three basic protocols suffice for most chest CT examinations in children. Metastatic disease, focal lung pathology or mediastinal mass/ adenopathy will allow scanning with thicker beam collimation and lower pitch factors preserving risk from inappropriate over dosage. Vascular or airways disease may require thinner collimation and higher pitches. MRI may therefore be more appropriate in these patients. In diffuse lung disease, sequential scans with thin collimation and high spatial frequency reconstructions are the established optimal technique. Tube current (MA) and kilo voltage KV should be kept to the lowest allowing diagnostic quality images and depend on patient size and weight. Very occasionally volumetric and high resolution images are required in the same patient. There are many controversial issues within applications of pediatric chest CT and it is vital that the radiologist is constantly questioning the added diagnostic role of CT over the other alternative non ionising examinations (e.g. MRI) when available and appropriate. The presentation will discuss potential controversy within the assessment of children requiring thoracic CT. Volumetric techniques are greatly improved by multislice spiral CT scanners that can scan large volumes with narrow slice collimation. These new scanners confirm that they now allow the radiologists to increase the diagnostic accuracy and clinical indications of volumetric scanning not only by means of high-resolution transverse CT sections but also by means of high-quality 2D and 3D images. Multiplanar reformatting creates sagittal, coronal or curved imaging planes providing unique displays for the transverse images. Volume rendering techniques address some of the limitations of shaded-surface display techniques. MIP rendering can be applied to either the entire imaged volume or can be targeted to a thin slab of tissue. All reformatting and volume-rendering techniques provide optimal results when applied to motion-free, three-dimensional data sets composed of isometric voxels. The purpose of this lecture is to focus on practical aspects of CT angiographic techniques aimed at evaluating thoracic vessels (aorta excepted). Learning Objectives: 1. To review the acquisition and reconstruction protocols for optimal imaging of thoracic vessels. The normal radiographic and cross-sectional anatomy of thoracic aorta, great vessels and mediastinal veins will be reviewed along with a description of the most common variants. A detailed knowledge of the wide range of congenital abnormalities that may involve the aortic arch is fundamental for a correct interpretation of the mediastinum, in order to avoid misdiagnoses. The most common anomaly of the aorta is an aberrant right subclavian artery originating from a normal left-sided arch, occurring in approximately 0.5% of the population. The proximal portion of the aberrant artery is frequently dilated, a finding known as diverticulum of Kommerel. A right aortic arch is present in about 0.1 -0.2% of subjects and in approximately 70% of cases is associated with an aberrant left subclavian artery. The presence of a left ligamentum arteriosum completes the vascular ring in most of such patients.

In patients with double aortic arch, the right common carotid and subclavian arteries arise from the right arch, whereas the left common carotid and subclavian arteries arise from the left arch. The two arches join posteriorly to form one descending aorta. Cervical aortic arch is a developmental entity consisting of persistence of the right or left third branchial arch and regression of the fourth branchial arches. A persistent left SVC draining to a coronary sinus is the most common thoracic venous anomaly that occurs in 0.3% of healthy subjects and 4.3% of patients with congenital heart disease. Rarely, the left SVC drains into the left atrium, thus creating a right-to-left shunt. Learning Objectives: 1. To describe the normal anatomy of the aorta, great vessels, and mediastinal veins. EN appointed the EHRcom Task Force to take forward its pre-standard ENV 13606 to a full EN. It is a multi-part standard whose purpose, scope and current status will be explored. Aimed at EHR communication it seeks to allow any kind of healthrelated to be faithfully communicated in a standardised way even though the data might have originally been captured in disparate systems. It provides an essential building brick in the evolution of life-long EHRs. The basis of the standard lies in a number of European R&D projects, having a strong requirements focus, as well as previous pre-standards, and is being informed by EHR implementation experience.

A worked example will be presented to show how the standard might be used for the communication of request-result cycle relating to imaging investigations. During the evolution of the standard, a number of harmonisation collaborations have taken place to ensure reasonable compatibility with systems based on HL7 (especially CDA) and IHE.

Archetypes are an important feature of current perceptions that have informed the standard, and allow domain-specific constraints to be applied to the creation and analysis of EHR entries, thus empowering professionals to implement policies governing the use of EHRs. Some archetype examples will be presented and explored.

Next steps in the evolution and use of this standard will be addressed. Indications for long-term venous access are increasing and insertion of a tunnelled central venous catheter is one of the most frequently requested radiological procedures. Perhaps the largest group of patients requiring a long-term venous catheter are those with malignancy who require systemic chemotherapy, blood products and repeated blood sampling over a prolonged period. Others indications are total parenteral nutrition, bone marrow transplantation, patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome who require long-term chemotherapy and patients requiring long-term dialysis catheters. Tunnelled catheters were initially inserted in operating theatres by surgeons but there has been a gradual trend in many centres towards their placement by radiologists for financial and clinical reasons. There are a wide variety of available devices including tunnelled catheters, implantable ports and peripherally inserted central catheters (PICCs). The usual site of venous access for most devices is the internal jugular vein or the subclavian veins. In patients with access problems when these routes are not available alternative approaches have to be considered. This workshop will focus on the method of insertion via collateral veins in the neck and the use of external jugular veins, femoral veins, the inferior vena cava and hepatic veins. Relative advantages and disadvantages of these routes will be discussed and the incidence and management of complications.

These sequences and contrast-enhanced T1-weighted images become mandatory to differentiate diffuse neoplastic marrow infiltration from abnormally cellular albeit normal marrow. In terms of lesion characterization, MRI plays little role because MRI patterns of neoplastic marrow involvement are non-specific: focal lesions and diffuse infiltration are observed in metastates, lymphoma and multiple myeloma. However, some subtle features sometimes help in the differential diagnosis:concurrent observation of diffuse bone marrow signal alterations, focal lesions and compression fractures are indicative of myeloma; combination of bone lesions with paraspinal or pelvic tumoral lymph nodes and extra-osseous tumor spread without alteration of the bone cortices suggest lymphoma; … The radiologist must be aware of some benign conditions which may mimic tumoral lesions: benign diffuse or focal bone marrow hyperplasia, intravertebral disk herniations, acute vertebral compression fractures, infectious lesions, …. Irving; Leeds/UKIntroduction: Ultrasound was the original cross-sectional imaging technique for the examination of the abdominal contents, prior to the introduction of CT and MRI. It remains inexpensive, easily accessible and is often the best first imaging investigation for patients presenting with abdominal symptoms. Content: The indications and techniques for ultrasound of the lower abdomen, including the pelvis, will be addressed. CT anatomy and pathology of the peritoneum and small bowel with MRI correlation F. Maccioni; Rome/ITThe peritoneal cavity is a potential space contained between the parietal and visceral peritoneum. The abdominal intra-peritoneal organs are suspended and connected by several infolds of visceral peritoneum, called ligaments, mesenteries or omenta, representing a link between intraperitoneal and retroperitoneal organs and spaces. These relationships can explain the pathways of spread of many benign and malignant diseases affecting the peritoneal cavity and its organs. The adult peritoneal cavity is divided by the transverse mesocolon into two main spaces: the sovramesocolic and inframesocolic space. The embryology is the key to understanding the anatomy of the peritoneal cavity, especially of the sovramesocolic compartment. At the fifth week of fetal age, the peritoneal cavity consists of two main spaces separated by the primitive gut, attached to the anterior and posterior abdominal wall by a ventral and dorsal mesentry.The complexity of the adult sovramesocolic space derives from the development of the liver within the anterior mesentery and the growth of the spleen and pancreas in the posterior mesentery. In the sovramesocolic space, the right and left peritoneal spaces remain separated and are further subdivided in different subcompartments, four for each side. Conversely, the adult inframesocolic space is less anfractuous because the ventral mesentery reabsorbs completely, and the midgut (the small bowel) remains attached posteriorly by its dorsal mesentery, so that the right and left spaces can freely communicate across the midline. Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the anatomy of the adult sovra-and inframesocolic spaces, showing the appearance of the main ligaments, omenta and mesenteries at CT and MRI. 2. To comprehend the relationships between intra and retroperitoneal compartments. 3. To show the pathways of spread of the main pathologic benign and malignant abdominal diseases through ligaments, mesenteries and omenta. 4. To show CT and MRI features of primary and secondary peritoneal malignancies.

Grampp; Vienna/AT Basis for the diagnosis of osteoporosisis the conventional radiograph, dual-X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) (femur, lumbar spine), and quantitative computed tomography (QCT) (lumbar spine). Conventional radiographs yield a relatively low sensitivity and cannot be used as a screening method. For economical reasons and because of the low radiation dose, DXA is of the most clinical relevance. After an initial radiograph of the lumbar spine either a DXA of this region (patients up to 65 and without significant degenerative changes) or at the hip (patients above 65 or with significant degenerative changes) should be performed. In special cases or if such a device is readily available a QCT of the lumbar spine might be a first-evaluation technique. General data for the application densitometry with quantitative ultrasound (QUS) do currently not allow a general recommendation for use in diagnosis. The methods, is currently regarded as an additional technique and can be used for prescreening to identify healthy women and men. Learning Objectives:1. To get the ability in using strategies to apply the radiological methods in the primary diagnosis as well as in follow-up studies and in different patient groups.3. FIGREF20.text: CT angiography (CTA) after infusion of contrast medium allows an immediate identification of vessel occlusion of the middle cerebral artery, basilary artery and even posterior cerebral artery and will show if there is spontaneous reperfusion. CT perfusion imaging is performed by using serial and rapid CT imaging following a bolus infusion of contrast material. CT perfusion provides both anatomical and functional information in that cerebral blood volume (CBV) and the velocity of flow as mean transit time (MTT) and thereby cerebral blood flow (CBF) can be measured. The method is well validated in animal models and humans. A rise in CBV reflects an intact cerebral autoregulation and indicates functioning cerebral vessels. A drop of CBV under normal values indicates post ischemic hypoperfusion and the core of the prospective infarct. Learning Objectives:1. To comprehend the role of native CT, contrast enhanced CT, CTA and CTperfusion in acute stroke. 2. To understand the pathophysiology of hemodynamic and thrombembolic blood flow impairment. 3. To understand the concept of penumbra and tissue at risk in respect to thrombolysis. 4. To learn the guidelines and recommendations for perfusion imaging.A-158How to use MR in acute stroke I. Berry; Toulouse/FR MR in acute stroke intends to confirm the existence of a brain lesion before it becomes irreversible. Three methods can be of use: diffusion-weighted MRI (DW-MRI), perfusion-weighted MRI (PW-MRI) and MR angiography (MRA) which can be obtained in emergency with an examination duration of half an hour. DW-MRI assesses cytotoxic edema; PW-MRI, cerebral blood flow and MRA, large vessel permeability. All these pathophysiological mechanisms contributing to the constitution of parenchymal damage can be identified on a qualitative basis in emergency and quantified producing parametric imaging: i.e. apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) for DW-MRI, cerebral blood volume (CBV), flow (CBF) and mean transit time (MTT) for PW-MRI, blood velocity for MRA. These postprocessing steps are time, computer ressources and expertise demanding and correspond to a level of need different from what is applicable/desirable in emergency. On the other hand these parameters are important for research purposes, namely for the goal of reversibility threshold identification. If such thresholds prove to exist, postprocessing should, after proper evaluation, be transfered back to procedures applicable in emergency. Meanwhile the use of MRI in emergency stroke relies on depiction of hyper-intensities on DW-MRI, hyper-intensities on PW-MRI displayed at the maximum effect of a gadolinium bolus and vessel occlusions diagnosed on MRA. The empirical information for patient management is derived from the coherence between vessel occlusion and parenchymal alterations, namely diffusion/perfusion mismatch of extension. Learning Objectives:1. To understand the difference between raw image acquisition of DW-MRI, PW-MRI and parametric imaging of ADC, CBV, CBF, MTT. 2. To identify an acute stroke lesion on DW-MRI and on PF-MRI while chosing the appropriate display meeting emergency time constraints.

Vascular ultrasound serves as a decision-maker in peripheral, carotid and renal arterial disease, in detection and follow-up of arterial aneurysms and in demonstration of venous thrombosis. Follow-up after therapy is mainly accomplished by ultrasound, too. CE-MRA and CTA compete with vascular ultrasound, and the results of this competition will influence clinical decision pathways under the scope of new reimbursement strategies. This review focusses on the potential impact of new ultrasound techniques and deals with the role of signal enhancers. Transducer improvement, digital beam forming and signal processing, extended field and 3D/4D techniques, imaging modes like tissue harmonic imaging and excitation techniques (e.g., B-flow) improve resolution, spatial understanding and demonstrability. Contrast agents based on different microbubble designs are available for enhancing signals in greyscale as well as in Doppler studies. Contrast enhancers can be combined with bubblespecific modes for semi-selective demonstration of bubble location (e.g., contrast harmonic imaging).Above all, the general technical improvements of US technology helped to improve US capabilities in vascular imaging. Many new techniques as well as contrast agents are supplementary tools (sometimes toys...) in weak signal situations like in renal arteries, tight carotid stenoses and transcranial Doppler. BUT: All new tools do not reduce the main challenges in vascular ultrasound: training, standardization and establishment of cost-effective pathways for work-up of vascular disease. Kollias; Zürich/CH Anatomically, the cerebello-pontine angle (CPA) comprises the subarachnoid space between the pons, the cerebellum and the posterior surface of the petrous bone. It communicates anteriorly with the prepontine cistern, superiorly with the ambient cistern, inferiorly with the lateral cerebello-medullary cistern and laterally extends directly into the internal auditory canal. It contains the trigeminal, facial, intermediate and vestibulocochlear nerves, the peripheral loop of the AICA and the petrosal vein of Dandy. The most common pathological processes are tumors, originating from the structures located within the cistern or anatomical structures forming its boundaries. The most common are acoustic schwannomas with distant second most common the meningiomas. Epidermoids, arachnoid cysts and neurinomas of other cranial nerves are relatively rare. The CPA cistern may also be secondarily involved by intra-and extraaxial tumors originating outside the cistern such as chordomas, chondrosarcomas, paragangliomas, meningiomas of the tentorium and the foramen magnum, and exophytic gliomas of the brain stem. Metastases, particularly melanoma, within the cistern are rare. Non-tumoral pathology includes vascular lesions, such as aneurysms and arteriovenous malformations, megadolichobasilar anomaly and vascular compression of the cranial nerves. The imaging modality of choice for the evaluation of the CPA cistern is pre-and postcontrast, high resolution MRI. To become more familiar with infectious diseases of the spinal cord since they are recently better disclosed by MRI.Urolithiasis is a common problem in patients presenting to emergency departments. Radiologic imaging has always had a primary role in the work-up of these patients. Traditionally, evaluation consisted of conventional radiography (KUB) followed by intravenous urography (IVU). With the advent of ultrasonography (US) those patients who could not safely undergo IVU could be evaluated for primary or secondary (ie. hydronephrosis) signs of obstruction. In the past several years, the introduction of unenhanced spiral CT has dramatically changed the role of the various imaging techniques in evaluation of urolithiasis. In the recent literature some authors believe that it is time for IVU to retire after 70 years of good performance. However, daily practice shows that urologists still like those "old" techniques. In addition, many patients have do undergo follow-up examinations for stone treatment. Complete replacement of IVU by CT for stone evaluation would excessively increase radiation dosages applied to patients with a high probability of disease recurrence.This lecture will review the pros and cons of KUB, IVU, and ultrasound. In addition, aspects of radiation dosage, requirements for further imaging, impact on urological interventions and follow-up examinations, as well as aspects on diagnostic utility and the measured clinical outcome will be addressed. T2-weighted MRU or gadolinium-enhanced T1-weighted excretory MRU is performed. Hence, stones can only be found on MR urograms by searching for filling defects. Initial studies demonstrate that MRU may be as effective as CT in the diagnosis of ureterolithiasis, whereas data concerning the value of MRU in nephrolithiais are still missing. Apart from an obviously limited value in acute urolithiasis, MRU may be a promising alternative to CT in chronic stone disease in order to provide exact knowledge of the urinary tract anatomy without repeated radiation exposure.

Cronqvist; Lund/SE MRA and CTA are noninvasive and have, to a certain extent, replaced digital subtraction angiography (DSA) as the principal techniques in diagnostic exami-nation of the cerebral vasculature. Spiral-CTA with improved multi-detector systems offers an increased spatial resolution and reduced partial volume errors. With high field strengths, 3D time of flight (TOF) MRA allows improved depiction of small vessels due to increased SNR and longer T1 relaxation. However, CTA still requires injection of a contrast agent whereas intracranial MRA is generally used without contrast injection. CTA and MRA with source images, multiplanar reconstructions, MIP and volume rendering are almost equal to DSA to visualize aneurysms larger than 3 mm and most AVMs. CTA easily defines vascular calcifications whereas both CTA/MRA are superior to DSA for evaluation of intraluminal aneurysmal thrombosis. Contrast enhanced MRI and MRA are still favourable to delineate AVM, especially with regard to its localization and relation to surrounding anatomical structures. CTA and MRA still harbour some technical and diagnostic pitfalls that must be known by physicians using them in their daily practice. DSA is the gold standard method to evaluate cerebral circulation, flow characteristics and collateral supply especially in AVM and combined with 3D angiography is still the most sensitive technique to detect small aneurysms and vessel irregularities. CT/CTA can replace DSA in patients with acute subarachnoidal or intracerebral hemorrhage. DSA remains the method of choice whenever CTA or MRA are inconclusive or uncertain and is still mandatory in most pretreatment evaluations of AVM. Learning Objectives:1. Clinical indications for CT/CTA, MRI/MRA and DSA in patients with cerebral aneurysm or AVM. 2. How and why we select a certain technique with regard to the underlying vascular malformation. 3. Highlight some pitfalls, especially those that might be more difficult to comprehend when you do not work as a specialist in neuroradiology on a daily basis. 4. Give some idea of what can be expected in the future etc.

To identify the pro and cons of implementation and use.B. Intervention and radiotherapy: Collaboration in treatment of head and neck tumorsM. Van Zanten-Heule, T. van Ooij; Amsterdam/NL Generally, small tumours in the head and neck region are effectively treated with surgical excision and/or irradiation. The results are usually good, with relatively few long term side effects. Greatly advanced tumours (T3-T4) are more difficult to treat effectively. The tumour is either inoperable or extensive surgery with radical margins is required followed by radiation therapy. The results of this treatment can be severe mutilation and functional restrictions to speech and food intake. Following a study in the USA for patients with advanced head and neck cancer, the Netherlands Cancer Institute/Antoni van Leeuwenhoek Hospital in Amsterdam introduced this new treatment 5 years ago. The treatment is called RadPlat and consists of a combination of radiotherapy and a very high dose of intra arterial chemotherapy (cisplatin) delivered by means of interventional radiology.To ensure a smooth treatment procedure a series of steps requiring a close collaboration between the ward, the radiotherapy and the radiology department is necessary.Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the role of radiotherapy and interventional radiology in the management of T3-T4 head and neck tumours. 2. To comprehend the indications for the interventional radiological delivery of chemotherapy. 3. To become familiar with the risks of intra arterial chemotherapy administration. 4. To understand the importance of collaboration between the radiotherapy and the radiology department.A. Pitfalls in non-vascular renal interventionK.A. Hausegger; Klagenfurt/AT During this workshop pitfalls and complications which may occur during percutaneous nephrostomy (PCN), antegrade urteral stenting and treatment of urteral stenoses will be discussed. PCN can be performed under ultrasound or fluoroscopic guidance. Technical success-and complication-rate of the two different techniques is equal. Before PCN it is of paramount importance to have information of the anatomical situation. Nephroptosis and malrotation of the kidney must be known. Renal cysts may complicate PCN and may lead to misplacement of the catheter. When a fluoroscopically guided 2-step technique is used, it is advisable to leave the chiba-needle in place if the renal pelvis is punctured directly to avoid contrast medium extravasation. After puncturing the renal pelvis all catheter manipulations should be performed over stiff guide wires, which preferably are placed down in the ureter. Puncture of a dorsal calyx should be attempted if ureter manipulations and antegrade stenting is planed. If an anterior calyx is punctured, guidewire passage and catheter manipulations are more difficult due to increased angulation. During recanalization of ureter obstruction, submucosal guide wire passage or perforation may occur. Usually this has no clinical relevance as long as adequate drainage is maintained. If a JJ-ureter stent is inserted proper length measurement is essential. An ureter stent which is too long might cause urgency and dysuria. A short stent may dislodge and removal of the stent may become cumbersome. JJ-stent exchange should be performed at 3 months, forgotten stents may fracture and act as crystallization focus for urinary stone formation. TABREF53.text: In the last 10 years different percutaneous therapies have been used in the curative management of primary and secondary liver tumors in patients not suitable for surgery. The field of image-guided tumor ablation includes chemical ablation (ethanol or acetic acid) and thermal therapies, such as radiofrequency, laser, microwave, ultrasound, and cryoablation. Radiofrequency (RF) is a relatively new image-guided procedure; results are encouraging that this minimally invasive technique could assume a primary role of in the treatment management of patients with both primary and secondary liver neoplasms. In RF ablation, a current induces ionic agitation which results in frictional heat production within the tissue. This heat induces cellular death via coagulation necrosis. Different RF devices are commercially avaliable for RF. These include single tip electrodes or expandible hooks electrodes. Electrodes can be placed under US (most frequently), CT or MR guidance. Treatments are performed under consious sedation or general anesthesia. Patient selection is mandatory. Multifocal disease (n > 5), lesions adjacent to bowel loops, or patients with severe coagulopaty should be considered not suitable for treatment. Lesion size is the most important factor in determining local therapeutic efficacy. Lesions larger than 4 cm have a high probability of tumor persistence after ablation. The introduction of combined procedures such as RF+embolisation (to reduce blood flow) or RF+saline injection (to increase ionic conductivity) can achieve better results especially in large lesions. The procedure is safe and well tolerated. Major complications are rare and include peritoneal hemorrhage, neoplastic seeding, intrahepatic abscesses, and intestinal perforation. Learning Objectives:1. An understanding of radiofrequency ablation-principles, techniques and equipment and appropriate case selection. 2. An appreciation of the imaging features of RFA lesions and their follow-up with regards to local recurrence. 3. The place of combined procedures and their potential role in difficult case management.

Winkler; Stuttgart/DE Due to its capability to visualize bone, bone marrow, soft tissue and the nervous structures at the same time, high-resolution, high-contrast MR-imaging is the major tool to evaluate diseases at or within the skull base in children. Results are greatly dependent on experience and knowledge. Developmental anatomy and pathology (cartilagenous portions at early age), pediatric pathophysiology (growing, more elastic skull), complex malformations, and specific childhood diseases and tumors are differentiating features from most problems in the adult. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common malignancy involving the skull base. Imaging should reveal lesions in which biopsy is not necessary or even hazardous such as juvenile angiofibroma or nasal encephalocele. Benign conditions such as hemangioma, fibrous dysplasia, fibromatosis, plexiform neurofibroma or histiocytosis X might simulate malignancy. Specific questions are involvement of the bone marrow, vascularization, tumor spread into foramina or canals of the skull base or into the cavernous sinus. TABREF74.text: Malignant biliary obstruction:Biliary drainage is performed at the same time as a PTC. After cannulating a suitable bile duct, a catheter is manipulated across the stricture into the duodenum. Biliary drainage is achieved by placement of an internal/external catheter. The best method of palliation is provided by an internal endoprosthesis. Plastic or metallic endoprostheses may be used. Metallic stents can be placed at the same time as the biliary drainage procedure. Plastic stents because of their larger calibre, should be placed a few days after the initial drainage procedure. Randomised trials have found that metallic stents are better than plastic stents with longer patency rates and lower reintervention rates. The main complications of biliary interventions are haemorrhage, infection, stent occlusion and injury to neighbouring organs. Benign biliary obstruction: The main causes of benign biliary obstruction are stones and benign strictures. Most stones are removed endoscopically. Benign biliary strictures should be managed by endoscopic or percutaneous balloon dilation using 8 or 10 mm balloons. Clinical success of balloon dilation is up to 70% at three years follow-up. Metallic stents are not used routinely in benign disease because of high occlusion rates due to tissue hyperplasia. Learning Objectives:1. Understand the techniques for percutaneous biliary drainage and stenting. 2. Understand the merits of the use of different types of stents in malignant and benign biliary obstruction. 3. Learn about the complications of percutaneous interventions and how to deal with them.

Zanetti; Zürich/CHOptimal magnetic resonance (MR) imaging of the wrist requires a high field strength magnet and a dedicated wrist coil to achieve high-resolution images. Using current MR sequences, detailed images of articular cartilage and the supporting ligaments and tendons can be obtained. Evaluation of the triangular fibrocartilage as well as intrinsic ligaments of the wrist is substantially improved by direct MR arthrography. Fast inversion recovery sequences or T2 weighted sequences with fat suppression allow for detection of osteonecrosis and fractures, which are often radiographically occult. MR imaging also provides valuable information in the evaluation of tendons and synovium in rheumatoid arthritis. Normal variants (e.g. lunate II, carpal boss), pitfalls (e.g. pseudo-DISI), and findings with high prevalence in the asymptomatic population (e.g. TFC lesion, intercarpal ligament lesion) have to be considered in the evaluation of chronic wrist pain. Learning Objectives: 1. To know the clinical relevance of MR abnormalities in patients with chronic wrist pain. 3. To know the relevance of various anatomical factors in chronic wrist pain.
