TABREF118.text: MRI: Tougher but better?A.R. Padhani; Northwood/UK This lecture focuses on 2 aspects: the intrinsic flexibility of MRI to quantify physiological phenomena relevant to the development of angiogenesis in vivo and the challenges faced by MRI techniques if they are to become widely adopted. Both contrast medium enhanced and non-enhanced MRI techniques are available. Dynamic MRI using ECF contrast agents (DCE-MRI) is most widely used in human studies. Performance and interpretation of results can be challenging for both experts and those new to the field. Even for a single technique such as DCE-MRI, it can be difficult to make meaningful comparisons of data obtained from different imaging centres because of a lack of consensus on image acquisition protocols and analysis methods. Other challenges include data acquisition and analysis methods in body parts where there is a large degree of physiological movement, heterogeneity analysis, determining measurement error, incomplete validation and the lack of readily available analysis software. Key requirements for successful implementation for multicentre studies include adequate quality assurance and the need to comply with regulatory standards. Learning Objectives:1. To appreciate the power of MRI techniques for obtaining biological information related to tumour angiogenesis and neovasculature. 2. To compare and contrast MRI techniques in terms of their biological mechanisms, sensitivity, ability for quantification and biological validation.A B C D E F G 3.To develop an understanding of the biological meaning of kinetic parameters derived from DCE-MRI using low molecular weight, extracellular contrast agents. 4. To outline challenges that need to be overcome if MRI techniques are to become useful clinical and research tools.Antivascular cancer treatment: Angiogenesis imaging in early clinical trialsA. Dzik-Jurasz; Greenford/UK; presented by A. Padhani; Northwood/UK The inhibition of tumour related angiogenesis is currently an important therapeutic target and strategic focus for drug companies. Although in vitro and animal studies provide drug kinetics and dynamics, a drug's ultimate success depends on its efficacy, safety and disease modulation action in man. Objectives of early clinical trials include: proof of concept -ideally an objective readout of the drug's intended pharmacological action; dose optimisation; analysis of the impact of treatment on tumour progression. Additional biological data on drug action or predictive and early measures of drug response are desirable. Dynamic contrast enhanced MRI (DCE-MRI) techniques can help to assess and support these objectives non-invasively in man. There are, however, a number of challenges that must be overcome before DCE-MRI is fully implemented as a clinical and research tool. These include sequence and analysis protocol standardisation, the issue of physiological motion, validation, data presentation, heterogeneity and assessing measurement error. Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the drug industry's requirements and expectations from early clinical trials of antiangiogenesis agents. 2. To understand the challenges to DCE-MRI in assessing antiangiogenesis and the role imaging clinicians and scientists can play in this process. A. Pediatric MRI in congenital and acquired cardiovascular disease C. Holmqvist; Lund/SE; presented by A.M. Taylor; London/UK Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the complementary non-invasive method of choice to echocardiography in evaluation of congenital heart disease (CHD), avoiding invasive catheterisation. The percentage of CHD patients that are operated without cine angiography has decreased during the last ten years, even prior to open-heart surgery. Many surgical corrections are carried out as early as possible during infancy. In the majority of infants, MRI can replace catheterisation in the pre-operative evaluation. MRI has been especially useful in the preoperative evaluation of malformations of the thoracic aorta and central pulmonary vessels, and in visualization of very complex intra-cardiac malformations. Contrast-enhanced MRA (ce-MRA) is now also widely in use. MRI/MRA should also be considered the choice examination in acquired conditions, such as cardiac/pericardial masses and in arterial or venous occlusion, thrombosis or stenosis as well as in extra-thoracic vascular investigations. MRI now also permit functional evaluation of the heart as well as flow information. The medical and surgical advances including, reduced postoperative mortality, has led to an increasing number of children requiring follow-up. Post-operative anatomic evaluation and physiologic information can be obtained by MRI. In this lecture, an overview of the most useful imaging techniques for paediatric cardiovascular MRI (white blood/black blood techniques, cine imaging, ce-MRA) is presented. The possibilities for functional information including quantitative flow measurement, even in smaller children, are exemplified. Learning Objectives: 1. To learn the basic examination techniques for paediatric cardiovascular MRI and MRA. 2. To comprehend the indications, applications and limitations for cardiovascular MRI in paediatric radiology. B. Diagnosis and local staging of the primary tumor R.A. Frost; Salisbury/UKColorectal cancer (CRC) usually develops from adenomatous polyps. Its symptoms and signs overlap with benign disease, so a strategy must be used to investigate those most likely to have CRC. We use a scoring sheet for colorectal symptoms, a high score indicates a high probability of CRC. Patients with high probability are investigated by colonoscopy which has the highest sensitivity for the primary tumour, and provides histological proof. It is important that synchronous polyps are found and characterised, as the presence of adenomatous polyps elsewhere will influence how much colon is resected. Barium enema is used in patients with a lower probability of CRC. CT is utilised in several ways, ranging from unprepared abdominal CT, to full bowel preparation and the protocol of CT colonography (CTC), which has an accuracy for neoplasia approaching colonoscopy. A minority of patients with CRC present with large bowel obstruction in which unprepared CT can confirm the diagnosis, the cause and complications. We stage colon cancer with portal phase abdominal MSCT to look, not only for liver metastases, but for direct invasion into surrounding structures, to aid surgical planning. Rectal tumours, usually presenting at T2 or greater, must be staged accurately as treatment depends upon pre-operative T-stage. MRI can accurately demonstrate the relationship of the tumour to the mesorectal fascial margin (MFM). If clear, a total mesorectal excision (TME) is performed, if not clear, neo-adjuvant chemo-radiotherapy preceeds surgery. Trans-rectal ultrasound is required to identify the rarer T1 tumour which may be resected trans-anally (TEMS procedure). Learning Objectives:1. Pathways for CRC development and the impact of these on imaging methods. 2. Endosonography of rectal cancer -technique and interpretation. 3. MRI in rectal cancer -technique and interpretation.B. Distant metastases C. Bartolozzi; Pisa/ITCareful staging of the disease is a key aspect for establishing patient's prognosis and planning an appropriate treatment. Tumor staging is based on imaging examinations in combination with clinical and laboratory findings. Special attention has to be focused on detection of hepatic and pulmonary metastases. In fact, patients with limited liver or lung involvement can experience a substantial improvement in long term survival if the lesions are suitable for surgical resection or percutaneous ablation. A 5-year survival rate of approximately 20 -40% and a 5year disease-free survival rate of approximately 20 -25% can be expected in patients with liver metastases who successfully underwent resection as compared to 0% in the untreated patients. Knowledge of the exact number and location of hepatic metastatic lesions is therefore crucial for selecting the most appropriate treatment and planning the full extent of the intervention. While US is widely used as the first-line examination, spiral CT or MRI are needed for accurate pre-treatment assessment. MRI has an edge over CT, as tissue-specific MR contrast agents, including hepatobiliary agents and reticuloendothelial systemtargeted iron oxide particles, improve detection of tiny lesions. Spiral CT, however, is the modality of choice for evaluating extra-hepatic abdominal disease as well as pulmonary involvement. PET is also a promising technique for detecting distant metastases, but further investigation and standardized protocols of image acquisition and interpretation are necessary before this method can be widely used.Learning Objectives: 1. To describe staging protocols for patients with colorectal adenocarcinoma. 2. To discuss the clinical value of each imaging technique in the detection of distant metastases. 3. To report the results of comparative trials of spiral CT versus MRI with liver specific agents in the detection of hepatic metastases.C. Follow-up and recurrenceA. Guthrie; Leeds/UK 35% of patients with colorectal cancer (CRC) will develop recurrent disease. The aim of surveillance is to identify asymptomatic recurrences so as to initiate further treatment and improve survival, the assumption being that early detection of metastases or locally persistent tumour increases the likelihood of curative treatment.Theoretically a surveillance strategy could be devised on the basis of an understanding of the biology of the disease, the sensitivity of investigations employed and effectiveness of therapies available. Few randomised trials evaluating surveillance have been performed. Most of these show a trend towards increased survival in the intensively monitored groups, but are too small to have sufficient statistical power. Meta-analyses suggest intensive surveillance leads to an earlier detection of recurrence and a survival advantage.The principal questions regarding surveillance strategies remain open. The optimal method to maximise detection of curable recurrence has not been established. The costs are high and the benefits to the overall CRC population small, but a few individuals will be cured and others will have their lives extended. Learning Objectives:1. An understanding of the principles of surveillance.2. An appreciation of the evidence available that post-operative surveillance is effective for colorectal cancer. 3. To appreciate the potential importance of the multiplicity and size of pulmonary nodules in patients with known extrathoracic malignancy.The connective tissue diseases are a heterogeneous group of immunologically mediated disorders in which the lungs are an important taget organ due to its abundant connective tissue. The most common form of diffuse pulmonary lung disease in patients with collagen vascular disorders is a chronic pulmonary fibrosis indistinguishable from other causes of usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).Complications of the connective tissue diseases include esophageal dysfunctionA B C D E F G leading to recurrent aspiration and secondary infection (in scleroderma and mixed connective tissue disease), respiratory muscle weakness contributing to atelectasis and secondary infection (in systemic lupus erythematosus, polymyositis) and drug-induced lung disease (methotrexate and gold treatment in rheumatoid arthritis). Because the pathology of chronic interstitial pneumonia takes a limited number of forms, there also are a limited number of radiographic manifestations. Currently, high resolution computed tomography (HRCT) is the imaging method of choice in evaluating patients with ILD. HRCT demonstrates the presence, gross characteristics and distribution of pulmonary disease with greater sensitivity than conventional chest radiographs and thereby may improve diagnosis. Additionally, HRCT can clarify confusing radiographic findings and direct invasive diagnostic procedures. In certain clinical circumstances HRCT findings can suggest a specific diagnosis or indicate a potentially treatable disease. The radiologic manifestations of those connective tissue diseases that affect the lungs will be discussed.Learning Objectives: 1. Summarize the HRCT features in collagen vascular diseases. 2. Describe some complications associated with collagen vascular diseases. 3. Learn key points in distinguishing collagen vascular disease from other infiltrative lung diseases.Multisystem vasculitides that affect the lung are inflammatory destructive processes associated with a variable extent of infiltration by activated neutrophils, which result in necrosis and dissolution of arteriolar and venular walls. The lung interstitium is affected by the development of oedema, deposition of fibrin, neutrophilic infiltrates and eventually areas of necrosis.The development of small vessel thrombosis, organising haemorrhage, the accumulation of free parenchymal haemosiderin and haemosiderin in the alveolar spaces may, after repeated episodes of diffuse alveolar haemorrhage, lead to functional and morphologic changes, the latter being recognised by HRCT. Multisystem vasculitides that involve the lung include Wegener's granulomatosis, Churg-Strauss syndrome, Takayasu's arteritis, Behcet's disease, microscopic polyangiitis, systemic autoimmune diseases and Goodpasture's syndrome.

back_matter.text: ECR is one of the first major conferences that introduce a fully digital submission and presentation system for scientific exhibits. The benefits of the electronic posters are great: color, movies, animations, sound and true interactivity are now possible, the presentation can be archived and made available on the internet, it enables easy searching for particular topics of interest during the limited time at the conference, expensive and often time consuming printing at large format is no longer needed, and the multimedia exhibits are easily uploaded from office or home to the ECR submission website. Also the role of the jury is facilitated, as the posters can be judged securely before the start of the congress from any computer connected to the internet. Learning Objectives: 1. How to write a grant proposal

How to write a grant proposal J.F. Debatin 1 , P.M. Parizel 2 ; 1 Hamburg/DE, 2 Antwerp/BE Scientific grants are an important method for independent, original research projects to obtain financial support. The money stemming from a successful peerreviewed grant gives the recipient the independence and freedom to pursue a specific research interest, enhances credibility and prestige within the scientific community, and is instrumental for academic advancement. In this presentation, we review the elements of a good grant proposal, propose a general outline, and offer some practical tips. We provide the ground rules for submitting a scientific grant, emphasize the need for a correctly formulated hypothesis, and analyze the structure of a grant proposal (abstract, specific aims, background and significance, preliminary results, research design and methods, bibliography). Though there is no magical formula for a successful grant proposal, we hope that this presentation will show that chances for success can be improved by using a methodical approach, focussed thinking, and planning skills.

Towards an MRI characterization of individual cancers for staging, treatment selection, and monitoring response R.C. Brasch; San Francisco, CA/US A major challenge for diagnostic imaging is to better define the specific characteristics of individual tumors.Tumors sharing a particular histopathologic type may have widely divergent biological properties including molecular expression, angiogenesis status, and susceptibility to treatment. Through the use of innovative contrast enhancing pharmaceuticals, it now seems feasible to interrogate each patient's tumor, defining both functional and structural characteristics. One of the several appealing approaches now being developed for clinical use, is the use of dynamic magnetic resonance imaging combined with novel macromolecular contrast media to quantitatively assess tumor microvessels. Using computer processing of the imaging data and a relatively simple two-compartment kinetic model, it is possible to non-invasively assay the relative blood volume, microvascular endothelial permeability, and the interstitial volume of any solid tumor. The MRI permeability assay appears to be a particularly powerful biomarker, able to indicate a tumor's malignancy, its pathologic grade, its angiogenic status, and the tumor's responsiveness to drug therapy. Using MRI and macromolecular contrast media, tumor responses to treatment can be detected within hours of initiating therapy. Optimization of the dynamic MRI technique linked with the anticipated availability of new macromolecular contrast media should lead to an even greater future benefit from diagnostic imaging in cancer patients. Learning Objectives: 1. To comprehend the diagnostic benefits afforded by MRI enhanced with novel macromolecular contrast agents for the characterization of individual tumors. 2. To understand the principles of altered microvascular permeability and how abnormal permeability relates to angiogeneisis and tumor aggressiveness. 3. To learn how the effects of anti-angiogenic therapy can be monitored by macromolecular enhanced MRI.
