Lung neoplasms H.C. Steinert; Zürich/CH Integrated PET-CT imaging enables the exact matching of focal abnormalities on PET to anatomic structures on CT. Recently, it has been shown that integrated PET-CT is superior in diagnostic accuracy to CT alone and PET alone, and to visual correlation of PET and CT in T staging of patients with non-small-cell lung cancer. Without image fusion, the use of PET in T staging lung cancer is limited. Due to the exact anatomic correlation of the extent of FDG uptake, the delineation of the primary tumor can be defined precisely. Integrated PET-CT imaging is very useful for the differentiation between tumor and peritumoral atelectasis. This is particularly important for the planning of radiotherapy in patients with lung cancer associated with an atelectasis. Integrated PET-CT imaging improves the exact localization of lymph node metastases, particularly in patients with a mediastinal shift due to an atelectasis or anatomical variants. In 10-20% of patients, PET scanning detects unknown distant metastases. However, the exact localization remains unclear, especially when no morphological alterations occur on CT images. The advantage of integrated PET-CT imaging is the exact localization of a focal abnormality on PET. Recently, it has been shown that integrated PET-CT imaging is a highly valuable tool in the management of patients with SCLC, particularly for planning radiation treatment. Integrated PET-CT imaging is also an excellent method for staging patients with malignant pleural mesothelioma. With the co-registration of anatomic and metabolic information, the extent of the tumor can be more precisely defined. Learning Objectives:1. Describe the role of FDG imaging for patients with lung cancer. 2. Recognize the diagnostic advantages and limitations of fused images. 3 . Learn how to interpret PET and integrated PET-CT images. 4. Identify common pitfalls.

Abdominal tumors P.J. Ell; London/UK PET/CT is a new imaging modality. It combines the advantages of spiral CT with the metabolic mapping with PET. PET/CT permits faster imaging times. It improves lesion detectability and lesion localisation. PET/CT is a whole body imaging technique for tumour staging and re-staging. PET/CT will be progressively inserted into tumour response assessment. In abdominal cancer, much data has now accumulated in the investigation of two aspects of tumour cellular metabolism: glucose activity with labelled FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose) and cellular proliferation with labelled FLT (fluorodeoxythymidine).In this presentation, the present role and clinical value of PET/CT will be discussed. Most current clinical work is confined to FDG but there is real progress with other F-18 labelled molecules. The solution of the distribution problem of FDG, which has limited the wide applicability of clinical PET, is also the solution for the distribution of any F-18 labelled ligand. There is much hope and indeed expectation of what has been described as the most exciting imaging opportunity in molecular and nuclear medicine. In oesophageal, gastric, colorectal and pelvic neoplasias, PET/CT has now gained acceptance as a major imaging modality. In many patients first presenting with these cancers, PET/CT could indeed be the first imaging investigation of choice. In modern assessment of tumour development, it will be difficult to ignore the real merits which this new approach brings to drug efficacy studies and patient response.

Lymphoma C. Messa, S. Sironi, C. Landoni, L. Gianolli, F. Fazio; Milan/IT PET has been widely used in patients with Hodgkin disease and high-grade non Hodgkin's lymphoma, providing useful information and improving the management of these patients. The areas where PET seems to be particularly useful are in improving the accuracy of initial staging, in defining response to treatment and in refining follow-up after completion of treatment. With the introduction of PET/ CT scanners, another interesting area of application is the definition of radiotherapy planning volumes. All these indications are based on the very early metabolic alteration detectable by PET, so that disease and response to treatment can be assessed in early phase. A major potential role of PET in lymphoma is in tailoring treatment according to response both at presentation and during first-line treatment. Final goal would be to improve management of patients by identifying those who can be cured with minimal treatment and those in whom more intensive therapies are needed. The advantages of PET/CT over PET are similar to those of other tumors and are based on faster and more accurate interpretation of PET images based on the anatomical CT information. By adding CT information to PET, residual masses in regions such as the latero-cervical and abdominal areas are better delineated. Also, anatomical landmark essential for radiotherapy planning, are provided. Technique: CAS is performed with shuttle sheath, pre-dilatation or only in-stent dilatation, self-expandable stent, and cerebral protection with filters or balloons. ASA and clopidogrel are applied before, during, and after the intervention. DW MI-imaging is helpful to detect clinically silent microembolism. Results: CAS is used in symptomatic patients with a > 70% stenosis, asymptomatic patients with a > 80% stenosis. It is the preferred method after CEA, neck irradiation, radical neck dissection, tracheostoma, recurrent nerve palsy, Bechterew's disease, and extreme obesity. In a series of more than 2,200 CAS from 8/ 1984 to 7/2003 a success rate of 99% was achieved accompanied by a complication rate of stroke and death of 3.6%. From 1999 to 2003 the technical success rate remained unchanged in 826 treatments with cerebral protection, but the complication rate (1.6%) could be reduced. A death rate of 0.26%, a rate of major stroke of 0.52% and of minor stroke of 0.78% prove the efficacy of cerebral protection. The 5-year patency is 90%. Cerebral protection reduced the rate of signal-intensive spots in DW-weighted MR-imaging significantly. In all high-risk trials CAS was superior to CEA. A-271 C. Subintimal PTA J.A. Reekers; Amsterdam/NL Subintimal angioplasty, also named percutaneous intentional extraluminal recanalization (PIER), is a technique for revascularization of long superficial femoral artery and crural artery lesions. It has proven to be of value in patients with chronic critical ischeamia and/or arterial ulcers. Especially in patients which are poor surgical candidates, this technique can be of value, as the clinical result, ulcer healing and limb salvage, seems to be much higher than the true hemodynamic patency.In this workshop the technique will be demonstrated. Also the etiology of lower limb ulceration, patient selection, outcomes and the current literature will be discussed. Mistakes in interpreting computed tomographic images in children are mainly related either to artifacts induced by the scanning technique or to misinterpretation of a normal anatomical variant as pathological. The aim of this lecture is to discuss both the normal variants found in pediatric radiology practice, the common diagnostic pitfalls they create, and the sources of common artifacts associated with cross-sectional imaging. The lecture will cover thoracic and abdominal/ pelvic imaging and will attempt to provide a series of helpful guidelines which will allow the differentiation of normal variants and artifacts from important pathologic entities. Likely future developments in multi-slice imaging will be discussed, including how these may help to reduce current artifactual appearances in the CT images. However, these new techniques may simply replace current artifacts with a new generation of artifactual problems. Learning Objectives:1. To understand the mistakes commonly made in pediatric CT thoracic/abdominal/pelvic practice which are related to image artifacts and how these may be minimized. 2. To discuss the range of normal anatomic variants which are important and which give rise to misinterpretation of CT thoracic/abdominal/pelvic images. 3. To discuss how future improvements in CT imaging may circumvent the above problems but may also induce a new range of image artifacts.

C. Contrast enhancement in pediatric musculoskeletal MR imaging G.-H. Sebag; Paris/FRThe indications for contrast-enhanced MRI in the pediatric skeletal system are rapidly evolving and increasing. MRI after gadolinium administration is unique in children in that it may possible to evaluate the vascularity of the growing osteocartilaginous structures and their maturational patterns of development. The presentation will focus on practical considerations to optimize the protocol for a specific age group, anatomical location and indication in order to avoid common mistakes and mismanagement. Recognition of the maturational pattern of enhancement for a given state of development is mandatory in order to rule out pathologic processes such as ischemia, necrosis, edema, revascularization and neovascularization. Furthermore, it helps to determine the optimal timing of data acquisition with respect to contrast administration. In conclusion, only an optimized MR protocol will reliably assist in establishing the prognosis (such as a growth disorder) and in guiding the appropriate treatment in children.

B. CT and MRI in the differential diagnosis of adnexal masses R.A. Kubik-Huch; Baden/CH Carcinoma of the ovary is the third commonest tumor of the female genital tract after carcinoma of the cervix and endometrium. However, as it is usually discovered at an advanced stage, its prognosis is usually poor. Management of clinically suspected disease involves a staging laparotomy with histological confirmation of the diagnosis, identification of tumor spread and debulking prior to chemotherapy, itself usually followed by second-look laparotomy to assess the response. Prior to surgery, cross sectional imaging nowadays plays an increasing role to determine the origin of a pelvic mass (uterine vs. adnexal), to characterize the lesion (benign vs. malignant) as well as for tumor staging in case of malignancy. In patients with suspected ovarian carcinoma, CT is the modality of choice alongside transvaginal and abdominal ultrasound as it is relatively cost-effective and widely available. While MRI plays a limited role in the staging of ovarian carcinoma, it serves as an important adjunct for the characterization of sonographically indeterminate ovarian lesions since it is capable of reliably differentiating mature cystic teratoma and other benign lesions from ovarian carcinoma. Pelvic MRI is now a recognized imaging modality in the field of pelvic floor dysfunction. It allows excellent anatomical depiction of cavities and of the surrounding organs, muscles and fat. Dynamic imaging allows sequential imaging during contraction, straining and defecation.Technically examinations are performed with the patient lying supine after rectal opacification. Sequences include static T2-weighted sequences in 3 planes, allowing anatomical analysis of the pelvis compartments; and dynamic gradient echo or fast spin-echo sequences, at rest, in contraction and straining. Clinical examination can be performed at the magnet. During straining in the normal examination, the bladder neck, lower portion of the bladder and uterine cervix remain above the infrapubic-coccygeal line. Urethra and bladder shift dorsally and caudally; the rectum shifts caudally and dorsally. Angulation of the levator ani muscles is modified with a widening and lengthening of the urogenital hiatus. MRI allows assessment of pelvic muscles defects and of pelvic organ motion. It allows a classification of prolapses with regard to each pelvic compartment (cystocele, hysterocele, peritoneocele, rectocele and pelvic floor descent). Clinical examination performed at the magnet may unmask hidden prolapses, otherwise undetected. Conclusion: Dynamic MRI of the pelvic floor allows a physiopathologic approach of pelvic organs at rest and in motion. It is nowadays a useful tool in the pre-and post-operative assessment of pelvic prolapse and of its complications.

A B C D E F G Amenorrhea in the long term: The incidence of premature ovarian failure after UAE has been reported in different series, permanent or temporary amenorrhea in 14% of patients undergoing uterine fibroid embolization. The exact cause of this phenomenon is probably multifactorial and it could be due to embolization of uterine-ovarian collaterals during the procedure and considering this we should use particles bigger than 500 µm, that can not pass through the anastomoses. The failure rates reported in the literature, after UFE is between 4% and 14%. Learning Objectives: 1. To discuss the most important complications that we can find with uterine artery embolization and their management. 2. To see the failures rates of this procedure.A-308 B. Embolisation for post partum haemorrhage is safe and effective. So why isn't it used more? J.-P. Pelage; Boulogne/FR Post partum hemorrhage remains a leading cause of maternal mortality throughout the world. Uterine atony, genital tract lacerations and abnormal placentation account for the majority of cases. Atonic uterus is usually controlled using oxytocin and prostaglandin analogues. Surgical repair is effective to treat cervical tears and curettage may be sufficient to remove retained placental tissue. For patients whose clinical condition continues to deteriorate, arterial ligation or hysterectomy is often the favored treatment. However, these procedures are associated with significant failure and morbidity rates particularly in patients with coagulation disorders. The successful use of embolisation was first reported in 1979 in a patient who underwent hypogastric artery ligation and hysterectomy. Since then many reports have emphasized the advantages of embolisation over surgery. The main supply to the uterus is provided by the uterine arteries originating from the hypogastric (internal iliac) arteries. The ovarian or round ligament arteries may account for recurrence of bleeding. Selective embolisation of both uterine arteries should be performed but in case of severe vasocontriction, embolisation of the anterior division of the hypogastric arteries is safe and effective. Gelatin sponge pledgets, which provide a temporary occlusion are particularly suitable. The success rates of embolisation range between 80 and 95% to treat bleeding following cesarean section and uterine atony respectively. Pluridisciplinary management for these patients should be realized in highly specialized centers open 24 hours a day only. If applied early in the course of events, embolisation is a valuable alternative to surgery in the management of intractable postpartum hemorrhage. Uterine artery embolisation has become an increasingly used interventional radiological technique to treat symptomatic uterine fibroids. An increasing literature on the subject documents the chances of success and the associated morbidity and mortality. The literature focuses on symptomatic and radiological outcomes and most authors quote figures approaching 90% for relief of mennorrhagia, dysmennorrhoea and pressure related symptoms. In addition most authors quote figures of urgent or emergent hystectomy (hysterectomy) following the procedure between 1-2% and premature menopause between 1-2%. Most authors also discuss other side-effects including chronic discharge but there is little mention in the literaure of the impact of the procedure on sexual function. This paper will focus on this topic with the following learning objectives. Learning Objectives: 1. Short overview of the female anatomy with reference to nerve and blood supply. 2. Potential complications post UAE with respect to premature menopause. 3. Results of a postal survery (n = 120 patients post UAE greater than 6 months following the procedure) looking at sexual function and satisfaction pre and post procedure. 4. Literature review with available evidence with respect to published data on pregnancy and outcome post UAE. By the end of this presentation the audience will be better equipped to answer patients questions and concerns about sexual function post UAE. Peripheral arterial disease usually presents to a primary care physician due to reduced blood flow to the lower limbs. This produces the well-recognised clinical symptoms of intermittent claudication or critical limb ischaemia. Once the physician has identified PVD as a likely cause for the patients symptoms, then the important issues to be addressed are to confirm that PVD exists and to assess the location and severity of that disease. MR angiography, CT angiography and new directions in sonography are addressed in other sessions. There are however, a number of simple, non-invasive techniques, which can be utilised, in the office or vascular laboratory setting, to answer many of the clinical questions. These include a focused clinical examination, pedal Doppler signals, ankle: brachial indices, and toe pressures. All of these can be performed in the outpatient environment and ensure that further evaluation is effective and patient orientated. In appropriate circumstances further noninvasive investigation may be performed in the vascular laboratory including exercising testing and duplex ultrasound. The appropriate equipment required for, and its optimal use depend on a sound understanding of the role and limitations of each technique. If used appropriately, judicious use of scarce resources of more complex investigations can be achieved, and patients given a reasonably accurate indication of their disease and its likely prognosis. In view of the significant legal and social implications of diagnosing non-accidental injury (NAI) in a child it is important that radiologists are aware of the potential diagnostic problems that can occur. This lecture will highlight the need for appropriate radiographs of the skeleton which must be reported in the correct clinical context. The importance of a full clinical history when dealing with potential nonaccidental injuries will be discussed. The role of the radiologist working as part of a multi-disciplinary team will be emphasised. The factors that differentiate accidental from non-accidental injury will be discussed along with the normal variants that may be confused with NAI. The radiological features of other diseases that can cause some confusion with NAI will be shown, including rickets, scurvy, Caffey's disease, infection as well as malignancy. The ability to remember and recognise more unusual fractures and skeletal injuries that occur in child abuse will be discussed. This lecture will give an overview of the radiological features of both the normal and pathological conditions that cause confusion when the diagnosis of non-accidental injury is considered. Childhood and adolescence are the ages of predilection for both primary bone tumours and osteomyelitis. Clearly, it is important not to underdiagnose a malignant bone tumour as an infection or, vice versa, overdiagnose osteomyelitis as a tumour. Incorrect diagnosis can lead to inappropriate management and a potentially disastrous outcome for the patient. Unfortunately, the clinical presentation for the two conditions can be remarkably similar. There is, therefore, a heavy reliance on imaging to help distinguish between these two entities. The purpose of this presentation is to highlight those imaging features, with particular emphasis on radiography and MR imaging, that help establish the correct diagnosis. These include the rapidity of onset of bone changes, growth plate involvement, pattern of periosteal new bone formation, cortical breaching, distribution of soft tissue extension, proportion of marrow oedema and the "penumbra sign" in a bone abscess. Where diagnostic doubt remains then an old adage applies recommending biopsy of suspected infection and culture of suspected tumour. Any biopsy/drainage should be positioned in such a manner as not to prejudice future surgery in case tumour is subsequently proven. Learning Objectives:1. To recognise differences in the rapidity of onset of bone changes between tumour and infection. 2. To identify differences in growth plate involvement between tumour and infection. 3. To identify differences in signal characteristics and perilesional oedema between tumour and infection. 4. To identify differences in cortical destruction and soft tissue extension between tumour and infection. In many CT investigations, MPR is becoming an imaging routine. Evidently, MPR has improved with the introduction of multi-slice CT (MSCT) and the associated computer technology. However, the effectiveness of the method is highly radiographer-dependant. Consequently the radiographer ought to be aware of the principles and the factors influencing MPR. It is essential that the appropriate acquisition technique be selected with emphasis given to image quality and dose consideration preceding the commencement of the examination. On occasion MPR is carried out arbitrarily. It is not always clearly indicated and thus, its clinical applications are somewhat limited. The learning outcome of this course will be to familiarize the radiographer with dedicated acquisition methods required for MPR with concern to CT dose index (CTDI). This will be accomplished by comparing helical CT scanning techniques used to produce MPR images of analogous regions. In addition, the clinical applications described in this presentation will mainly involve orthopaedic and surgical cases due to their increased accessibility. Furthermore to comprehend the benefits of MPR the following issues will be addressed: How accurate and reliable is MPR? Does MPR reduce dose without compromising image quality? How do slice thickness and table increment affect MPR? When is MPR indicated?In conclusion, the general purpose of this lecture will be to provoke radiographers in performing such reconstruction techniques effectively. The analysis of medical images plays an increasingly important role in many clinical applications. Different imaging modalities provide anatomical information about the underlying tissues such as the X-ray attenuation coefficient from X-ray computed tomography (CT) and proton density or proton relaxation times from magnetic resonance (MR) imaging. The images allow clinicians to gather information about the size, shape and spatial relationship between anatomical structures and any pathology, if present. Other imaging modalities provide functional information such as the blood flow or glucose metabolism from positron emission tomography (PET) or single-photon emission tomography (SPECT), and permit clinicians to study the relationship between anatomy and physiology. Finally, histological images provide another important source of information which depicts structures at a microscopic level of resolution. In recent years, there has been a rapidly growing demand for the automated combination of these different sources of information. The fusion of these images is important in a number of applications such as diagnosis, therapy and monitoring of disease. However, this integration requires a registration step which maps the images in a common space. Recent breakthroughs have led to the development of very robust and accurate registration algorithms. The purpose of this talk is to give a comprehensive overview of existing techniques for medical image registration. We will also give a step-by-step description of the design of registration algorithms and their basic components for specific applications.

Over the last decade, image registration has emerged as an extremely successful and powerful tool in medical imaging finding a wide range of medical applications. This talk will explore how the development of this technology impacted on these applications. In the early 1990's most applications were being built around multi-modal imaging in which complimentary information was combined to provide synergy between two (or more) imaging modalities. Examples include the combination of structural information from MR with the functional information available at lower spatial resolution from PET or SPECT. As the technology became more advanced, very accurate alignment of intra-modality data became feasible. This allowed subtle temporal changes in structure or function to be analysed. Over short time intervals image registration, for example, improves image alignment in functional MR studies and over long time intervals allows highly accurate detection of cerebral atrophy. Image registration, in this case to the physical space of the patient in the operating room, is the key enabling technology in image-guided surgery. All these applications were built on rigid body registration technologies. Non-rigid registration, in which one image is warped or morphed into the space of another, has more recently found wide ranging applications, from the measurement (as opposed to detection) of change, to the generation of atlases and the propagation of segmentation in the automated interpretation of images. The application and interpretation of non-rigid registration raises important issues related to definitions of spatial correspondence and homology, but, with this proviso, provides an extremely powerful tool for image analysis. Applications include accurate measurement of tissue growth and destruction in the monitoring of therapy and the progression of disease. This achieved by analysis of the deformation fields produced by the non-rigid registration. Atlases can be built from large numbers of example images that have been aligned and the statistics of the resulting deformation models can be used to build statistical shape models. These models can then be used to propagate organ outlines to improve measurements of size and shape. Learning Objectives: 1. To learn how to carry out very precise measurements of change, growth, atrophy. 2. To understand how to apply image registration in motion analysis. 3. To understand how to apply image registration in shape modelling, atlas generation and segmentation propagation. 4. To understand how to use image registration in image guided interventions. 5. To understand how to use image registration in multi-modality imaging.
back_matter.section: A-318 B. Applications D. Hawkes; London/UK

back_matter.text: A. Todd-Pokropek; London/UK Image registration techniques require validation, which implies the availability of a gold standard. For rigid registration this then permits the definition of a target registration error, and a number of successful evaluations of rigid registration techniques have been completed. Non-rigid registration includes a model of interpolation and cannot be evaluated in such a simple manner. We are interested in the accuracy of registration at all points in image space, but "weighed" by the clinical objective to be achieved. Non-rigid registration must also include a model of the process of deformation (for example amodel of tissue characteristics) and can be divided into spatial deformation and material transport. It is then possible to define the registration in terms of the deformation vector field and transport field, where some methods exist for their assessment. In general, a suitable strategy for validation of such methods starts by using real clinical data and deforming it, for example using a finite element (tissue based) method. The accuracy of restoring the data back to its undeformed state provides a baseline for evaluation, although the use of circular methods (where the forward and reverse operations match) must be avoided. Finally clinical trials are required to confirm this validation on real clinical data for real applications. Learning Objectives:1. To enable the understanding of the processes of rigid and non-rigid registration, of constraints such as diffeomorphism and consistency, and the choice of various particularities of different methods as appropriate for different clinical applications. 2. To understand the process of validation of rigid registration and strategies for use for non-rigid registration. 3. To become familiar with the use of and the limitations of such techniques.

The Globe The concept of molecular imaging has gained increasing interest and tremendous developments over the last few years. A simple definition is not yet established, but molecular imaging covers "imaging of physiological or pathological processes at a cellular or subcellular level". It covers imaging of gene expression, enzyme activity, cell receptor imaging, cell trafficking, but also the consequences of these cellular events at the organ level, like angiogenesis and early cancer detection. Current applications of molecular imaging are being developed in the small animal because of the numerous disease models available in mice, and the technical developments of machines dedicated for small animal (micro PET, micro CT, micro MRI, optical imaging devices). Hence, compared to traditional specialties in radiology, molecular imaging covers a wide area of techniques, specific probes and applications. This large concept has lead to confusion and difficulties to understand the exact place and potential overlap of molecular imaging with nuclear medicine or traditional imaging techniques based mainly on anatomical or functional findings. The aim of this state of the art symposium is to be an update for general radiologists who want to know what is beyond the phrase "molecular imaging" and to have a clear view of the current diagnostic tools availables in animals and potential or current clinical applications in the future. Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the scope of molecular imaging. 2. To understand that molecular imaging covers several imaging techniques with corresponding contrast agents or probes. 3. To understand the in vivo applications of molecular imaging in small animals using dedicated machines. 4. To understand the potential clinical applications in humans of receptor imaging with PET, cellular imaging with MRI, and gene or enzyme expression with optical imaging.

Scope of molecular imaging, from receptor imaging to imaging the gene P. Reimer; Karlsruhe/DE Our current assessment of disease is largely based on anatomic changes, or more recently in specialized applications, physiologic changes that are late manifestations of the molecular changes that truly underlie disease. Much research attention has been directed towards understanding the cellular and molecular mechanisms of diseases. Although there still remains a gap between basic science and clinical imaging applications, this gap is closing. The transition of these novel methods into clinical practice is on the horizon and to expected to have direct impact on patient care within 5-15 years. In radiology we are often not aware of the fact that certain imaging techniques that may be defined as "molecular" were developed decades ago, such as receptor imaging with nuclear techniques. Furthermore, already approved X-ray or MR contrast agents allow for an assessment of angiogenesis or exhibit cell specific uptake via surface receptors. Sophisticated computer analysis or the development of cell specific contrast agents, which took place especially with the development for MRI within pharmaceutical programs, stimulated some of these already existing tools. On the research side, an entire industry has developed that is aimed at speeding up molecular research and drug discovery. Radiology has focused on biomedical engineering and computing. Today's imaging systems are markedly improved in terms of resolution and speed as compared with those of only a few years ago. Imaging technology is at a stage where imaging can occur at near micrometer resolution, and concomitant acquisition of functional and physiologic information is possible.Learning Objectives: 1. To describe the way from anatomic imaging to physiologic imaging at a cellular level. 2. To learn about existing clinical applications that may be defined as "molecular". 3. To understand some of the research about cellular and molecular mechanisms of diseases.

A. Jackson; Manchester/UK Recognition of the importance of the angiogenic process in a wide range of diseases, most especially cancer, has led to the development of novel imaging techniques to study the angiogenic process. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is widely available in most clinical centres and, since it is free from ionizing radiation, it can be used repeatedly for sequential monitoring of disease progress or therapeutic response. The major challenges facing investigators have related to the development of reproducible quantitative imaging techniques for use in clinical trials. The most widely used approach uses dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI where the progression of signal changes following an injection of contrast agent are used to derive information about the microvasculature. Application of analysis techniques which use pharmacokinetic models of contrast agent distribution allow calculation of a wide range of quantified descriptive parameters which reflect local vascular density, the size of the interstitial space, the speed of passage of blood through the tissue, the absolute blood flow, the capillary endothelial permeability and the physiological reactivity of the neoangiogenic vessels. This talk will describe the common approaches to quantitative imaging of angiogenic tissue and illustrate the application of these techniques in clinical trials.

Cellular imaging O. Clément; Paris/FR Cellular imaging covers the visualization of specific cells in living organisms. Imaging of normal endogenous cells is interesting for the understanding of immune response in ischemic, inflammatory or tumorous processes. Imaging of abnormal endogenous cells corresponds, for example, to early cancer detection. Finally, imaging the fate and homing of exogenous injected cells could be of great help in the development of human cell therapy of numerous diseases. Different techniques can be applied for cellular imaging in vivo: fluorescence or bioluminescence, but with a low in depth-detection for human applications; radioisotope labeling, but with a poor spatial resolution; MRI with superparamagnetic probes. The aim of this presentation is to review the different techniques, with an emphasis on MRI which allies a high spatial resolution and a good sensitivity to contrast agents at high fields. The different superparamagnetic markers available for cell labeling will be detailed: commercial particles with or without the use of a transfection agent (Endorem®, Sinerem®, Resovist®); facilitated endocytosis with a receptor or translocation peptide (CLIO-TAT); anionic particles for non-specific cell labelling. The influence of cell division, site of injection, magnetic field strength and iron load will be discussed for the efficacy of the method. Several diagnostic applications will be illustrated in the following areas: macrophage imaging; imaging of stroke; imaging of diabetes; imaging of the antitumor response; imaging of cellular therapy of myocardial infarction. Learning Objectives: 1. To understand the scope of cellular imaging. 2. To understand the different imaging techniques available for cellular imaging in vivo. 3. To know the different magnetic particles and techniques used for cell labelling. 4. To understand the potential clinical diagnostic applications of cellular imaging in the inflammatory response and for cell therapy. 5. To understand the technical prerequisites for cellular imaging with MRI, in terms of cell labelling and magnetic field strength.Tissue visualization with light is probably the most common imaging practice in medicine and medical research. Historically, the visual inspection of a patient or the observation of tissues using optical microscopes has been widely used to assess structure and function. Those two examples use the human retina as the recording medium. Generally, medical optical imaging is a large set of imaging technologies that use light from the ultraviolet (UV) to the infrared (IR) region to image tissue optical characteristics. Light-tissue interactions offer wavelength dependent contrast with rich diagnostic potential. This presentation reviews the capacity of optical imaging to resolve functional and molecular characteristics of tissue. We focus on recent developments in optical imaging that allow imaging of superficial and deeper tissues yielding quantified information. These technological advances allow the non-invasive, in-vivo quantification of oxygenated and deoxygenated hemoglobin and of appropriate contrast agents that can target physiological and molecular function. Application in imaging breast cancer, motor cortex activation and the exercising muscle are presented. The capacity to quantitatively resolve fluorescent probes with high molecular specificity and several centimeters deep in tissues is showcased. Current progress with tomographic imaging of enzyme up-regulation, induced apoptosis and gene-expression in intact animals is presented. Limitations of the technology are also discussed. We conclude on the future clinical applicability of optical imaging methods. Learning Objectives:1. This lecture is to serve as an introduction to optical imaging and the potential for clinical use. First, it will review the basic physics of light propagation into tissue and describe fundamental contrast mechanisms of light tissue interactions. 2. Examples from everyday experience will be given. Then, reflectance imaging, trans-illumination imaging and optical tomography will be reviewed. Advantages, limitations and the usability of these technologies will be discussed. 3. Imaging of intrinsic contrast and of extrinsically administered contrast will be showcased. Special focus will be given to fluorescence imaging and tomography as it pertains to imaging molecular function using targeted fluorochromes. Finally possible clinical applications will be briefly reviewed. The most common cause for a neonatal abdominal mass is hydronephrosis. Overall, an underlying ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, posterior urethral valve, and ectopic ureterocele are responsible about 20% of the time. Prune-belly (Eagle-Barrett) syndrome and ureterovesical junction (UVJ) obstruction account for another 20%. However, hydronephrosis is not only caused by obstruction. Vesico ureteral reflux (VUR) accounts for another 20%, and polyuria and urinary sepsis may also cause dilatation of the urinary tract. In the neonatal age group, hydronephrosis is often diagnosed prenatally. If the degree of ureteropelvic dilatation is moderate to severe, it may persist after birth and necessitate further evaluation (by VCUG) in about 50% of neonates. In mild cases, prenatal hydronephrosis disappears, probably related to the child's emergence from the special environment of the uterus (perhaps from gravity or improved GFR). Evaluation and follow-up by US are usually sufficient for a month or two; after such time, a VCUG may be needed to exclude VUR as the underlying cause. The characterisation of prenatal hydronephrosis is difficult and not very reliable. Progressive hydronephrosis is usually caused by an obstruction, varying hydronephrosis may be due to VUR. Imaging strategies current in 2004 will be highlighted for each of the above. Learning Objectives:1. To comprehend the indications for pre and postnatal imaging of the urinary tract. 2. To understand the role of imaging in the management of the dilated upper urinary tract in infants and newborns. 3. To be able to assist the clinician in effectively and practically developing therapeutic intervention if needed.A-332 C. Imaging in delayed menarche M. Riccabona; Graz/AT Objective: To describe the most common conditions associated with delayed menarche and pubarche with its imaging implications. Method: Besides a list of the various diseases and reasons for a delayed menarche the applicable imaging modalities are presented and discussed. Conventional plain films are used for assessment of bone age and skeletal growth retardation. Ultrasound (US) at present is the first line abdominal study tool, whereas MRI is used for neuro-imaging (in case of suspected hormonal disturbances related to cerebral tumours etc.) and promoted for the imaging of complex abdominal disease (e.g. hormonal active tumours of the various glands, significant or complex malformations of the inner genitalia etc). Due to the relatively high radiation burden CT indications have decreased, and fluoroscopy is restricted to the rare case of complex genital malformation that need genitography -however, these conditions are usually diagnosed earlier in infancy.Conclusion: Imaging plays a relatively minor role in evaluating patients with delayed menarche; many conditions are properly recognised and diagnosed or ruled out clinically or with various laboratory, hormonal, or genetic studies. However, if either hormonal gland pathology (such as tumours or hyerplasia) with secondary hormonal dysfunction or significant genital malformation are on the list, imaging -mainly consisting of US and MRI -is indicated and should be performed appropriately and skilfully. Learning Objectives: 1. To familiarise the pediatric radiologist with this new field when dealing with adolescent patients, who at least in some countries are more and more directed to paediatric hospitals. 2. To know the most important conditions associated with delayed menarche. 3. To list the potential imaging tools, including modern imaging techniques such as MRI and 3D US. 4. To demonstrate the most important imaging findings in patients with delayed menarche. 5. To suggest an imaging algorithm for evaluating boys and girls. 6. To discuss the restrictions, pitfalls and differential diagnoses that impact imaging findings and algorithms. Post-processing of digital images is the first step following image acquisition. It can start with 2D multiplanar reformations along three orthogonal axes and on oblique planes, followed by generation of 3D images, using both surface and volume rendering algorithms. With surface rendering, following the choice of an adequate threshold value, all the pixels other than this value are automatically removed. Contiguous pixels at the boundary of a predefined threshold value are modeled as surfaces. Computer-produced imaginary sources of illumination depict surface reflections that are encoded in the image gray scale.With volume rendering, more flexible management of 3D datasets is possible, with generation of surface views (similar to surface rendering), 3D models, and tissue transition projection images, which resemble a "double contrast" conventional X-ray study. The major advantage of volume rendering is that the entire dataset is preserved, with either no or very limited data segmentation, and tissue reconstruction is obtained using different opacity levels.Using both surface and volume rendering algorithms, virtual endoscopic images resembling conventional endoscopic views can be generated. Color is assigned to simulate expected normal tissue color in vivo. In addition, "fly through" sequences within the lumen can be produced by automatically creating a "flight path"; automatic centering as well as auto-navigation systems help virtual endoscopist in image analysis. More recently, image data can be displayed using newly generated 3D views (i.e., "mercator projection") or different rendering algorithm (i.e., "virtual dissection"). Computer-aided detection (CAD) has been for used now for many years in the evaluation of mammography with very good results and time saving especially in screening tests. The recent development and improvement of other diagnostic modalities have significantly improved image quality expanding non invasive diagnostic imaging to other body fields. In particular computed tomography is the modality that has undergone the greatest developments in the past five years, with the introduction of the multi-detector row technology. Several other problems have nevertheless to be faced that particularly concern the large number of images to be evaluated and the very small details to be identified. The recent CT developments have also introduced its applicability as screening modality also in other fields, such as the chest (lung cancer) and the colon (colo-rectal carcinoma). New systems for computer aided detection of focal and diffuse disease have therefore been developed or are under investigation with the purpose to provide an aid to radiologists that now have to face a greater amount of data and information. CAD systems now allow not only identification of nodulary lesions but also their 3D display, differentiation and relationships with normal structures. The typical examples are nodules in the lung with a greater number of screening projects in at risk population and polypoid lesions in the colon. Ultrasound is the longest established of the cross sectional imaging techniques and remains the most frequently requested. In honour of Anne whose professional base was Glasgow, the development of ultrasound in the UK will be traced from its clinical beginnings in gynaecology and obstetrics. The use of bi-stable static systems and then, the early grey scale and real time machines will be described and illustrated. To put this in context the current status in a number of clinical areas will be highlighted briefly including in paediatrics, breast assessment, in evaluation of the abdomen and in the expanding range of musculo-skeletal and superficial applications. The dynamic interactive nature of ultrasound will be emphasised combined with the central role micro bubble contrast agents now have in evaluation of the liver, after a long development and evaluation period.The final issue to be addressed will be the differing ways in which ultrasound is used in practice. It may be a standardised examination by a sonographer or as a focused clinical examination by a specialist, or as a screening examination prior to CT/MR. The equipment available will significantly impact on this -portable or high end. Ultrasound has the best inherent resolution of all the imaging modalities and so full advantage should be taken to optimise this asset. In the past few years there has been a rapid improvement in computer technology. Also high power computers have become generally available. Subsequently, the way of presenting scientific data has changed dramatically.In the past 5 years scientific slide presentations have been replaced completely by digital PowerPoint presentations, and instead of "conventional" scientific posters electronic exhibits will be used. Presenting data electronically puts an extra demand on the authors. They have to adapt to these new techniques, and must find a way in using them efficiently.In this course guidelines will be presented on how to make an electronic exhibit, how to make, and how to present a professional digital presentation.

A. The winning exhibit: How to make an electronic scientific poster A. Gangi 1 , S. Guth 2 ; 1 Strasbourg/FR, 2 Illkirch/FR Purpose: To deliver the knowledge for realization of an electronic poster in html. Abstract: After a short introduction about the html language standards, objects and image format, we will deliver the knowledge needed to write an electronic poster with EPOS focusing on image and movie management. EPOS is a PHP based application server. It is a good solution for publishing on the Internet, as physicians who are not used to publishing web content are able to produce high quality web pages with it quickly, efficiently and without long learning process. Epos is a so called "W.Y.S.W.Y.G." html editor: W.Y.S.W.Y.G. means What You See is What You Get, it is the easiest and fastest way to edit html pages without having to know the html code language. We will explain how to write an electronic presentation with this tool, taking as example our ECR 2004 electronic posters. Conclusion: It can be very easy to realize a simple electronic presentation in html with EPOS; advanced design, database connectivity and some web-contents need more advanced techniques. Going from slides to a digital power point presentation is a dramatic change. Instead of double projection there is single projection, all kind of animation effects both for text and figures can be applied, subsequent images can merge into each other, movies and sound can be integrated, and changing from slide to slide also can be done with some kind of effect. In addition, preparing a digital presentation paper allows the author to do last minute changes.This part of the course will focus on how one can make a professional digital PowerPoint presentation. First, it will be explain how one can use the most important features of the Pow-erPoint program. Second, pitfalls like too many disturbing effects, the wrong type and colour of fonts, the wrong format of images, or wrong handling of movies will be illustrated. Also hardware, like the laptop/PC remote control mouse and the integrated use of other programs -like MPR/MIP -will be discussed. Finally, some important practical tips will be given, which can be used directly before or during the presentation. A-344 C. Scientific papers: How to get your message over and not be a bore! R. Godwin; Bury St. Edmunds/UKThe differential diagnosis of the acute abdomen in childhood varies with the age of the child. The clinical team will be able to make a confident diagnosis on the basis of age, presenting history and clinical examination without the need for radiological investigation in many cases. In other situations further imaging may be helpful in determining whether surgical intervention is necessary. With increasing use of CT scanning in the evaluation of the acute abdomen in adults, there is an increasing tendency to dismiss the unique value of ultrasound scanning (US) in children and perform a CT scan. In many cases, CT is unnecessary. Young children often have little body fat making interpretation of bowel pathology on CT more difficult than in adults. By paying meticulous attention to ultrasound technique combined with appropriate clinical knowledge, US can often answer the clinical question without the need to expose the child to relatively high doses of ionising radiation or the discomfort and potential risks associated with the administration of contrast media. This paper will review the common causes of the acute abdomen concentrating on the imaging in the toddler and older child presenting with a possible diagnosis of acute appendicitis. The US features in appendicitis and a number of other less frequently encountered conditions will be highlighted. Some of the pitfalls and limitations of US in the diagnosis of the acute abdomen will be discussed, and attention drawn to situations where CT scanning may be found to be helpful or even essential. The tumorsize is recorded as one of multiple prognostic data of breast carcinoma. Gold standard is the measurement on the excised specimen and that obtained on histological preparation. The invasive part, accompanying intraductal components, multifocal sattelites und multizentric growth have to be documented if present. The nearest distance of tumorous spread towards the excision margin may be important in determining the risk of recurrance. Preoperative imaging is therefore essential for the surgeon's choice on an optimal pathway of excision. In this field mammography, ultrasound and magnetic resonance have specific strengths and limitations in cancer visualization. Since the methods provide complementary tissue information, a multimodal approach will give best results, even though in many cases one method alone presents already all diagnostic information which will not be gained by the others. Parameters affecting the diagnostic value are: tumor size, histomorphological entity, macroscopic growth pattern, vascularity, presence of microcalcifications and tissue composition of the surrounding tissue. Major imaging differences become apparent in the evaluation of tiny tumors and the estimation of potentially extensive intraductal component in invasive (EIC) or in situ carcinoma (DCIS). Postoperative specimen sonography and/or thin sectioning with consecutive specimen radiography are helpful tools in the interdisciplinary approach on the evaluation of the "real" tumor size. Both methods invaluably assist the pathologist in the assessment of the specimen's margins. Vessel density, permeability and perfusion charcteristics differ from benign to malignant lesions. With upcoming contrast agents further tumor charcteristics may be evaluated by Doppler sonography and contrast-enhanced MRI. Learning Objectives: 1. Discuss which is the real size of breast cancer, including multifocality and multicentricity. 2. Discuss the potential of the imaging methods in assessing the "useful" tumoral size. 3. Discuss the vascularity of breast cancer as assessed by non radiological and imaging methods.A-354 C. Nodal invasion G. Rizzatto; Gorizia/ITThe principal route whereby most carcinomas migrate to distant tissues is via the lymphatics. Therefore nodal invasion is a very important determinant in breast staging. This evaluation is mostly based on the sentinel node (SLN) concept: the efferent lymphatic channel draining a primary tumor leads directly to the first SLN in the regional lymphatic basin.To better detect the SLN the use of a radiolabeled colloid at preoperative lymphoscintigraphy and intraoperative detection with gamma-ray detection probe have been incorporated into the traditional blue dye protocol. Actually this is the gold standard with a technical success rate of 88%, sensitivity of 93% and accuracy of 97%. Based on these excellent results many centers perform the axillary dissection only if sentinel nodes are not found or if positive nodes are found at physical examination.Incorporating ultrasound in the preoperative evaluation of nodal chains may avoid SLN procedure in over 20% clinically node-negative patients. Contrast agents allow perfusional studies that increase the sensitivity for small nodal metastases and allow useful monitoring in locally advanced breast cancers. Recent studies show interesting potentials also for PET and MR lymphography.In the near future nodal staging will include also molecular imaging with optical and near-infrared probes. Since its introduction, CT angiography has been an excellent clinical tool for evaluating thoracic aortic diseases. Multislice scanning has now made it possible to improve spatial resolution and, at the same time, include the abdomen into the evaluation. Fast retrospective ECG gating or prospective triggering suppress pulsation effects and can be considered in patients with suspected type A aortic dissections. Thin-section imaging is less important for the aorta than for evaluation of its side branches, especially in aortic dissections or aortitis. The presentation will discuss how the timing of contrast administration has to be adapted with faster scanners. The course will review the most critical question for aortic dissection, aortic aneurysm, aortic rupture as well as aortitis. Because of its speed, ease and diagnostic yield, multislice CTA is rapidly becoming the gold standard for the evaluation of the thoracoabdominal aorta. In young patients (radiation exposure) and in patients with impaired renal function, however, MRA should be preferred. Aggressive lesions encompass a wide spectrum of pathologies, these can be preliminarly classified as infectious or non-infectious conditions. Mycosis is the most common infectious lesion, manifesting in different forms, mainly depending on the host's immune system. Both invasive forms (most common in immunocompromised patients) and non-invasive forms (namely allergic fungal sinusitis and mycetoma) are described. Non-infectious aggressive lesions include granulomatous inflammatory diseases such as Wegener's granulomatosis and sarcoidosis. Both these may affect the paranasal area as an isolated manifestation or as a localization of a systemic disease. Chronic inhalation of cocaine also results in necrotizing vasculitis causing mucosal changes and wide bone erosions, often hard to differentiate from Wegener granulomatosis, even at pathology. Inverted papilloma is the most common benign tumor, arising from the lateral nasal wall and middle meatus. It is characterized by high recurrence rate and it may be associated with epithelial malignancies (5-8%). Vascular lesions include juvenile angiofibroma, angiomatous polyp, cavernous and globular capillary haemangioma. Imaging offers several clues for the differential diagnosis and to plan adequate treatment. Less common benign lesions include neurogenic tumors (schwannoma, neurofibroma), neuroendocrine tumors (paraganglioma), and mesenchymal lesions (leyomioma, non-ossifying fibroma). The DICOM (Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine) committee has approved in 2000 a new supplement called "Structured Reporting", which introduces generic objects for representing structured reports. This specification covers a wide spectrum of reports, from very basic free text documents with a few relevant images, up to highly structured documents including coded entries, and measurements derived from image data. We will first review the motivations which triggered the works on structured reports. Then, we will explain the "SR tree", a hierarchical structure that was defined to organize this information: the various kinds of nodes (called "content items"), as well as the meaning of the various relationships types connecting the parent to the child nodes, etc. Examples from the radiological domain will be provided. The notion of "templates", which are models of the content of a particular category of reports, will be briefly described.The importance of DICOM SR will be discussed, with regards to: (1) its industrial impact, especially in the context of the IHE (Integrating the Healthcare Enterprise) initiative, (2) The Clinical Document Architecture (CDA) is an HL7 standard for structuring clinical documents. It uses XML as the representation and storage format. CDA documents consist of header and body. The header contains the structured administrative information required in health care documents, the body the clinical information. CDA has a three level architecture dealing with the granularity of the structured clinical information. In level 1 the header is structured only, the body consists of textual data without markup and/or non textual data. In level 2 also the body is roughly structured and has in particular headings with standardized markup. In level 3 markup is used to specify details of the medical data. Release 1 of CDA is already ANSI approved. This release is mainly dealing with the header structure and provides only some structure elements of the body. It is already used in several international CDA projects and becomes more and more accepted as the standard of health care documents. Release 2 is currently in the HL7 balloting process. It is closely related to the HL7 Reference Information Model (RIM) and is dealing with the structured markup of detailed clinical data. RIM clones are used to define the clinical content of documents. CDA could as well be used to represent the content of radiology documents. Available examples will be explained. It can also be applied as an appropriate format for structured reporting of radiology documents. Relationships between both standards will be shown and possible solutions demonstrated. Learning Objectives:Participants of the session will understand: 1. The structure of the Clinical Document Archicture (CDA). 2. The structure and content of the CDA header.3. The different approaches to structure the body of CDA documents. 4. The applicability of the CDA standard for structuring radiology reports. 5. The relationahip to DICOM Structured Reporting Participants will be able to apply the CDA in their own environment.

The role of the interventional radiologist starts soon after fistula creation. From the 3 rd week after creation surgery, any clinical suspicion of delay in maturation should be imaged rapidly. An underlying stenosis is unmasked in all cases and is amenable to percutaneous dilatation in the vast majority of cases. The initial success rate of the endovascular approach is very high and the long-term salvage rate can reach 90% at 1 year. In mature fistulas, it must be borne in mind that the results of percutaneous dilatation are very much operator-dependent. This apparently simple, minimally invasive, procedure provides conflicting results because inexperienced operators frequently either underdilate stenoses that should be treated aggressively or dilate stenoses that are contraindications to any treatment because of underlying excessively high flow (elbow fistulas) or precarious arterial supply to the hand (diabetics, elderly), or simply because these stenoses would never threaten fistula patency. The largest series published to date showed that the outcome of native forearm fistulas after either dilatation or declotting is much better that of upper arm fistulas, which is better than prosthetic grafts. Indications for stent placement must be limited to acute dilatation-induced ruptures that are not controlled by reasonably long low-pressure balloon tamponade and to clearly insufficient results of dilatation (central veins and upper arm fistulas). This means that stents should never be placed in forearm fistulas, except for rupture control, since residual stenosis after dilatation in the forearm is always the consequence of the use of a balloon of insufficient diameter. Percutaneous angioplasty has been an effective technique in relieving central venous stenoses with technical success rates of 82% to 94%. The technique is simple with a very low morbidity. There are however limitations in the technique as certain types of lesions do not respond well to angioplasty alone. These include lesions with elastic recoil, kinking or rigid concentric stenoses. The primary patency after angioplasty is also limited with about 80% of patients with successful angioplasty requiring reinterventions at a mean of 7.5 months. Stents have therefore been utilised to address some of the limitations of angioplasty but their definitive role have still not been fully defined. Although stents can address the immediate problem of poor angioplasty response, the stented segment of vein is still very vulnerable to initimal hyperplasia. Primary patency after stenting is not very much better compared to angioplasty alone and stents do add additional cost to the procedure. However, reintervention after stenting has been noted to be easier and more effective. The standard techniques of angioplasty and stenting will be discussed during the workshop session with emphasis on tricks and tips when encountering difficult lesions. The possible complications that can be expected and their management will also be discussed. Macrocrania in children is a common presenting clinical feature. It affects 5% of the population. Macrocrania is an associated finding in some syndromes in which mental retardation is a cardinal clinical sign. In these cases, the medical problem is of a completely different nature. However, macrocrania in some instances appears isolated. Macrocrania by definition is the consequence of an increased growth of the cranium over the brain. It cannot appear after the closure of the sutures. The role of ultrasound is to check the ventricular size and to exclude massive hydrocephalus. CT scan is usually done following the ultrasound or directly as a first procedure. It will assess the ventricular size, rule out the presence of a brain tumor and look for a chronic subdural effusion. In many cases MRI will be performed to make a precise diagnosis, to appreciate the extent of a tumor or to do MR angiography. Main causes of macrocrania are as follows: hydrocephalus; external hydrocephalus; brain tumors; vascular malformations; vein of galen aneurysms; metabolic diseases; idiopathic. A familial incidence is often found. Mild mental retardation is not unusual. Headache is a very common and usually benign symptom in pediatric patients. Psychogenic headache and migraine are frequent. The classical characteristics of migraine are not always identifiable in younger patients. Organic lesions are present in a minority of children with headache but should be considered in every case. Abnormalities of the eye or maxillofacial area can cause headache. An intracranial lesion is the most feared cause of headache and should be looked for using computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging at the slightest doubt. The aim of the presentation is to give some rules concerning the choice of the imaging technique, depending of the clinical presentation and the degree of emergency. Intracranial lesions that can cause headache will be illustrated, including vascular malformations, either non-ruptured or responsible for subarachnoid hemorrhage, tumors, in particular in the posterior fossa, and hydrocephalus. Socalled benign intracranial hypertension will also be discussed. Neonatal asphyxia remains a considerable problem for neonatologists. Infants presenting with seizures have different patterns of injury, reflecting the aetiology of the insult. The major challenges for the next ten years are to understand these aetiologies and how to recognise their effects on the brain. Particularly important is the issue of timing, not only for medicolegal purposes but for future interventions. MR techniques need to be exploited to improve our understanding of tissue injury and the brain's response to it, so providing novel information to devise suitable interventions whether they be acute e.g. hypothermia or subacute e.g. anti-apoptotic. Serial MR studies coupled with accurate clinical information provide a way of establishing many of these objectives. Ideally post-mortem data should be coupled with MRI data. The current lack of post-mortem examinations The high magnetic field strength combined with strong gradients (40 mT/m) offers several advantages compared to 1.5 T scanners. Higher signal to noise ratio gives us the possibility to increase the resolution and/or shorten the scan time. A 3 T headscanner is smaller than a whole body scanner and has a short bore.To most patients it looks less frightening than ordinary size MRI scanners. This makes it possible to examine younger children and people with slight claustrophobia without using heavy sedation or full anesthesia. MRI-safety is another important issue working with high field MRI. Very few items like surgical clips, shunts or other metallic implants were declared 3 T MR-safe or 3 T MR-compatible when our headscanner was ready for the first patients in January 2002. Studies where we truly can see and appreciate the advantages of scanning with our 3 T headscanner are fMRI, MRA, MRS, perfusion, diffusion and morphological studies that need high resolution images. A brief presentation of these different examinations will be done and information given about specific patient preparations. Necessary additional equipment will be described. Recent experiences from starting up a 3 T whole body scanner will also be presented. Learning Objectives: 1. To gain knowledge about advantages and disadvantages with a 3 T headscanner. 2. To learn more about different functional brain examinations and why 3 T really has advantages compared to lower field strengths. 3. To be able to understand practical difficulties involved working with a high field system and also get some advice, based on our experiences. Not only the applied dynamic gradient fields (which may induce peripheral nerve stimulation), but also the acoustic noise produced by the gradients (which may create hearing damage and makes the use of ear protection essential) and the RF fields transmitted by the RF coils (which results in energy absorption for the patient and ultimately heats up the patient), make it essential to implement safety measures on the system to avoid surpassing of the safety limits. Also the applied static magnetic fields (known to create instantaneous effects such as nausea or dizziness or metal taste) may become a limiting factor for future scanners. The MR specific limits for these parameters for patients are described in the IEC 60601-2-33 international standard for safety of MR equipment (2 nd edition published in 2002). In addition, also the usage of liquid helium filled superconducting magnets poses a risk on the patient and many precautions are necessary to minimize this risk during e.g. a quench of the magnet. In spite of all these potential hazardous situations MR scanners are still considered to be a most safe and patient friendly modality. In MRI, safety issues affect everyday clinical practice. Every patient undergoing an MR examination has to be screened for implants, tattoos, eyeliner, and clothing, i.e. anything which may move in the magnetic field or that can heat up and cause injury. It is important to note that burns are the most reported incident in MRI. Even the way the patient is set up within the bore of the magnet is an important safety issue, especially if there are monitoring devices involved. Another major cause of injury in MR is projectile hazards; this means that all visitors and staff must be screened for potential "missiles" e.g. scissors. Visitors must be made aware of the risk and staff must be trained to minimize the risk. These issues will be discussed in term of good practice within the MR suite. Currently higher and higher field strengths are being installed which in turn means that patients and staff are exposed to higher and higher noise levels; this presents noise protection issues which will be discussed. Another important concern is that of pregnancy and MRI. The current state of play regarding imaging of pregnant patients and pregnant staff working in MRI will be addressed. A-374 C. Safety issues related with interventional MRI A. Bücker; Aachen/DE MR-guidance of interventional procedures requires fast imaging sequence to speed up the procedure and even real-time imaging for guidance of vascular interventions. Interventional devices used have to be MR-safe as well as MRcompatible. Using passive methods for device visualization, one has to be aware of the artifact behaviour of interventional instruments in order to correctly localize the instrument tip. The artifact behaviour can be quite dependent on the applied imaging sequence (gradient versus spin echo) and sequence parameters like echo time and phase encoding direction. Active methods can overcome these potential problems and allow not only for device visualization but also for slice tracking. Drawbacks of active methods are more sophisticated hard-and software requirements. Furthermore safety issues concerning heating of long conductive wires have to be taken into account in order not to jeopardize the patient or interventionalist. First approaches are using fiberoptic means to achieve MRsafe active instrument visualization. While passive device visualization is sufficient for interventions like biopsies, vascular interventions will greatly profit from the possibility of slice and tip tracking of active means especially in the region of small and tortuous vessels. Performing interventions in the MR environment requires special awareness of all personnel involved in the procedure including anesthesiology. Consequently, a dedicated team should be set up in order to avoid accidents due to inexperienced handling of metallic patient support devices. Reporting discrepancies are common in radiology but fortunately only a minority effect patient management. While one can categorise their aetiology as being due to problems of technique, perception, knowledge and judgement, in reality the origins are often multifactorial and systemic. We need to learn lessons from the airline industry in improving safety.Teamworking is fundamental to optimising performance. However, individual accountability still remains even in a systems based culture, and we should have strategies for radiologists in difficulties. Learning from error and discrepancy is very important. We need to have a no blame reporting culture. Patients have the right to know of errors that have adversely effected their care. The communication of this information must be undertaken in a sensitive manner. A simplistic approach to accuracy in radiology needs to be replaced with a more complete model of radiologic performance. Learning Objectives: 1. How some "incorrect" radiological reports may be due to uncertainty or discrepancy rather than error. The scale and causes of error in radiology. 2. How a report can be diagnostically accurate but lack therapeutic impact. The relative infrequency of clinical effect on patients from radiological error. 3. Complacency is not appropriate and how we should learn from error in a supportive environment including properly conducted discrepancy meetings. The application of teamworking in radiology to improve patient safety and working lives.
