back_matter.text: Pitfalls in musculoskeletal MR imaging W.C.G. Peh; Singapore/SG Numerous pitfalls may be encountered in musculoskeletal magnetic resonance (MR) imaging. Those caused by imaging technical factors are potentially preventable, and include optimizing coil selection, slice selection, scan planes, pulse sequences, fat suppression, intravenous and intraarticular use of contrast agents, use of surface markers, and protocol-error artifacts. Common inherent MR artifacts include motion, truncation, chemical shift, susceptibility, fat suppression and the magic angle phenomenon. Normal anatomical structures and variants may also be a source of diagnostic pitfalls. Emphasis is placed on recognizing common potential pitfalls, identifying their causes with the aim of providing a remedy for correctable problems, improving diagnostic accuracy, and avoiding unnecessary treatment or surgery.

B. Transplantation of cartilage K.L.A. Verstraete; Gent/BE Articular cartilage has a limited capacity for repair. Injuries usually progress to degeneration of the articular surface. Injuries that penetrate subchondral bone undergo repair through formation of fibrocartilage. There is an increased interest in and demand for imaging cartilage since more patients are treated with various pharmacological and surgical techniques to repair cartilage. These procedures are most frequently performed in the knee and ankle. Autologous chondrocyte implantation is a technique in which a patient's own cartilage cells are harvested, grown ex-vivo, and reimplanted in a full-thickness articular surface defect, covered by a periosteal patch. The autologous osteochondral transplantation technique uses osteochondral plugs that are harvested from non-load-bearing areas and transferred into the articular defect. In fresh osteochondral allografting, a piece of the articular surface, with a thin layer of subchondral bone from a cadaver is transplanted into a damaged joint. Microperforation and fixation with biodegradable pins are two other repair techniques. The purpose of this lecture is to review different techniques for cartilage repair and transplantation, their indications and contra-indications and to draw special attention on the specific task of the radiologist in preoperative planning and postoperative evaluation of patients undergoing these procedures. The value of plain radiography, CT-scan and MR imaging, including qualitative and quantitative postprocessing techniques, will be discussed. Normal and pathologic imaging findings after autogenous chondrocyte implantation and osteochondral auto-or allografting will be demonstrated. Guidelines for optimal pre-and postoperative evaluation of cartilage will be proposed. The overwhelming number of images from modern scanners is a strong impetus for the development of computer-based support in the diagnostic and therapeutic process. The 80's was the decade of the CT, the 90's was the decade of the MR. Today we are in the middle of the process of making the logistics of image handling fully digital with PACS and workflow management. The next decade will show us the advent of spectacular computer vision techniques: for computer aided diagnosis (mammography CAD is the pioneering success story), interactive 3D visualizations with automated segmentation; image guided surgery and interventions, interventional and surgical simulations, image guided querying of huge image (PACS) databases, and learning recognition principles from these databases. Web-based second opinion systems may appear, and scientists look deeply into human visual perception principles to learn how they can mimic with the computer the spectacular performance of our brain. Learning Objectives: 1. To become familiar with the state-of-the-art in image analysis techniques, presented by European experts with outstanding experience. 2. To comprehend image processing in mammography, in surgery and in our human brain. 3. To get up-to-date with the latest revolution in image analysis techniques, explained in an intuitive, easily understandable way.

Digital mammography and computer aided diagnosis on mammograms N. Karssemeijer; Nijmegen/NL Computer aided detection of breast cancer is gaining acceptance as a new way of improving reader performance in screening mammography. Interpretation of mammograms has been known to be difficult for a long time. It appears that high rates of interval-and late detected cancers are hard to avoid in practice without increasing the rate of false positive referrals to an unacceptable level. Double reading is recommended, but often there are no resources to implement this. Under these circumstances the growing interest in the use of CAD is understandable.First applications of CAD in practice are aimed at avoiding observer errors due to oversight. In this case the CAD system puts prompts on suspicious areas to raise the attention of the reader. In this way errors due to oversight can be reduced. More recently, investigators have begun to explore possibilities for CAD to help radiologists in the diagnostic process. They have realized that part of the problem of screening is the large number of negative cases that have some abnormality. Many mammographic regions are inspected during screening and most do not lead to referral. There is evidence that the majority of screening errors are related to this decision making stage. To deal with this, new applications of CAD are aimed at helping radiologists to improve characterization of abnormalities.In the presentation an overview will be given of recent studies on mammography screening with CAD. Also implications of the introduction of full field digital mammography in relation to CAD will be discussed. Learning Objectives: 1. Better understand the nature of perception errors in breast cancer screening.2. Learn about the state of art of CAD in mammography.3. Gain insight in future development of CAD in the context of full field digital mammography.

Image guided surgery and the operation theatre of the future W.J. Niessen; Utrecht/NL There is an irreversible trend towards minimally invasive interventions. Two technological developments, viz. image guided navigation and advanced surgical instruments play a key role in this development. Image guided navigation allows the visualization of the position of instruments in preoperatively acquired images thus facilitating the use of small incisions. Advanced surgical instruments, e.g. telemanipulation systems, enable the execution of complicated surgical manoeuvres even though instruments (e.g. robot arms) are inserted through small incisions. Some of the scientific, technological and logistical challenges of the widespread introduction of these techniques in the operation theatre are addressed. First, image guided surgery using preoperatively acquired data assumes that these data are representative for the patient in the operation theatre. If this is not the case, intraoperative updates are required. Examples are given how intraoperative 3D ultrasound can be used to compensate for brain shift in image guided neuro interventions, and how intraoperative fluoroscopy can be used to assist in CT-guided orthopaedic interventions. Second, the logistical challenges of the operation theatre, e.g. how to integrate the visualization of the real and the virtual patient, and how to combine advanced surgical instruments with image guided navigation, is discussed. Learning Objectives: 1. Get an verview of the state-of-the art in image guided surgery 2. Get an overview of the scientific, technological and logistical challenges of the introduction of image guided and minimally invasive therapy in clinical routine

Co-Me computer aided and image guided medical interventions G. Székely; Zürich/CH Technology transfer across different areas has dramatically changed the art of medical interventions in the past few years. While a considerable part of this development is already indispensable in today's daily clinical routine, current results represent only the first milestones for medicine in the information age. Widespread integrated use of information technology, image guidance and intelligent instrumentation offers a huge, and up to now only partially understood and explored potential for improved patient care. The main research theme of this Swiss National Center of Competence in Research is to understand and transfer the fundamental potential of modern computer-based technology for the promotion Postgraduate Educational Programme 114 A B C D E F G of a novel paradigm for medical interventions and ultimately of patient care. It lies at the interfaces between basic science, engineering, and medicine. The focus of Co-Me is on the development, integration, and validation of enabling technologies towards advanced computer aided and image guided systems for medical interventions that support the complete treatment process from diagnosis, therapeutic planning and simulation via intra-operative action to postoperative care, monitoring, and documentation. The talk will concentrate on the following important technological development areas aiming at converting radiological data to essential information for optimal image guidance for the clinician: -Image segmentation, especially emphasizing the creation of robust, interactive image analysis systems allowing to solve the segmentation problem in a routine clinical environment. -Cross-modality intra-patient image registration, especially addressing 2D/3D image fusion and non-rigid registration issues. -Simulation techniques to support the functional planning of interventions, like implant and stent placement. Learning Objectives:1. To understand, how current image analysis tools can help to convert radiological data to essential information for optimal image guidance and support during interventions. 2. To become familiar with recent advances in simulation technology and its potential role in diagnostics, therapy and training. 3. To learn about recent results of the Co-Me research network in image segmentation and registration.

Biologically inspired image recognition B.M. ter Haar Romeny; Eindhoven/NL How do we see? Why do we recognize things so much faster and better then a computer? How does it work in our brain? Can we mimic this with software in our workstations, doing computer-aided diagnosis (CAD)? This talk explains visual perception principles for radiologists. The diagnostic workstation is rapidly becoming the super-assistant of the radiologist. The first FDA approvals to CAD programs, and their unexpected success, have triggered widespread attention to automated CAD systems. The field that invents the algorithms for such pattern recognition software is the field of computer vision. Actually, the notion "vision" can be taken literally: more and more inspiration for new clever designs of algorithms is coming from studies of the human visual system, i.e. how visual perception is done by the brain. Progress in understanding the basic physiologic mechanisms has been spectacular: next to studies with fMRI, MEG, diffusion tensor imaging, it is now possible to observe the firing of cortical neurons directly with voltage-sensitive dyes. The first levels of our visual perception in the occipital brain have been modelled carefully with mathematical models. The retina turns out to observe on many different resolutions. The brain has specialized cells for a wide range of features. (1) is to provide detailed preoperative assessment and follow-up including detection and differential diagnosis of recurrence and post-therapy sequelae. The goal in situation (2) is the evaluation of implant complications, tissue necrosis, scarring, local recurrence or new primary. Diagnostic tools are combination of clinical examination, mammography, sonography, MRI and guided biopsy. Additional diagnostic help is obtained by comparison with prior films. The quality of the postoperative imaging depends on preoperative assessment. All the congenital and benign conditions must be known before surgery in order to avoid postoperative interpretation problems. Pathology results and preoperative films as well as prior surgical and/or needle biopsy results must be present. Most of the postoperative complications may be evaluated by mammography and ultrasonography. Complicated cases require guided biopsy and/or MRI. FNA shows lower diagnostic capability among post-therapy conditions than preoperatively. Core/vacuum core biopsy provides more accurate information, therefore these techniques are the methods of choice. Dynamic post-contrast MRI is very useful but the radiologist must be aware of false negative and positive tests. MRI results should always be confronted to other imaging methods. Implants may be screened by ultrasound, but MRI is superior by evaluating the integrity of prosthesis. Gadolinium-enhanced 3 dimensional MRA (3D-Gd-MRA) has already been established as a non-invasive, accurate and safe technique for evaluation of the celiac trunk, the extrahepatic parts of the hepatic artery as well as the proximal parts of the superior mesenteric artery. This is particularly true for atherosclerotic disease as well as for the assessment of anatomic variants prior to liver transplantation or for postoperative controls. 3D-Gd-MRA still faces technical problems in the distal mesenteric vascular bed, in particular the distal arcades. Along with the rather long examination times 3D-Gd-MRA therefore still plays no substantial role in the evaluation of acute mesenteric ischemia. Similarly, the usefulness of the technique for assessment of vasculitis such as polyarteritis nodosa is also limited as small wall irregularities cannot be reliably detected due to a lack of spatial resolution. New k-space acquisition techniques such as parallel imaging, new intravascular contrast agents, as well as 3 Tesla MR systems might overcome these drawbacks. On the other hand, magnetic resonance imaging allows the exquisite combination of 3D-Gd-MRA with functional techniques. Non-invasive MR oxygenation measurements can be used to assess the significance of chronic ischemia in patients with celiac trunk or mesenteric artery stenosis. Phasecontrast flow measurements can be used to assess the flow reserve of the me-senteric vascular bed after caloric stimulation. In radiology the optimisation of imaging using ionising radiation must always consider the reciprocal relationship between radiation dose to the patient and image quality. Multi-detector CT scanners are more dose efficient than their predecessors but, with the facility to reconstruct ever thinner contiguous slices, the temptation is to use that dose efficiency to improve image quality rather than lower the dose. Standard multi-detector CT (MDCT) protocols are to some extent evidence based in that they are derived from protocols that have become established in clinical use and scanner specific modifications are performed with reference to the pref-

Therefore any "optimisation" of protocols should be rigorous and evidence based; at present there is little published data on which to base optimisation of standard protocols, a situation that should improve as MDCT scanning becomes more widespread. MDCT, more than any previous CT technology, broadens the range of alterations that can be made to scanning parameters and therefore requires careful study into how this flexibility is best utilised. The assertion that any radiation dose, no matter how small, can cause cancer is the basis for the linear no-threshold theory of radiation carcinogenesis. However, some health scientists consider the cancer risk from low-dose radiations as used in clinical practice for diagnostic procedures as being grossly exaggerated or even negligible. The European Commission has published precautionary measures in order to limit the radiation dose, in particular from CT, because the dose from a chest CT may be 100 times higher than that from a CRX. The influence of CT parameters (number of detector-rows, beam collimation, KVp, mAs, pitch, CTDIw), of patients parameters (height, weight, body mass index, age, gender, and underlying conditions) as well as of radiologist-dependant parameters on the effective dose are presented. Radiation dose levels from typical standard CT protocols with single and multislice technique are compared to those of a CRX. Low-dose HRCT and multislice CT protocols enable to reduce the radiation per examination by a factor of 10 as compared to standard acquisitions, mainly by decreasing the mAs or by increasing the pitch. Potential benefit in dose reduction by the use of low KVp is presented. Newly developed automatic dose reduction systems are promising because they adapt the tube conditions to the patient's geometry. Distinction has to be made between the radiation dose delivered to one single individual and the collective radiation dose because the effect of diagnostic strategies on the individual and the collective doses may be opposite. B. Broncho-pulmonary foregut malformations: Antenatal and postnatal imaging S. Puig; Vienna/AT The foregut is defined as the anterior part of the alimentary tract leading from the mouth to the entrance of the bile duct. The human lung is a derivative of the primitive foregut and appears by 3 weeks of gestation as an enlargement of the caudal end of the laryngotracheal sulcus of the foregut. Further development of the pulmonary parenchyma includes 4 stages: the pseudoglandular period (5-17 weeks), the canalicular period (16-25 weeks), the saccular period (24 weeks to birth), and the alveolar period (late fetal period to childhood). Each of these stages are marked by distinct changes in tissue organization and cellular differentiation. Structural and functional defects in lung development may lead to a number of abnormalities including bronchopulmonary foregut malformations (BPFM). Routine US screening, performed at week 16 to 20 of gestation, enables the visualization of fetal intrapulmonary malformations. Prenatal MRI, especially with ultra-fast sequences, is an important adjunct helping to differentiate different masses and/or to evaluate large or atypical masses. This is particularly useful for the planning of in-utero interventional procedures, delivery, and immediate postnatal surgery. After birth, BPFM can produce acute respiratory difficulties in the infant. Chest radiography is the primary image tool. For further evaluation, high spatial resolution of contrast enhanced multi-detector CT (MDCT) is recommended to visualize small anatomical structures to either confirm the diagnosis or to demonstrate the exact anatomy for the surgeon. Abdominal distension in the neonate is mainly attributable to intestinal obstruction, urinary tract dilatation, solid or cystic masses, and organomegaly. Intestinal obstruction is the most important cause of distension in the newborn period. The role of imaging may vary from helping to establish a diagnosis, to the evaluation of associated abnormalities, to surgical planning, or to therapy for some conditions like meconium ileus or meconium plug syndrome. Plain abdominal radiographs and sonography can frequently answer the clinically important questions; however, in certain conditions contrast enema is mandatory. CT or MRI is rarely indicated. Ultrasound is the best imaging modality to assess urinary tract dilatation causing abdominal distension, the result of this study guiding the selection of subsequent imaging modalities. Ultrasound is also ideal for the screening of solid or cystic masses and organomegalies. CT and MRI are unsuitable techniques for general screening but they provide excellent anatomic detail and add diagnostic specificity in the evaluation of complex anomalies and for surgical purposes. Continuing professional development (CPD) is now recognised as an essential element of contemporary radiography practice. Whereas CPD has a firmly established role in several specialties, in radiography much work remains to bring all practitioners into the CPD loop. A starting point is increasing awareness of the value of CPD. CPD benefits the individual practitioner, the patient, and the hospital system. For the individual, the acquisition of new or refreshed skills and knowledge enhances job satisfaction and professional self-respect. It may also stimulate new departures in sub-specialisation and research. For the public, CPD ensures contemporary standards of care -essential in an evolving, technology-driven field. For the hospital system, CPD contributes to efficiency, perceived standards of care, and long term success. Nonetheless, multiple barriers stand in the way of successful CPD. These include perceptions that education finishes at graduation, and that non-remunerated time in work-related activities is somehow wasted or unjust. At a hospital or departmental level, day-to-day manpower requirements and financial restrictions frequently impede the development of a CPD program. CPD will always be most effective when it is viewed as a partnership between the individual and employer. In this lecture I will briefly describe the fundamental elements of CPD and its importance to radiography and radiotherapy in the 21 st century. Suggested mechanisms of how to introduce CPD to radiographers, departmental chiefs and administrators will be presented. In particular, the Irish system of CPD will be presented and comparisons of CPD activity with our neighbours in Europe will be drawn. Learning Objectives: After session completion, the participant will have an understanding of: 1. How CPD is an important tool to encourage and motivate professional development. 2. Ways to set up a national CPD program/differences in Europe? 3. What impact will a compulsory program have on health resources -both personnel and financial.
